column20: Direct opens up with the bad news, while indirect starts with a positive message.

column23: It is complimentary, kind words that are used in an indirect approach to negative news.

column9: The Five S's of Goodwill Messages are

column14: Organizes employee development.

column17: Be Selfless
column18: Which of the 5 S's specifies that each message is written from scratch?
column20: Be Spontaneous
column21: What is it called to use the words 'We' or 'I' to begin a goodwill message?
column23: You-Attitude

column9: Which of the following does NOT take place during the planning process?
column11: Proofread the message
column12: What is NOT an example of a medium?
column14: Pencil
column15: What are the three steps in the writing process?
column17: Planning, Completing and Ordering
column18: What step in the process does the message get produced in the medium?
column20: Complete
column21: Which of the following occurs during the completion step?
column23: Revise the message

column9: Which of the following is NOT an example of Positive Message?
column11: Satisfaction Survey
column12: Positive messages are
column14: a type of communication that provides good news, acceptance or congratulations in the work place.
column15: Routine messages
column17: provide the who, what, where, when and why.
column18: What type of message uses templates to allow fast delivery of the information and it can be easily edited?
column20: Routine
column21: Which of the following is NOT an example of a Routine Message?
column23: Satisfaction Surveys

column9: Why are words NOT an element of vocal cues?
column11: Because they are part of verbal communication.
column12: Which of the following is NOT a form of nonverbal communication?
column14: Word choice
column15: How is verbal communication primarily used?
column17: To convey a message.
column18: Which of the following is NOT an example of formal communication?
column20: A discussion at lunch about a new company policy
column21: How does the grapevine function within an organization?
column23: As a form of verbal informal communication that moves quickly in all directions.

column9: Which of the following is the BEST explanation of a communication channel?
column11: The medium by which a message is transmitted.
column12: Which of the following steps occur the least in the communication process?
column14: Feedback
column15: A headache is an example of _____ noise.
column17: physiological

column20: It is the process of transforming a thought into a message that can be sent.
column21: Johny is a second-year freshman. He is having some difficulties in understanding his professor because he did not have enough sleep. Why is this an example of noise?
column23: His fatigue is preventing him from decoding the message.

column9: Which of the following phrases BEST describes communication?

column12: Janice is a manager who is out of town on a business trip. She needs to get some measurements to a member of her staff rather quickly so a presentation can be updated. She chooses to send the information via an email. This is an example of _____.
column14: written communication
column15: Why is communication important in the business world?
column17: It allows businesses to communicate with their customers.
column18: Jon is making a class presentation. He is very uncomfortable and begins to sweat, rock back and forth, and wring his hands. These actions are examples of:
column20: body language.
column21: What type of information is NOT typically conveyed during a communication?
column23: private thoughts

column9: What is another way to characterize an individual who possesses personal power?
column11: a charismatic leader
column12: Which of the following is NOT a basis of formal power?
column14: power coming from the popularity of the manager and his or her ability to create relationship with employees
column15: What's the best explanation of where a person's formal power comes from?
column17: It stems from a person's appointed position.
column18: What's the best explanation of power?
column20: the ability to control resources, people and events to reach objectives and overcome obstacles
column21: What is the basis of personal power?
column23: It is intrinsic to the person who has it.

column9: Sarah works for an independent accounting firm and is performing an audit of the MegaCorp company. MegaCorp offers Sarah's firm a multi-million-dollar consulting contract in the midst of the audit. Under the provisions of The Sarbanes Oxley Act, what action can Sarah legally take?
column11: Sarah can turn down the consulting contract.
column12: Sarbanes-Oxley applies to which of the following types of businesses?
column14: Publicly traded companies
column15: Under Sarbanes-Oxley, what is the best explanation of internal controls for purposes?
column17: Ensures that there is no conflict of interests on the board of directors

column20: To protect investors
column21: If a CEO files a false certification that all material aspects of the company finances are included with a filed report, what type of criminal penalty may the CEO face?
column23: Up to five years in prison and $500,000 fine

column9: How can a company be considered socially responsible?
column11: By minimizing its carbon footprint
column12: Which of the following is NOT an example of social responsibility?
column14: Implementing a hiring freeze for a three-month period
column15: How does a company become socially engaged?
column17: A company should go all in. Engage with the aspects of social responsibility, review them and determine how the company can support them.

column20: Because they care about the environment and want to make the world a better place
column21: Which of the following phrases BEST describes social responsibility?
column23: A company that works to benefit society during the course of its business dealings.

column9: Why does an individual use the process of ethical decision making?
column11: To make a decision guided by ethical principles and values
column12: Tyler is considering outsourcing the marketing department to a foreign country. What might be an ethical dimension of his decision?
column14: The effect on the foreign workers

column17: Ethical policies, relevant laws, and information about the possible alternatives.

column20: Reviewing the decision and modifying it as necessary
column21: Jane has been debating what to do about a case she has been working on. She has made an ethical decision about the case. What should she do next?
column23: Implement her decision

column9: Which of the following is considered a 'low road' approach to business ethics?
column11: Compliance-based ethics
column12: What is the best explanation of ethics?
column14: A system of values and principles guiding behavior
column15: What is a stakeholder?
column17: Any person, group or organization that has an interest in the business
column18: How is a compliance-based code of ethics different from integrity-based ethics?
column20: Compliance-based code is focused on ensuring that the business and its employees comply with all laws and regulations.
column21: Which type of ethical code is often referred to as taking the 'high road?'
column23: Integrity-based ethical codes

column9: An employee of a large multinational firm makes a mistake with a client's account. Company policy dictates that he immediately contact the client and let them know what happened. However, he knows he can fix the mistake easily, without worrying the client. What would the ethical course of action be?
column11: Follow the rules of conduct set up by the company and tell the client what happened.
column12: A CEO of a large company is having some difficulties in dealing with his subordinates. They complain that he is not specific enough about the tasks he assigns them. He is having a problem addressing _____.
column14: Employee relations

column17: They bought and sold energy.

column20: Both are relations that a company has with outside groups or individuals.
column21: Investors depend on which of the following governmental organizations to ensure the stock market stays in order.
column23: The Securities and Exchange Commission

column9: Rebecca runs a research department with specific goals for new product ideas. She lets employees work on their own new product ideas every Friday with little supervision. Rebecca is practicing _____ management.
column11: Theory Y

column14: Douglas McGregor
column15: Mary allows her employees plenty of leeway in how they do their jobs and expects them to motivate themselves to be high achievers. She sets the standard by coming in early and working as hard as they do. The self fulfilling prophecies predict that her employees _____
column17: will motivate themselves and achieve the goals she sets.
column18: Joe thinks that his workers hate their job and only come to work to earn their paychecks. However, he is satisfied with their creativity and imagination when they work on projects. Is Joe a typical Theory X manager?
column20: No, because he believes in their creativity and imagination.

column23: They would rather be told what to do instead of directing themselves

column9: Which of these people is most likely to be a middle manager?

column14: People and Resources

column17: By developing and implementing plans to achieve top management's goals

column20: They work most closely with the general workforce
column21: How are top level managers different from managers at other levels?
column23: They hold the most responsibility for setting the overall direction of the entire company

He assures her that if she can make it through this season he will reward her with time off in the upcoming months. Which skill has the manager used to help Shirley in this situation?
column11: Human

column14: Human

column18: The three managerial skills a manager should possess are:
column20: Technical, human, and conceptual
column21: At what level are technical skills in a manager most important?
column23: Bottom-level management

column11: project management

Denise listens to Justin, both the facts of the situation and his feelings. She is demonstrating which of these essential managerial skills?

column17: Span of control

column17: Employees being flexible and adaptable about their work environment.

column20: John Stacey Adams

He just requested a transfer from marketing to PR. Which of the following is a usual behavior that this employee did NOT do when he felt that he was not being treated equally?
column23: Asking for more equitable treatment.

column9: Identify the three components of expectancy theory.
column11: Expectancy, performance, reward

column17: Victor Vroom

column9: Which of the following is necessary in order to satisfy Maslow's safety needs?

column23: Comfortable working conditions, reasonable work hours, and the necessary breaks to use the bathroom and eat and/or drink.

column23: Only certain employees will perform without being part of the decision.

column14: All of the answers are correct.

column17: Group history and cohesiveness

column20: Hundreds

column23: None of the answers are correct.

column9: Craig is late meeting with his college professor. Choose the BEST answer to explain the type of nonverbal communication Craig displayed.

column14: All answers are correct.

column17: Nonverbal communication is all communication that occurs without words.

column20: Space
column21: Choose the BEST answer to define body language.
column23: Body language is the process of sending nonverbal messages through arms, fingers, expressions, and posture.

column9: Which of the following is important when maintaining good communication?
column11: All answers are correct.

column14: Employes increased performance under all conditions.

column17: hierarchical communication

column9: The management group at Arrow Consulting contains many adventurous members who enjoy extreme sports and like to take risks in their everyday life. When they meet to decide on the direction for their new marketing campaign, the group comes up with an extremely risky approach that will either make the company millions or bankrupt them. How does this situation reflect group polarization?
column11: It demonstrates a situation where the group came up with a collective solution that is more risky than an individual's solution would have been.
column12: How might it be advantageous for a company to bring together a group of people who each have a unique perspective regarding an issue the company faces?

column17: A group of individuals are selected to tackle a problem together in order to achieve a solution.
column18: _____ can hamper the judgment, mental alacrity and effectiveness of a group's decision making through _____.
column20: Groupthink; pressure from the group.

column23: Synergy

column9: The three different types of work teams are
column11: Functional, Cross-functional and Self- Managing

column14: Cross-Functional
column15: What benefit of teams does this describe: Individual workers can't always see the big picture and miss problems.
column17: Detect problems quicker

column20: Conflict, Conformity and Consensus

column23: Consensus

column9: Which of the following is a problem within companies that are ethnocentric?
column11: They like to steal competitor ideas.
column12: What is when an individual assigns generalizations to a group of people based on an incorrect belief?
column14: Stereotyping
column15: What is known as a prejudgment and consists of thoughts and feelings regarding a specific group?
column17: Prejudice

column20: Ethnocentrism
column21: One advantage of ethnocentric type companies is
column23: simple management

column9: All of the following are drawbacks of electronic translators EXCEPT:
column11: They can't understand the language.

column14: Use a qualified interpreter.
column15: Certain words or expressions used by a specific profession, group or culture are referred to as _____.
column17: jargon

column20: Because an interpreter may have difficulty in translating it into something recognizable.

column9: Which orientation views schedules and punctuality as an indispensible part of a work day?

column14: Polychronic

column17: Monochronic

column20: Polychronic
column21: What is the way individuals interpret the use of time?
column23: Chronemics

column9: One criticism of Geert Hofstede's classification of cultures as masculine and feminine is that it _____.
column11: uses gender stereotypes that aren't true all the time
column12: Julio is from a feminine culture. When he's talking about his future goals, Julio is MOST likely to describe how he would like to _____
column14: help others.

column17: By saying that the system will build community and increase job satisfaction

column20: rising through the ranks at her job.
column21: In masculine cultures, is it possible for a woman to display competitive, assertive traits?
column23: Yes, she is just as capable of displaying these traits as her male counterparts if those traits are appealing to her

column9: An example of a culture that utilizes low context communication would be _____.
column11: Switzerland
column12: How should a manager handle a situation where there are employees from low as well as high context cultures?
column14: The manager should manage the interaction and ensure both cultures communicate effectively.
column15: How are messages communicated in a high context culture?

column18: An example of a culture with high context communication would be _____.
column20: Japan
column21: How are messages expressed in a low context culture?
column23: In a very specific and thorough way.

column15: What type of culture believes that the group is more important than an individual?

column18: What type of culture views individuals as independent and able to succeed by themselves?

column21: What type of culture is based on the tenet of self-reliance.

column9: Jack made a business mistake when he asked Yamato's workers for their thoughts on his business ideas. The management structure that exists in Yamato's business is an example of what?

column15: Which communication style attempts to bring understanding to how employees of different cultures speak, communicate and perceive the world around them?
column17: Low context.

column9: Which of the tenets of empathetic communication relies on the ability to be introspective?

column15: What is empathy?
column17: Understanding the feelings of others
column18: What does it mean to put yourself in someone else's shoes?
column20: To try and act like someone else

column9: Why is it important for a speaker or presenter to have self-awareness?

column12: Jerry applied for a job but did not think he had a chance to actually get the job. When he went to the interview, he wore jeans and a t-shirt, arrived late and answered questions from the interviewer without looking him in the eye. Jerry did not get this job. This scenario is an example of _____.

column15: A person who can express and control his or her emotions while also relating and adapting to the emotions of others is said to have high _____.
column17: emotional intelligence

column20: They can relate to customers' complaints and be understanding while also solving problems.
column21: Which of these choices provides an example of a person with good intrapersonal intelligence?

column9: Which of the following is NOT a factor that affects communication in a diverse workplace?
column11: Employees' preference for timely communication
column12: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of communication in a diverse work environment?
column14: A diverse workforce supports the company's predominant culture.
column15: In some cultures, _____ in face-to-face communication is considered aggressive and intrusive.

column18: Kelly manages a small team and noticed that for the last few weeks, Dashawn has been incredibly efficient and his work error-free. column20: How he has responded to compliments in the past.
