column9: Anne applies for a job at a manufacturing plant and sees a bunch of union information in the HR department. She asks if she has to join a union in order to get a job. The HR rep tells her she can join the union if she wants but does not have to do so. What type of shop is the company?
column11: Open shop
column12: Casey goes into the town's factory to apply for a production job. She is told that if hired, she will have to join the union. What type of shop is the company?
column14: Union shop
column15: Abe is applying for a job at a plant. When asked if he's a member of the union by the HR he says he's not. The HR rep informs Abe that he cannot be hired because the company only hires union workers. What type of shop is the company?
column17: A closed shop.
column18: Which piece of legislation outlawed closed shops in the United States?
column20: The Taft-Hartley Act
column21: Who or what determines whether a company is an open or a union shop?
column23: The collective bargaining agreement.

column9: Nate's job is to receive grievances from union members and try to resolve them with management. He'll also try to recruit new members and educate members about the union. What's Nate's role?
column11: Shop steward
column12: What human resource management function relates directly to dealing with unions?
column14: Labor relations
column15: Mark was elected by the general membership and is responsible for heading up the day-to-day operations of the union. What is his role?
column17: President
column18: Which one of the following groups has the most powerful role in a union?
column20: General membership
column21: Why do workers join a union?
column23: In hopes of better wages

column9: Which of the following is NOT a rule of the collective bargaining process?
column11: The union can waive an employer's statutory duties by agreement.
column12: Which of the following procedures would NOT be a part of the collective bargaining process?
column14: Board of Director appointments
column15: Which of the following is NOT an important characteristic of collective bargaining?
column17: When parties have equal bargaining power, employers maintain an advantage over the workers and the agreement will favor management.
column18: John is employed by ABC Manufacturing and is represented, along with his coworkers, by the XYZ Union. John has become unhappy with the amount of overtime he is working and is seeking a solution to this problem. John's best legal course of action is to:
column20: Approach the union representative with his problem, as this person has the sole authority to represent the workers.
column21: What is the purpose of the National Labor Relations Act?
column23: It provides workers with the right to unionize and collectively bargain.

column9: Which of these best describes the proposal step of the collective bargaining process ?
column11: Management makes an initial offer to the union
column12: Sammy Slugger the famous baseball player is having contentious negotiations with his team ownership about what he should be paid next year. The Baseball Commissioner has called for an arbitrator to end the dispute, the arbitrators ruling will be binding. What does this mean for Sammy and the owner?
column14: The arbitrator will determine Sammy's new salary
column15: Which of these best describes the negotiating step of the collective bargaining process ?
column17: The two sides make offers and counter offers
column18: Why do unions and company management enter into collective bargaining?
column20: To jointly come to agreement on workplace issues.
column21: Why do most strikes occur ?
column23: Because the union does not feel satisfaction with the negotiations

column9: Mary is a welder and a member of a union. Her fellow members include Paul, a production worker, Janice, a janitor, and Mike a machinist. They all work in an automobile factory. What type of union is this?
column11: An industrial union
column12: Tom is a carpenter and is a member of a union. All of his union members are also carpenters. In fact, only carpenters can be part of his union. What type of union is this?
column14: A craft union
column15: What are the benefits and drawbacks of being part of a union?
column17: Unions members get more benefits, but employers don't want to pay them higher wages.
column18: Why do you think the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Independent Organizations wanted to merge in 1955?
column20: They could accomplish more for their members if they were one big union.
column21: Which of the following is NOT a factor relating to the decline in union membership and influence?
column23: Government sponsored unions, which compete with other unions

column9: What type of agency is the National Labor Relations Board?
column11: An independent federal agency
column12: The process of employees deciding whether or not to cease union representation is called:
column14: Decertification election.
column15: Which of the following is NOT a function of the National Labor Relations Board?
column17: Empowering employers to dissolve a union that negatively impacts their company.
column18: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of the National Labor Relations Board?
column20: Members of the National Labor Relations Board are confirmed by the United States House of Representatives.
column21: The National Labor Relations Board consists of _____ members.

column9: Which of the following is an exception permitting class-based discrimination usually prohibited by Title VII?
column11: If the class characteristic is a bona fide job qualification
column12: What is used to establish the damage cap a plaintiff may demand of the company in either punitive or compensatory damages?
column14: The number of employees of the company
column15: How did the Civil Rights Act of 1991 impact workers abroad?
column17: It extended coverage of Title VII to U.S. citizens that work abroad for U.S. companies as well as for Senate employees.
column18: Identify which of the following types of organizations is NOT subject to Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964:
column20: A start-up with only 5 employees.
column21: Which of the following is FALSE regarding the Civil Rights Act of 1964 as amended by the Civil Rights Act of 1991?
column23: Discriminatory intent is required to establish liability

column9: What principle underlying the NLRA supports the proposition that a union representative should not be a manager in the company?
column11: Structural autonomy
column12: Which of the following was created by The Civil Service Reform Act?
column14: The United States Merit Systems Protection Board
column15: Why did the Taft-Hartley Act outlaw certain actions, like wildcat strikes?
column17: The Taft-Hartley act was passed in response to concerns that the NLRA gave labor unions too much power.
column18: What is the best definition of a wildcat strike?
column20: A strike based upon politics
column21: What is a closed shop?
column23: A company that doesn't hire union workers

column9: Which of the following is incorrect about the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act?
column11: It authorizes training and funding for training
column12: How many days prior notice must a covered employer usually provide a covered employee pursuant to WARN?
column14: 60 days
column15: What's the best explanation of bumping in the context of the WARN Act?
column17: An employee with more seniority taking the job of an employee with less seniority
column18: A tornado takes down a company's major client causing the company to undertake a massive layoff that usually requires a 60 days notice under WARN. Is there an exception to this requirement under these circumstances. If so, what is it?
column20: The unforeseen business circumstances exception applies
column21: Where does one go to seek enforcement of WARN?
column23: U.S. District Court
column24: Which of the following correctly describes those covered by the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act (WARN)?
column26: Full-time bank employees terminated when the function performed by their entire 200-person department was outsourced to another company.

column9: Todd is the Operations Manager for Quality Granite. He cares for the company and the employees and wants to comply with OSHA safety regulations. What must Todd do to be in compliance?
column11: Todd needs to keep up-to-date records of employee illness and injury.
column12: If a company receives a citation and fine from OSHA, who would hear the appeal?
column14: Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission
column15: Ed works for Stellar Solar Installations, Ben works for the DEA (Drug Enforcement Agency), and Sam is a self-employed contractor for an online education company. Which of these employees is subject to the rights set forth by OSHA?
column17: None of the employees are subject to the rights set forth by OSHA.
column18: Which of the following is FALSE about OSHA?
column20: It is the only agency that can regulate workplace health and safety.
column21: Ron just got a job in an industrial plant that manufactures specialty car parts. Since this is a new field for Ron he must buy the necessary safety attire to work at the plant. Which of the following must the employer pay for as required by OSHA?
column23: The employer must pay for all of the attire.

column9: Who will eventually be able to utilize the SHOP marketplace?
column11: Employers with up to 50 full-time equivalent employees.
column12: Which of the following is NOT part of the series of healthcare reforms that are associated with the Affordable Care Act?
column14: Provisions for long term-care for seniors
column15: What is the maximum tax credit for which a small business may qualify for under the Affordable Care Act if it provides a qualifying health care plan to its employees?
column17: 50% of the value of the employer's contribution to the insurance premiums.
column18: Which of the following companies is subject to the Employer Shared Responsibility provision under the Affordable Care Act?
column20: An employer who has 28 full-time employees and 50 part-time employees who each work at least 20 hours on average.
column21: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding the Affordable Care Act?
column23: Employers are required to provide health coverage for their employees.

column9: An employee is injured in a forklift accident. An investigation discovers that the forklift was defective and the manufacturer had issued a recall notice but the employer had not complied with it yet. The employee receives workers' compensation benefits for the injury. What litigation options would give the employee the BEST chance of success?
column11: Suing the manufacturer of the forklift.
column12: Mark is an employee that has worked for 20 years in a retail company. He has to undergo a liver transplant due to years of substance and alcohol abuse. Why is he NOT eligible for worker's compensation during that time?
column14: Because this is an example of a personal risk that has nothing to do with work.
column15: Tim cuts his hand at work, requiring bandaging at the first aid station, but he returns to work immediately. He is able to continue coming to work until he resigns because his supervisor was very strict and often yelled. The injury did not inflict any permanent damage. Why is Tim NOT entitled to indemnity benefits?
column17: Because he suffered no loss of income as a result of the cut.
column18: Which of the following would be an event that would make a worker qualified for workers' compensation benefits?
column20: When a researcher gets hurt while performing an experiment at work because the equipment is out-of-date.
column21: Sara is injured at work, and is confined to a bed for a week while she fully recovers. What's the most likely indemnity benefit she will receive?
column23: Temporary total disability benefits

column9: What law is part of unemployment compensation?
column11: The Social Security Act
column12: Who administers unemployment compensation?
column14: State governments
column15: How are unemployment compensation benefits related to the economy of a country?
column17: Unemployment compensation benefits can provide a stimulus to the economy of a country.
column18: How is unemployment compensation funded?
column20: By state and federal payroll taxes paid by the employer
column21: Select the statement that is NOT correct regarding unemployment compensation.
column23: All unemployed individuals are eligible.

column9: Which of the following is NOT a requirement for an employee to receive COBRA benefits?
column11: Your company has to sign off on your COBRA benefits
column12: What do COBRA benefits cost the employee?
column14: Up to the full price of the insurance premium plus an administrative fee of two percent
column15: Which of the following is NOT a qualifying event for purposes of COBRA benefits?
column17: Termination from employment due to gross misconduct
column18: Identify which of the following is an example of a profile where COBRA may be extended to up to 36 months:
column20: A young college student from Boston who lost his dependent child status and whose father recently lost his job
column21: Identify which of the following benefited MOST from COBRA:
column23: The children of a person who recently lost his job

column9: An employee is granted FMLA leave to take care of a seriously sick spouse unrelated to military service. How much unpaid leave may he use?
column11: 12 weeks
column12: Select the statement that best describes the Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA).
column14: FMLA requires certain employers to provide unpaid leave to eligible employees under certain circumstances.
column15: How many hours must have an employee worked during a 12 month period before being eligible for FMLA leave?
column18: How long must an employee have worked with a covered employer to qualify for FMLA leave?
column20: 12 months
column21: Who enforces FMLA?
column23: The U.S. Department of Labor
column24: Which of the following is NOT covered by FMLA?
column26: Care for a friend with a serious illness

column9: Which of the following is NOT covered by the Fair Labor Standards Act?
column11: Employment discrimination
column12: Which of the following is NOT legal, based on the FLSA?
column14: A 15-year-old from New York working 4 hours every day except during the weekend.
column15: A worker is paid $8.00 per hour and his boss is asking him to work overtime because several people are sick. Based on the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), what is the minimum wage that he must be paid for his work overtime?
column18: Sue is 16 years old and wants a job. What limitations does the FLSA place upon Sue's employment?
column20: She cannot work in certain hazardous employment activities.
column21: A restaurant owner pays one of his waiters the federal minimum of $7.25 dollars an hour in a state with a minimum wage of $8.50 an hour. Why are such actions legal?
column23: Because there is specific regulation for employees that get tips.

column9: How is a defined benefit plan different from a defined contribution plan?
column11: A defined benefit plan is the traditional pension plan while defined contribution plan is a retirement plan where an employee defers some of her pay into the plan.
column12: What is true of a fiduciary under ERISA?
column14: A fiduciary works solely in the interest of participants and beneficiaries and that is consistent with ERISA.
column15: Which of the following is the enforcing department for ERISA?
column17: The U.S. Department of Labor
column18: Identify the statement that is NOT correct about ERISA.
column20: ERISA provides a right for an employee to sue the administrator of a plan for violations of ERISA.
column21: What federally charted corporation is established by ERISA?
column23: PBGC

column9: The Equal Pay Act of 1963 includes the following components of 'pay' EXCEPT _____.
column11: work schedules
column12: Which of the following enforces the Equal Pay Act?
column14: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission
column15: As of 2013, which of the following is true regarding the pay gap between men and women?
column17: Women average 77% of the pay men receive.
column18: Which of the following is not one of the four general factors used to determine if the work is equal for purposes of the EPA?
column20: Same seniority of tenure
column21: According to the EEOC, there can be pay differentials between male and female employees if _____.
column23: it is based on some legitimate factor, such as seniority

column9: What special practices and procedures must be followed concerning a pregnant employee?
column11: Employers must use the same practices and policies with pregnant employees as they do with other temporarily disabled employees.
column12: Holly has just gotten pregnant. Usually Holly goes on a large number of sales calls, which requires her to travel frequently. A doctor has recommended she limit her traveling because of certain symptoms with her pregnancy. According to the PDA, is the company obligated to adjust Holly's job duties while she is pregnant and experiencing these symptoms?
column14: Yes; PDA covers medical conditions and the company would need to adjust her work duties.
column15: What type of conditions cover the PDA?
column17: All of the answers are correct.
column18: Who enforces the PDA?
column20: EEOC
column21: Which type of employer is subject to the PDA?
column23: Employers employing at least 15 employees

column9: The ADEA applies to:
column11: Employers employing at least 20 people.
column12: Who is protected under the ADEA?
column14: Every employee and job applicant who is at least 40 years old.
column15: How is a hostile work environment different from an adverse employment action?
column17: Both hostile work environments and adverse employment actions are not protected under the ADEA.
column18: Identify the employment practice that is NOT a violation of the ADEA:
column20: Requiring a physical test to establish an employee's ability to perform a job that excludes many elderly employees.
column21: Which organization is responsible for enforcing the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, 1967?
column23: The Department of Labor

column9: How may an employer require a medical exam and not violate the ADA?
column11: A physical exam may be required after a job offer has been extended, but only if all new employees for the same position are subject to the same exam.
column12: Why might an employer be allowed to refuse an accommodation under the ADA?
column14: If the accommodation poses an undue hardship on the employer
column15: Identify the statement that best describes a disabled individual within the meaning of the ADA.
column17: A person with a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits a major life activity
column18: Who enforces the ADA?
column20: The EEOC
column21: Which type of employer is subject to the ADA?
column23: All publicly traded companies

column9: Which of the following types of employment discrimination is prohibited under Title VII?
column11: Discrimination based on gender
column12: Who enforces Title VII?
column14: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission
column15: An employer presents evidence of a legitimate, non-discriminatory reason for the action that formed the basis of an employment discrimination lawsuit. What happens next?
column17: The employee must establish that the purported motive offered by the employer was a mere pretext.
column18: An employer can retaliate against an employee for _____.
column20: Failing to show up to work on successive days without providing an acceptable excuse
column21: What is a key difference between a typical employment discrimination lawsuit and a lawsuit based on disparate impact?
column23: A typical lawsuit is brought by rival employers, while disparate impact actions are caused by acts of discriminatory intent.

column9: Title VII is part of which legislation?
column11: The Civil Rights Act of 1964
column12: Which of the following employers are subject to Title VII?
column14: Private sector employers and local and state government agencies that employ at least 15 people.
column15: Which of the following instances of discrimination is NOT prohibited by Title VII?
column17: A 61 year old job candidate was not hired because of his age.
column18: Which of the following agencies is responsible for enforcing Title VII?
column20: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission
column21: Which of the following employment practices is subject to Title VII?
column23: All of the answers are correct.

column9: Which of the following statements is inaccurate regarding sexual harassment?
column11: It is a form of unwanted sexual advances and may be illegal, but only if it's against the company's policy.
column12: A company with 60 employees engages in government contract business and has revenue of $50,000,000. Why is this company subject to policies of affirmative action?
column14: The company has contracts with the government and has more than 50 employees.
column15: Identify which of the following individuals would NOT be considered a covered employee under the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Title VII:
column17: A middle-aged white male from New Jersey
column18: How did the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) impact the Civil Rights Act of 1964?
column20: It helped to not only enforce, but to expand the prevention of discrimination as defined in the Civil Rights Act.
column21: Which of the following would assist an employer in dealing with an employee's pregnancy discrimination claim?
column23: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC)

column9: Why is rust-out dangerous in a work environment?
column11: Because lack of challenge and opportunity makes workers less productive.
column12: Identify which of the following is an example of psychological symptom of stress at work:
column14: When a manager is suffering from depression and causing difficulties within their work environment.
column15: Jane works in a high-stress job at a marketing company and is experiencing headaches and stomach pains almost every day. What type of symptom relating to stress are these?
column17: Physiological
column18: Which of the following is an example of a behaviorial symptom of stress?
column20: Substance Abuse
column21: Why are backaches a common symptom of work-related stress?
column23: Because it's part of the body's reaction to prepare for fight or flight.

column9: John received a promotion at GTC Company, Ltd. last month, but he still does not know how his tasks will change. This uncertainty causes stress that manifests itself in feelings of lack of control and concern about career progress. Which category of stress is John actually going through?
column11: Task demands
column12: How is a challenge stressor different from a hindrance stressor?
column14: A challenge stressor is positive in nature while a hindrance stressor has negative impacts.
column15: What kind of stresses are placed on individuals by themselves such as volunteer work, overworking and traumas?
column17: Personal Demands
column18: Vicky has just been appointed to work as helper in a restaurant. She works for 7 hours a day either standing or walking around to perform her tasks. What type of demand is Vicky facing?
column20: Physical Demand
column21: Identify the set that consists of work demand stresses.
column23: task, role, interpersonal and physical demands

column9: The owner of James' Small Engine Repair has decided to purchase gym memberships for all of his employees. This is an example of a _____ work-life program.
column11: fitness and healthy living
column12: Work-life balance is:
column14: an organizational concept that empowers employees to split time and energy between work and other important areas of their life successfully.
column15: Carla is taking 30 days off of work to organize a breast cancer awareness program in her community. This is an example of what type of work-life program:
column17: Leave of Absence/Vacation
column18: Businesses offer work-life balance programs in order to _____
column20: reduce turnover.
column21: XYZ Corp. will allow all office workers the chance to work from home on Fridays. This is a _____.
column23: Flexible work arrangement

column9: Which of the following is an example of an off-duty act by an employee?
column11: Posting about the employer on a personal Facebook page while at home.
column12: What type of legal liability does an employer seek to avoid by performing background checks on all applicants?
column14: Negligent hiring
column15: Which of the following creates workplace health and safety standards that employers must follow?
column17: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration.
column18: Ann has interviewed for a job with a new company. She has been informed that a background check will be completed as part of the hiring process. This may involve all of the following, EXCEPT _____.
column20: A review of previous tax returns
column21: John has discovered that his employer has been monitoring his email account and telephone calls while he's at work. John is very upset, but is told the company has the right to do so because _____.
column23: the communication utilized company equipment

column9: Jane was fired because she filed a workers' compensation claim. Why will a court likely rule the company has to reinstate Jane?
column11: Public policy protects the statutory rights of workers.
column12: Which of the following is NOT allowed by the employment-at-will doctrine?
column14: A manager firing a junior partner because of her religion
column15: How can an employee and employer prevent application of the employment-at-will doctrine?
column17: By entering into an employment contract
column18: An employment handbook tells Mary that she will not be fired except for good cause. Mary is subsequently fired because a manager doesn't like her personality. Which of the following exceptions to the employment-at-will doctrine may be applied?
column20: Implied covenant of good faith exception
column21: Why do many employees perceive the employment-at-will doctrine as a double-edged sword?
column23: Because it means your employer can easily fire you, but it also allows you to walk out at any time

column9: Which theory claims that executive compensation is not truly based upon performance or arms-length negotiation?
column11: Managerial power theory
column12: A/n _____ is a specific fixed payment that is usually calculated annually and paid throughout the year in regular installments.
column14: Base salary
column15: What is the difference between bonuses and stock options?
column17: Bonuses are variable and conditional on executives achieving certain performance standards, while stock options allow executives to purchase company stock at a set price for a certain period of time.
column18: Which of the following statements best describes the current trend of executive compensation in the United States?
column20: Executive compensation is growing at a faster rate than employee compensation.
column21: Which of the following would NOT be part of an executive's lucrative benefits?
column23: Commissions

column9: At the end of the year, Sue receives an additional payment representing a fraction of the net earnings of her company for the year. Why is this an example of profit sharing?
column11: Because she receives part of the company's profit
column12: Which of the following is FALSE about gain sharing?
column14: Employees share in the profits earned
column15: Tina's employer gives her a contract that allows her to purchase company stock in the future at a set price. Tina has chosen to purchase the stock in two-to- three days and based on the contract she must hold it for at least one month before she can exercise them. This doesn't bother her as she didn't plan to sell them for at least six months when she wants to buy a new car. What is the vesting period in this case?
column17: One month
column18: Mary receives a bonus at the end of the year based on a percentage of money she and her fellow employees saved the company by improving efficiency and reducing waste. Why is this an example of gain sharing?
column20: Because it rewards employees for reducing waste and improving efficiency
column21: What do stock options, profit sharing, and gain sharing have in common?
column23: All align employees' interests with the owners' interests

column9: Edward is a computer programmer who just got a raise after successfully earning a certification in a new programing language the company uses. What type of incentive pay did he earn?
column11: Skills-based pay
column12: David sells shoes in a retail company. His boss agreed to pay him a commission for each pair of shoes he sells. Which of the following statements is an example of what his boss promised?
column14: Dave has a base salary and also receives 5% of the value for each pair of each shoes he sells.
column15: Jane is a CEO of an IT company and the department that she manages raised in 2 days what it takes other departments to earn in a month. For that Jane received a $100,000 bonus. Why is this an example of a spot bonus?
column17: Because it was earned in a relatively short period
column18: Bob's annual performance review showed a marked improvement in his productivity. As a result, he is given a raise. Why is this an example of merit pay?
column20: It is additional pay based on past results in the company.
column21: Cathy works as a stylist cutting hair. She gets paid for each haircut. Why is this example of piecework?
column23: She is paid per unit produced or service performed.

column9: John's retirement benefit is based upon a formula consisting of his years of service and the average of his salary during his final years of work. The company is obligated to make these payments. What type of retirement benefit does he have?
column11: A traditional defined benefit pension
column12: Which of the following laws regulate defined benefit and defined contribution plans?
column14: ERISA
column15: Which of these is correct about a defined contribution retirement plan?
column17: The employer puts a specified amount into the plan each year.
column18: Tiffany's employer set up a retirement account for her where she can contribute part of her salary. The plan also provides that her employer will make yearly contributions to her retirement account as well. Which of the following best describes the plan?
column20: A 401(k) plan
column21: How are benefits calculated in Fred's cash balance retirement plan?
column23: His benefits are based on a hypothetical cash balance.

column9: How are mandatory benefits different from voluntary benefits?
column11: Only mandatory benefits are required by law.
column12: Which of the following is NOT an example of indirect financial compensation?
column14: Salary
column15: Which benefit is only partly paid by employers?
column17: Social Security benefits
column18: Which of the following is an example of a mandatory benefit?
column20: Unemployment insurance
column21: _____ is a voluntary benefit offered by employers.
column23: 401(k) plan

column9: Bob and Rob work for the same company. They have the same responsibilities and the qualifications. They also perform equally well, but Rob is paid more than Bob. This is an example of which of the following?
column11: Internal inequity
column12: Which of the following can result from compensation inequity?
column14: Resentment
column15: Bob is a machinist who discovers that machinists at the neighboring factory are paid a higher wage than he is for doing the same job. This is an example of what?
column17: External inequity
column18: John and Mary work as computer programmers at the same company. John has an additional programming certification and three more years at the company so he is paid more. This is an example of which of the following?
column20: Employee equity
column21: Tim and Anne were hired on the same day at the same company. They have similar skill sets and do the same job. However, Anne is paid less than Tim. Which of the following laws is being violated?
column23: Equal Pay Act

column9: Tabatha is an accountant. She's paid a base salary in addition to the possibility of more compensation if she exceeds the firm's minimum billable hours she's expected to generate. What is this type of compensation system called?
column11: Pay-for-performance
column12: Tanya is negotiating with her employer about a new contract. They have agreed that she will be paid by commission. Identify which of the following BEST reflects such a deal:
column14: If she's paid a percentage of all revenue that she generates for the company
column15: What type of compensation is employer-sponsored health care?
column17: Indirect financial compensation
column18: John is working for an IT company based upon a contract and the company doesn't withhold any payroll taxes when it pays him. Which is most likely true about John's employment?
column20: He is self-employed and working as an independent contractor so payroll taxes are not withheld
column21: Stan is paid $10 for each hour he works. Why is this an example of a wage?
column23: It is an example of a commission.

column9: Which of the following is an example of non-financial compensation?
column11: Your manager deciding you're doing such a good job that he will give you more autonomy in decision making.
column12: Alex is paid a salary of $35,000 a year with the potential for further money if he meets certain performance goals. Why is this an example of direct financial compensation?
column14: It is an example of direct payment for labor.
column15: Beth receives stock options from her employer as part of her overall compensation package. What type of compensation is this?
column17: Indirect
column18: Why is it important to conduct a salary survey?
column20: Because it's important for the employer to know how well a certain position is paid
column21: Which of the following is an example of internal equity in the context of compensation?
column23: All employees that have the same level of experience and skill receiving the same sum of money

column9: Stock options are considered _____
column11: a benefit
column12: Non-exempt employees who receive wages are paid _____.
column14: for every hour they work
column15: Mary is an exempt supervisor of the accounting department. She worked 60 hours last week closing the books for month end. How much will she be paid ?
column17: One week's salary
column18: Tom was top salesperson in the department and won a contest. His prize includes: a cash bonus, a small raise in his salary, the ability to buy company stock at a discount price and a slightly more flexible schedule. Identify which of these is indirect compensation:
column20: A slightly more flexible schedule
column21: Jonas, the owner of a small engine repair shop, is going to give all of his employees a paid day off on New Year's Eve if profit goals for the year are achieved. This form of compensation is called:
column23: an incentive.

column9: Joe works in the data entry department. He has become dissatisfied with his job. He never used to take time off, but lately he has been taking sick days. His work is now sloppy and full of errors. Which response to dissatisfaction is Joe demonstrating?
column11: Neglect
column12: Julie has worked in the same position for a financial firm for six years. She is generally happy but would like a new challenge. After two years, a new position finally becomes available, and she applies for it. She is qualified but is rejected in favor of Karen, an outsider with more experience. What can company management expect from Julie?
column14: Julie may become dissatisfied and perceive the firm as limiting her career growth.
column15: How should a company respond if employees voice their issues or appear dissatisfied with their jobs?
column17: Be attentive and try to resolve employees' concerns
column18: What general four categories does job dissatisfaction fall into?
column20: underpaid, limited career growth, poor management, lack of interest
column21: Why is it important for a company to monitor levels of employee dissatisfaction?
column23: Dissatisfied employees may create high turnover

column9: Which of the following is NOT part of the Management by Objective (MBO) process?
column11: Management has the final say on the company's objectives.
column12: Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding the role of employees in the Management by Objective (MBO) process?
column14: Employees know their opinions will be heard and reviewed.
column15: How is Management by Objective (MBO) BEST defined?
column17: Managers and employees collaborate to set objectives; their collective buy-in increases the organization's success.
column18: Which of the following was established by Peter Drucker's Management by Objective (MBO) concept?
column20: It started the practice of management listening to employees, and marrying that with the thoughts and ideas of management.
column21: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of Management by Objective (MBO)?
column23: A company's stock increases in price.

column9: Jill is concerned that her employees are stagnating and not developing their skills as she had hoped. Jill believes that _____ will help the employees assess their work and generate skill development plans.
column11: self assessments.
column12: How would a manager implement Management by Objective (MBO) in her employee appraisals?
column14: By collaborating with each employee on goal setting
column15: The CEO of XYZ Corp. will be conducting reviews with his top managers. He has asked them to get feedback from lower level supervisors and outside vendors with whom they work. Which method is the CEO using to review his top managers?
column17: 360 Degree Feedback.
column18: Top-down appraisals measure employee performance against goals _____
column20: set by management.
column21: Employee appraisals are for _____.
column23: all employees

column9: Matt the manager is completing an appraisal that consists of answering multiple choice questions regarding his employees' traits. Which appraisal method is Matt using?
column11: Forced choice
column12: A large corporation uses an appraisal method where the bottom 10% of employees must show immediate improvement or be terminated. Which appraisal method are they using?
column14: Forced distribution
column15: Edward is a supervisor evaluating an employee by writing an essay about the employee's performance. Which type of appraisal method is he using?
column17: Narrative
column18: Lisa is reviewing the results of recent performance appraisals that have been plotted on a graph in the form of a bell curve. Which type of performance appraisal can be graphically represented this way?
column20: Forced distribution
column21: Sarah the supervisor would like an appraisal system that doesn't rank employees or compare them with one another. Which appraisal method should Sarah use?
column23: Narrative

column9: Which of these is a major benefit to using graphic rating scales?
column11: They are easy to design and use.
column12: Sal is a supervisor for a cellphone assembly contractor. To design a new appraisal method, he has brought in a consultant. They will do a thorough job analysis to identify the most efficient way to assemble phones and the behaviors assemblers need to have. Which appraisal method are they working on?
column14: BARS
column15: Sara is a supervisor at a call center. She monitors her employees' calls and keeps a record for each employee of times when they provided exceptional customer service as well as when service was not helpful or substandard. Which appraisal method is Sara using?
column17: Critical incident
column18: Beth is a teller supervisor at the bank. She gives each teller a rating for their accuracy, customer service and salesmanship. Which appraisal method is Beth using?
column20: Graphic rating scales
column21: Which of the following appraisal methods uses vertical scales based, in part, upon job analysis?
column23: BARS

column9: What is a formal system used to assess performance and effectiveness of employees and teams of employees known as?
column11: Performance appraisal
column12: Justin is a university professor in economics. The criteria for his performance appraisal is his knowledge of economics and his ability to teach it to students. Which type of standards are being used in his appraisal?
column14: Competencies
column15: Fred is a football coach. The criteria for his appraisal will be how many games his team wins this year. Which type of standards are being used in his appraisal?
column17: Results
column18: Bethany is a salesperson at the cellphone store. Her performance appraisal is based on her ability to talk to the customers and build relationships with them. Which type of standards are being used in her appraisal?
column20: Behavioral
column21: Kate is a data entry clerk. Part of her performance appraisal is how much she is never satisfied with her work if isn't perfect. Which type of standards are being used in her appraisal?
column23: Results

column9: A performance appraisal using criteria correlated to the goal assessed has which characteristic?
column11: Relevancy
column12: An appraisal that can differentiate between effective employees and ineffective employees has which characteristic?
column14: Sensitivity
column15: Sarah has complained that the performance appraisal her company has her use is too complicated for many to understand, and simply isn't very useable. Sarah is complaining that the performance appraisal is lacking:
column17: practicality.
column18: Bob did a performance appraisal for an employee in his department. Ellen works in the same department and did a performance appraisal for the same employee. Bob and Ellen got different results. What is the performance appraisal lacking?
column20: Reliability
column21: A performance appraisal supported by an organization's members has which characteristic?
column23: Acceptability

column9: Why would performance appraisals be useful to a company that is investing in employee development?
column11: To assess the effectiveness of their development training by evaluating the employee before and after
column12: Which of the following is NOT a developmental function of performance appraisals?
column14: Personnel planning
column15: A performance appraisal is best used for:
column17: Evaluating an employee's past performance and helping future development
column18: Which of the following is NOT an administrative use of performance appraisals?
column20: Individual employee feedback
column21: What is a formal system of assessing an employee's effectiveness and productivity called?
column23: Performance appraisal

column9: Which of the following errors involves rating everyone pretty much as average?
column11: Central tendency error
column12: The executive director wants to save time on his performance appraisals of mid-level management. He rates all of his managers as excellent to finish the process quickly. Which rating error is being committed?
column14: Leniency error
column15: A supervisor rated five very poor performers and then incorrectly rates the sixth as an above average performer even though the employee is only average. What type of rating error is this?
column17: Contrast error
column18: Steve is considering Paul's performance on the job within the last few months. Which of the following rater errors is he most likely to make because he is thinking about a current impression of an employee's performance?
column20: The recency effect
column21: Which one of the following is a benefit of performance appraisals?
column23: Guide for offering promotions and raises

column9: Beth the bank manager wants to implement the hot stove rule in her discipline for employees breaking the rules. Which of these should she do?
column11: Discipline all employees who break rules consistently
column12: Joe has previously received verbal and then written warnings about taking long lunch hours, yet he continues to return one half hour later than he should. What should be the next step in progressive discipline for Joe?
column14: Suspension without pay
column15: An automotive assembly line has strict rules about wearing safety glasses in work areas. Felix is a good employee with no prior rule violations. Today his supervisor sees him in the work area without his glasses. What should the manager do next under progressive discipline?
column17: Give Felix a verbal warning
column18: Matt the manager follows the hot stove rule of discipline. He observes one of his employees breaking a rule by making many personal phone calls on company time. What should Matt do next?
column20: Reprimand the employee immediately
column21: What should the primary purpose be for engaging in an employee disciplinary action?
column23: To change future behavior

column9: How is Daniel Goleman relevant to the study of emotional intelligence?
column11: He helped bring the concept of emotional intelligence into the mainstream.
column12: Eddie is an innovative industrial engineer. Impressed by his intelligent approach to problem solving skills Eddie's boss is considering to promote him to shift supervisor. However, even though Eddie is good at his job his boss worries that Eddie may lack the emotional intelligence to manager other employees, i.e. being intuitive as to what other coworkers may feel and need. Based on Eddie's boss' evaluation, what domain of emotional intelligence may Eddie lack which could prove problematic in managing others?
column14: Empathy
column15: Alyssa is a student in the second grade. Her teacher has noticed that while other students in class respond well to external rewards like stickers, extra recess time, or praise from the teacher, Alyssa is intrinsically motivated. Doing well is her reward. Alyssa demonstrates strength in which domain of emotional intelligence?
column17: Self-motivation
column18: Which of the following is the BEST explanation of emotional intelligence?
column20: It is the ability to understand and manage emotions for one's self and others.
column21: Diane has noticed that when someone puts her off, it ruins her whole day. She just can't shake it off, which really puts a damper on her production at work. She worries her boss will get mad, yet she just can't seem to focus on anything else. Diane is emotionally stuck. Which domain of emotional intelligence is troublesome for Diane?
column23: Managing emotions

column9: What type of contract has an implicit agreement between an individual and an organization that details exactly what is expected in the relationship?
column11: Psychological
column12: Joan has been a store manager for six years. She loves her job and is not interested in a job as regional manager because she would have to move to another city. Which stage of the career model is Joan in?
column14: Maintenance
column15: Don is a 50-year-old repair technician for a computer hardware company. He notices that all of the recent promotions have gone to younger techs with more recent college degrees. What point in his career has Don MOST likely reached?
column17: Career Plateau
column18: Susie plans to cut back her work hours and begin passing her responsibilities on to younger associates in anticipation of retirement. Which stage of the career model is Susie in?
column20: Withdrawal
column21: What are the four career stages?
column23: Establishment, advancement, maintenance and withdrawal

column9: Which of the following is an employee benefit associated with career development and management programs?
column11: The programs can find a job for employees who were unfortunately part of a company- wide layoff.
column12: What group would benefit from a career management development system focused on task forces?
column14: Managers
column15: Jackie has a sense of loyalty to her company now that it is paying for her graduate tuition. This is an example of _____.
column17: an organizational benefit of career development and management programs.
column18: What is the purpose of a career management and development systems?
column20: To offer programs, counseling, planning and workshops to help employees manage their careers.
column21: Which of the following is not a benefit of career development and management systems for managers?
column23: It improves overall job commitment and productivity.

column9: Cindi is the newly appointed head of the accounting department. She is receiving training from a mentor and meets with her trainer every day to discuss how the day went and any unusual problems she is facing. Which of the following is NOT an advantage of using this training method?
column11: It hones in on employee interests
column12: Using hands-on training while working alongside an experienced worker is called _____.
column14: unstructured on-the-job training
column15: Why can job rotation be harmful to the productivity of a company?
column17: Because it can disrupt the workflow as the employee learns a new task or job
column18: Juan is a newly hired assembler at Speedy Cellular. He will spend his first week with Juanita, a veteran assembler, who will work side by side with Juan, showing him each step of the assembly process as he assembles the phones. Why is this an example of on-the-job training?
column20: Because Juan is learning his job by performing a specific task or job
column21: In which of the following cases would a company MOST benefit from a job rotation program?
column23: When absenteeism is slowing up the assembly line

column9: Which of the following provides the best explanation of employee assimilation?
column11: An employee becoming integrated into the company
column12: The following are advantages of a solid new hire orientation process EXCEPT _____.
column14: it completes the assimilation and socialization process
column15: Orientation for new employees includes the following components EXCEPT _____ to help with socialization and assimilation.
column17: providing an overview of the company's expectations regarding employee failure and resignation statistics
column18: A solid orientation program is important because _____.
column20: the chance of employee success is increased
column21: What's the best explanation of new hire orientation?
column23: Introducing a new employee to the organization and begin the socialization and assimilation process

column9: Which type of training would MOST likely result in employees becoming more willing to work together and trust their coworkers?
column11: Interpersonal Skills Training
column12: What are some of the possible benefits to training an employee in the use of new technology?
column14: Self-confidence and skills levels are improved
column15: Kathleen has a difficult time submitting project objectives and results to her supervisor in a clear and concise format. Her supervisor feels her reports are confusing. In order to improve Kathleen's skills in writing reports, her supervisor might recommend _____ training.
column17: Literacy
column18: Problem-solving training will teach employees to do all of the following, EXCEPT:
column20: Report results
column21: Diversity training focuses on the recognition of cultural differences and improves the ability of employees to _____.
column23: work effectively with people who are different

column9: Which of these is a step in the process of assessing training needs?
column11: Take an inventory of what is presently being done
column12: Which of these would be a quick action that would aid in keeping current clients?
column14: Send surveys to current clients
column15: What is the purpose for training needs assessments?
column17: They bridge the gap between what is happening now and what needs to happen in the future
column18: Which of the following should be reviewed when assessing training needs?
column20: Employee job descriptions
column21: A manager finds her employees are unfamiliar with the mission and vision of the organization. What type of training will solve the problem?
column23: Organizational culture training

column9: Carmen is a stay-at-home wife and wants to treat her parents to an expensive vacation for their 25th wedding anniversary. She gets a part-time job at a retail store and intends to quit once she earns enough money for her parents' trip. Carmen is an example of _____.
column11: a pre-planned quitter
column12: Diego works at a hardware store and has applied to an apprenticeship program with a local plumbers' union. He plans to quit his job if he is accepted into the apprentice program. Diego is a conditional quitter because:
column14: He will quit if a specific, predetermined event occurs
column15: Alicia's customer at the bridal shop was so difficult and rude that Alicia decided to quit on the spot. Why would this be considered impulsive quitting?
column17: Alicia made her decision in a quick and emotional moment
column18: Exit interviews are important to organizations because:
column20: They provide data on why employees leave and ways to retain them
column21: Ben sells cars and learns of another dealership with better commissions. He contacts the dealership and is offered a sales position. He accepts their offer and quits his current job. What type of quitter is Ben?
column23: Comparison

column9: Janice was just terminated. She was told her skills were not up to par for the company's needs. What type of termination did she undergo?
column11: Discharge
column12: Joe and a bunch of his buddies have just been terminated from employment because the company was able to reduce its labor requirements with new equipment. Why is this an example of a reduction-in-force?
column14: It is a permanent change caused by the acquisition of labor-saving technology.
column15: Thomas quit his job to work for another company, while Jane retired after working 40 years. How does Thomas' termination compare to Jane's termination?'
column17: Both of these are examples of voluntary termination.
column18: Tom was terminated due to a slowdown in demand for his company's products. His employer tells him he will be called back when product demand increases. Why is this scenario an example of a layoff?
column20: Because any involuntary termination is a layoff
column21: Which of the following factors increases the probability that an employee will quit?
column23: An employee with a desirable skill set gets an offer from a competing business.

column9: Identify the first step that is involved in terminating an employee.
column11: Documenting employee performance and behaviors
column12: Why is it important to include a compelling reason for terminating an employee?
column14: It eliminates confusion for the employee.
column15: What changes should you recommend be incorporated in a written statement of termination?
column17: Adding the termination dates
column18: Thomas works in a PR company. The company's manager is not satisfied with his performance and wants to fire him. Why would it be a good idea to try to find an alternative to firing him, such as finding him a new post in the company?
column20: It raises company morale.
column21: Which of the following is an example of a good question for an exit interview?
column23: Can you summarize in a few sentences whether or not you feel included in the company?

column9: To motivate employees to stay with the company, the HR manager recommends an across the board pay raise, which will get the company wages up to current market level. What type of tool is this?
column11: Extrinsic motivation
column12: Which of the following is the BEST explanation of 'absenteeism'?
column14: The pattern or habit of employees missing work, often for no good reason
column15: Beth is feeling burnt out at work. She needs a change, so she decides to quit her job and take classes to become a real estate agent, which she thinks will provide her with a more flexible schedule. Which of the following describes this example?
column17: Turnover
column18: Which of the following may affect intrinsic motivation?
column20: Participation in decision-making
column21: Which of the following is the BEST explanation of 'turnover'?
column23: Replacing employees who left employment, either voluntarily or involuntarily

column9: Bob is looking to hire someone from within the company for a vacant position. He comes up with this as a job posting: ZZT Engineering is looking to hire someone from within the company to fill the position of Senior Engineer. The Senior Engineer will oversee all the Junior Engineers and their projects. You can apply on the company website, on the opportunities page.Â What is missing from this job posting?
column11: Job qualifications
column12: Rita is an HR specialist that wants to notify company employees of a vacancy. What is the name of the notification process?
column14: Job posting
column15: What do you call the process of attracting and selecting the most qualified candidates for positions in an organization?
column17: Recruitment
column18: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of external recruitment?
column20: Fresh ideas and new perspectives
column21: What do you call the process of employees applying for vacancies in their current organization?
column23: Job bidding

column9: How do group interviews and panel interviews differ?
column11: A group interview involves at least two applicants while a panel interview involves at least two interviewers.
column12: Nina is interviewing for a position as manager of a new store location. The interviewer asks if she could talk about her past experience with new store situations. Nina is getting what type of interview?
column14: Behavioral
column15: What type of interview uses open-ended questions and free flowing conversation?
column17: An unstructured interview
column18: Helen in HR is interviewing five applicants today. She will ask each of them the same job related and situational questions and record the answers. What type of interview is Helen giving?
column20: Structured
column21: An interviewer has just given outstanding scores to an average applicant who followed several very poor applicants. What type of interviewing pitfall has the interviewer fallen into?
column23: Contrast effect

column9: An HR manager is trying to determine what qualifications the candidates have in order to best serve the company. It is clear that the CV of several candidates are excellent, and it is now the HR manager's job to decide which of them will be invited to participate in face-to-face interviews. The remaining candidates' information will be stored in a database for possible future opportunities with the company. Why is this an example of application review?
column11: The HR manager is determining which candidates have the qualifications needed for the job
column12: Which of the following will provide an employer with relevant information about the candidates, like personal hygiene, timeliness and manners?
column14: Conducting Interviews
column15: What is the proper course of action when an employer is performing background checks and discovers that a candidate has provided information in his employment application that is untrue?
column17: The employer has grounds to rescind the job offer
column18: Which of the following is the LAST step in the hiring process?
column20: Sending a candidate for a health check.
column21: Which of the following is NOT a step used by a human resources manager to determine the best possible fit for a job?
column23: Perform a detailed check of the candidates' regular contacts

column9: Which of the following is the difference between downsizing and turnover?
column11: Downsizing is planned while turnover can be unplanned and create gaps
column12: A successful architectural design firm is expanding its business and needs to hire three architects and five project managers in the next two months. The human resources department is already tied up with other critical staffing projects. Which of the following would BEST suit the firm's recruitment needs?
column14: Using an employment agency
column15: Although downsizing saves a company money in salary and benefits, which of the following can be a disadvantage of this practice?
column17: The remaining employees become overworked
column18: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of promoting internal candidates into new positions?
column20: The promotion creates a gap in staffing
column21: Felicia manages the training department. She notices that Adam, the training assistant, is bored performing the same, repetitive tasks and often has idle time throughout the day. Adam's low morale concerns Felicia since he is a good employee. Which of the following actions would BEST address this situation?
column23: Redesign Adam's job responsibilities and tasks

column9: Tom is an HR specialist. He is determining what tasks his company needs to perform in order to accomplish its goals. What is Tom doing?
column11: Job analysis
column12: What does performance standardization allow you to do?
column14: Appraise individual employee performance against the position's standards
column15: James is an HR specialist. He is determining what tasks need to be performed, how the tasks should be performed and how these tasks relate to other tasks in his company. What is James doing?
column17: Job design
column18: Jack and Diane are two mail clerks for a large corporation. They have the same job responsibilities and are judged by the same performance standards. This is an example of:
column20: Standardization
column21: Why is performance standardization important?
column23: It allows a company to appraise employee performance against the position's standard and against employees in similar positions.

column9: Mary is an HR specialist who needs to consider the importance of each job to the organization when she determines compensation for the jobs. Which type of job evaluation method is Mary using?
column11: Job ranking
column12: Henry is an HR specialist who has divided all of the jobs in the company into six broad classes, some of which have grades within each class. Which job evaluation method is Henry using?
column14: Classification
column15: Janice is a HR specialist engaged in job evaluation applying the same five general factors to each job. Which job evaluation method is Janice using?
column17: Factor comparison
column18: James is an HR specialist that is evaluating jobs in different clusters by assigning values to each compensable factor for each job in the cluster. Which job evaluation method is James using?
column20: Point-factor rating
column21: What's the best description of job evaluation?
column23: Assessing the relative value of jobs in an organization

column9: Which of the following is the process used to determine the duties of a job and the qualifications required to perform it?
column11: Job analysis
column12: The minimum qualifications and traits that a person needs in order to perform the duties of a specific position are contained in a _____.
column14: job specification
column15: What is the difference between a job description and a position description?
column17: A job description describes tasks and activities, while a position description summarizes what an employee does.
column18: Tiffany is preparing a written statement that summarizes a set of activities, duties and responsibilities related to the achievement of an organization's goals. This statement is referred to as a _____.
column20: job description
column21: Audrey wants to compose a description of tasks, duties, and responsibilities that will be undertaken by one specific employee. Which document should she use?
column23: Position description

column9: Why might a company need to reengineer jobs for continuous improvement?
column11: In order to remain an industry leader.
column12: Dale was hired into a company's management associate program straight out of college. As part of the program, Dale will spend the first two years of his employment cycling through different divisions and functional areas of the company, in order to gain a better understanding of the company and how the different units work together. This is known as:
column14: Job rotation
column15: Which of the following is NOT a key method of reengineering?
column17: Micromanaging employees to ensure their workload is sufficient.
column18: Joseph is a massage therapist who works in a spa while studying sales and marketing at college. Joseph's manager at the spa is hoping to retain him after he earns his college degree and has asked him to use his new skills to assemble ideas for a promotional campaign that will increase the number of clients that visit the spa. Joseph is happy to have new job responsibilities that incorporate what he is learning at school. He has been given the authority to make the necessary decisions to follow the promotional campaign through to its completion. This is known as:
column20: Job enrichment
column21: Anthony is working in a sales position at his company and started out performing two activities for his job. Recently, Anthony has had three additional activities added to his role, so that he now performs five job activities that belong to the same hierarchy level in the organization. This is known as:
column23: Job enlargement

column9: Which job redesign strategy encourages respect for coworkers doing other jobs ?
column11: Job rotation
column12: How might job redesign benefit an employee?
column14: It will make a job more interesting.
column15: How does job enrichment differ from job enlargement?
column17: Job enrichment provides additional responsibility and authority; job enlargement just adds extra tasks
column18: Maria is a teller at a bank. She was recently given the task of helping customers with the paperwork for opening checking accounts. This is an example of _____.
column20: job enlargement
column21: How might job rotation benefit a company?
column23: It provides employees with a broader perspective on how the organization operates as a whole.

column9: Ed, an executive, believes he has a great group of employees. He would like to let the employees have more control over how they do their jobs. Which job enrichment method should Ed use?
column11: Job redesign
column12: What are the three ways to provide empowerment?
column14: Job redesign, quality work circles, and teams.
column15: Sally, a supervisor, has been getting lots of feedback lately from employees about the business. She would like to get these suggestions on an ongoing basis. Which job enrichment method should Sally use?
column17: Teamwork circles
column18: Which of these is the best strategy for improving motivation and retaining employees?
column20: Empowerment
column21: Mark, a manager, has seen many changes to the production methods in his department. He believes his employees may be unsure about their new tasks and require help. Which job empowerment method can Mark use to BEST address this issue?
column23: Teams

column9: To increase productivity, Mary has decided to design a job to match the traits of her most talented employees. This job design approach is known as _____.
column11: Job Characteristic Theory
column12: All of the following are characteristics of job design EXCEPT _____.
column14: Provides salary and benefit information
column15: Which of the following is a potential problem with the job enrichment approach?
column17: The employee can become overwhelmed with responsibilities
column18: John is concerned that the workers in his manufacturing plant will become bored with their jobs, due to performing the same task over and over. Which job design approach might John take to provide variety to workers?
column20: Job Rotation
column21: What are the four approaches to job design?
column23: Scientific Management, Job Enlargement/Job Rotation, Job Enrichment and the Job Characteristic Theory

column9: Mary allows her employees plenty of leeway in how they do their jobs and expects them to motivate themselves to be high achievers. She sets the standard by coming in early and working as hard as they do. The self fulfilling prophecies predict that her employees _____
column11: will motivate themselves and achieve the goals she sets.
column12: Joe thinks that his workers hate their job and only come to work to earn their paychecks. However, he is satisfied with their creativity and imagination when they work on projects. Is Joe a typical Theory X manager?
column14: No, because he believes in their creativity and imagination.
column15: Which of the following is credited with the development of the Theory X and Theory Y?
column17: Douglas McGregor
column18: Rebecca runs a research department with specific goals for new product ideas. She lets employees work on their own new product ideas every Friday with little supervision. Rebecca is practicing _____ management.
column20: Theory Y
column21: Mike is a Theory X manager. Which of these does he assume about his employees ?
column23: They would rather be told what to do instead of directing themselves

column9: Carley works for a company in the Human Resources department. She is concerned about the company's oversight of their employees' personal development and motivation. She is hoping to help the company grow in this area. Based on Carley's concerns, we can determine she is a supporter of the _____.
column11: Human Relations Movement
column12: The human relations movement _____.
column14: focuses on the person as an individual and analyzes what motivates and cultivates his or her achievement in a work setting
column15: Who is the father of the human relations movement?
column17: Elton Mayo
column18: Which sentence describes the Hawthorne Effect?
column20: Attention makes workers feel important and results in better output.
column21: What are the three key elements of the human relations movement?
column23: Teams, upward communication, and dynamic leadership

column9: Tom is one of the highest ranked managers at an information technology company. He is allowing a project to continue because it was his idea to launch that line of products, although he now sees that the company could lose a lot of money if it moves forward. Tom doesn't want to admit that he was wrong because he fears for his job. Which principle of management does this concern?
column11: Subordination of Individual Interests to the General Interest
column12: How does the view of Henri Fayol on management and productivity differ from that of Frederick Winslow Taylor?
column14: Taylor believed in a scientific approach while Fayol believed in an administrative approach focusing on management.
column15: A CEO of a small company has implemented a strategy where all employees do their work together, without doing specific assignments all the time. He hopes that it will decrease the level of paperwork necessary and improve employee relations. Which one of Fayol's principles did he violate?
column17: Division of Labor
column18: Which of the following is NOT one of Fayol's first seven Principles of Management?
column20: Discipline
column21: XYZ Corporation follows the administrative school of management; managers are taught that one of their important roles is
column23: coordinating.

column9: Which answer best describes the principle of order?
column11: The workplace facilities must be clean, tidy, and safe for employees.
column12: Why did Henri Fayol develop the 14 Principles of Management?
column14: To provide managers with the right tools to manage workers in an effective way.
column15: How could a manager at XYZ Corporation explain the scalar chain to her employees?
column17: By using the aid of an organization chart.
column18: Which of these would be an example of the owner of James Small Engine Repair implementing the principle of equity?
column20: Giving everyone a paid day off for meeting the year's profit target.
column21: Why would a manager at XYZ Corporation be concerned about the stability of her personnel?
column23: Turnover disrupts the work and interferes with specialization.

column9: How would an automobile assembly line use Taylor's four principles to increase productivity and efficiency?
column11: Use a precise, specific approach for completing tasks rather than general guidelines.
column12: Which of the following is NOT one of Taylor's four principles of scientific management?
column14: Managers should pay employees based on effort and level of productivity.
column15: Why was Frederick Taylor dissatisfied with systematic management processes?
column17: He felt systematic processes led to a great deal of inefficiency in work processes leading to low productivity.

column9: How does the lack of any conflict impact the work environment?

column12: Two coworkers are having a dispute about how to achieve the goal of their company, which is to introduce the most competitive product in the smart phones industry. In the heat of the argument, one of the workers calls the other a lazy good-for-nothing. Why is this an example of a people conflict?
column14: Because it was a personal insult not relevant to the task.
column15: Which of the following is a major source of people conflict in teams?
column17: Perceived inequality
column18: Thomas and Jane are working on a proposal for a new PR strategy for their company. Thomas believes that they should focus on TV ads, while Jane believes they should focus on the world of social media because most other forms of communication are outdated. Identify the kind of conflict in this situation and the reason behind it.
column20: It is a task conflict, because they are proposing alternative methods to achieving the same goal.
column21: How does a perceptual set of beliefs, values and attitudes influence the behavior of people?
column23: Each individual interprets factual situations in a different manner, which can lead to conflict.

column9: Which of the following is NOT a style used to resolve a conflict?

By his estimates, since the last time they hired a larger number of people, the profit of the company has decreased by 5%. He thinks that these new employees are the cause of the issues and he wishes to fix these problems. Why is this an example of the cognition and personalization stage?

During their joint collaboration on a new product line, they argued so much the firm sent them to the HR department. After going through the conflict process, Thomas quit the company and started a blog about the organization's dysfunction. This is an example of which type of outcome?
column23: It's an example of a dysfunctional outcome because the conflict lead to further negative results.

column9: Mark from the IT sector and Wayne from the accounting sector are supposed to develop a strategy that will accommodate the long-term needs of the company. Which one of the following options best explains why this situation resulted in competition?
column20: The objective of each party was to win at the other party's expense, regardless of the cost.

column17: Country B has an absolute advantage in both goods.

column21: Why might sending an American female executive into a satellite office in Saudi Arabia come with a unique set of challenges that are not present in the U.S.?
column23: Women there are looked at as inferior to men in responsibility and/or ability.

column9: When decisions flow from the top of the organization down, the organizational structure is considered _____.
column11: Traditional
column12: Connie's Computers is in the 'operate' phase of a project. How will this affect the project?
column14: It will lower expenses.
column15: How many phases are included in the Cisco NDCS lifecycle business model?
column18: When finding ways to gain a competitive advantage, what phase of the business lifecycle model are we in?
column20: Optimize
column21: What phase of the Cisco NDCS lifecycle business model focuses on reducing response times?
column23: Implement

column9: If a company transforms a working philosophy, it has undergone _____.
column11: an organizational change
column12: An organizational change can involve modifications in all of the following EXCEPT:
column14: Ownership
column15: By marketing new eco-friendly vehicles, which of the following areas of GM underwent organizational change?
column17: Branding
column18: Under GM's organizational change, how did the relationship between the employees and the company change?
column20: Employees became more involved in decision making.
column21: How much control did the U.S. government take from General Motors?

column9: A company is trying to force a change by letting their employees know they will be fired if the organizational change fails. They have also stated that the entire change must happen at once and have tried to communicate to the employees why the change was necessary. Did company management perform any of the right steps to overcome employee opposition to change?
column11: Company management tried to communicate the importance of the change to the employees.
column12: A large company is trying to implement an organizational change. The company is trying to switch from primarily door-to-door operations to internet sales. They feel the changing marketplace requires that they adapt and have invested over $10,000,000 into this transition. The company's labor unions have organized strikes and the workers are threatening to resign. Why did the change fail?
column14: Because the employees refuse to accept the change.
column15: Which of the following is NOT a reason why employees resist change?
column17: They fear the status quo.
column18: How does organizational change impact a company?
column20: It restructures the company in a way so that it is completely transformed.
column21: How do external factors differ to internal factors?
column23: Internal factors are things like company policies or procedures, while external factors are things over which the company has very little influence on.

column9: What might cause an employee to feel particularly distressed at finding out that his company is changing its main focus of business?
column11: A feeling that his internal commitment, or psychological contract, with the business, has been violated
column12: How might an employee react to a workplace change that will increase workload difficulty if that employee is not 100% sure he or she will be able to keep up with the new workload?
column14: The employee might be against the change based on fear of failure.
column15: Which of the behavior reactions, or 4Ds, concerns confusion created by the initiation of change?
column17: Disorientation
column18: A fast food restaurant chain decides to automate several of its front-end processes in order to save money by cutting down on the number of employees needed. How might this impact employees of the restaurant on a personal level?
column20: It could disrupt relationships between employees as well as employee-customer relationships by taking away the human element of interaction.
column21: Jim feels angry and disgusted with his company after a recent company-wide change. It doesn't seem like management thought about it before making the change, and now Jim just can't experience any positive feelings about his work. Jim appears to be going through _____ with the company.
column23: Disidentification

column9: Which of the following is a useful tactic after deciding on a change?
column11: Involve staff in every step of decision-making
column12: Amy works in a company that has had a very casual environment for years.
