Now she has to sign her name both electronically and on paper prior to submitting any work and she feels that this change is completely unnecessary. Identify which of the following factors motivates her resistance to change:
column14: Lack of understanding why an additional process was needed
column15: Which of the following does an organization have full control over?
column17: The way a production process of a particular product is conducted
column18: Approximately 70 workers are employed at an IT firm called Johnson Incorporated. All of these workers are used to checking in with their supervisors five minutes before starting to work. In case an employee has a good idea, he doesn't have to worry about channels but can go straight to the CEO. The environment is very casual here. Why are these things examples of organizational culture?
column20: Because they reflect basic shared norms, beliefs and values of Johnson Incorporated.
column21: An advisory board of a multinational company is trying to assess the main challenges that the company will have to overcome in the next five years. Amongst them, they have listed these: dismissing fears regarding globalization, trying to predict the fluctuations of the stock market, and keeping up with the technological requirements of the industry. What do all of these goals have in common?
column23: They are all examples of external changes.

column9: As CEO of his company, Mack seeks to use Kotter's 8-step change model to make a comprehensive organizational change to improve efficiency and boost the company's sagging profits. As part of the first step, he outlines a program he believes will revive the business in six to nine months. What aspect of the first step in the change model did he miss?
column11: He didn't foster a sense of urgency by helping employees realize that their jobs depend on their support of the changes
column12: Lauren held a staff appreciation luncheon to inform her employees that existing clients' feedback on phase one of the new skincare system and pricing structure was overwhelmingly positive. Why is this an example of the sixth step of the change model, generate short-term wins?
column14: The manager publicly recognized employees with evidence their efforts are paying off
column15: Which of the following does NOT occur during step seven of Kotter's 8-step change model, consolidate gains to produce more change?
column17: Creating a team tasked with kick starting the change
column18: Which of the following actions would a manager take to empower broad-based action?
column20: Immediately address any barriers to keep the change process moving
column21: Why would an organization use Kotter's eight-step change model?
column23: To implement transformational change in the organization

column9: During a major change initiative, management discovers that there is not enough understanding about the change itself and there is a lack of strong project management for the change. These types of obstacles would be dealt with in which of the following steps in Kotter's change model?
column11: Empowering broad-based action
column12: In which of the following steps of Kotter's change model does management take time to paint a picture of what the organization's future will look like after the change has taken place?
column14: Develop a vision and strategy
column15: Which of the following steps in Kotter's change model involves the change leader selecting and recruiting a team of individuals who will be capable of carrying out the change?
column17: Create the guiding coalition
column18: Which of the following steps in Kotter's change model involves inspiring the necessary teamwork, ideas, and eagerness to make sacrifices relating to the change?
column20: Establish a sense of urgency
column21: Which of the following steps in Kotter's change model involves monitoring the acceptance of change and how well the organizational culture is adapting to the change?
column23: Anchor changes in the organization's culture

column9: Which step did Lewin find to be especially important to ensure that people do not revert back to their old ways of thinking or doing prior to the implementation of the change?
column11: Refreezing
column12: During which stage of Lewin's model do employees learn the new behaviors, processes and ways of thinking?
column14: Changing
column15: During which stage of Lewin's model does reinforcing, stabilizing, and solidifying the new state after the change occur?
column17: Refreezing
column18: Which of the three stages make up Lewin's change model?
column20: Unfreezing, changing, refreezing
column21: Which stage of Lewin's model is used to create an awareness of how the status quo, or current level of acceptability, is hindering the organization in some way?
column23: Unfreezing

column9: All of the following are areas an organization can focus on to overcome barriers to change EXCEPT _____.
column11: Third-party vendors
column12: Annual sales at K-Put, Inc. were down 55%, which prompted the CEO to implement a major overhaul of the business. He sent out a memo to all employees, stating: 'There will be some big changes made across all departments. If you do not happily comply with the new directives, you will likely find yourself on the short list for termination.' This scenario is an example of _____.
column14: coercion
column15: A large global restaurant chain recently began selling fried rice. However, after managers in several international markets spoke up, the company's franchised restaurants in those areas added fried noodles to their menu instead. Which change strategy was MOST likely used to get the company to consider this menu option?
column17: Negotiation
column18: Which of the following is a LIKELY outcome if management receives too many employee ideas about change within the organization?
column20: The employees become aggressive and highly competitive
column21: The best time for an organization to implement a new plan is when _____.
column23: customer satisfaction is high

column9: Slim Down Soda Company created a top-level position for a corporate officer in charge of work-life balance initiatives. Which force of internal change does this address?
column11: Employee Expectation
column12: Package delivery methods are expected to change greatly in the upcoming years as drones develop. Which external change influence does this represent?
column14: Technology
column15: What term describes a change occurring due to deliberate decisions made in an organization?
column17: Planned Change
column18: XYZ Corporation reorganized the sales division to meet competition from other countries. What external force is influencing this change?
column20: Globalization
column21: Crazy Kids Clothing implemented new standards for fireproofing its' products. What caused this change?
column23: Ethical Behavior

column9: Based on the mission statement, which of the following is the most important goal for Starbucks?
column11: Making the communities they serve a better place
column12: Pat is a Starbucks Barista. She read a recent financial statement that was not made public. The statement revealed profits for the company. Can Pat share this information to advise her family and friends to purchase stock?
column14: Yes, Pat can advise her family on Starbucks stock purchases because she is a representative of and partner with the company.
column15: Starbucks' mission statement most closely resembles which of the following?
column17: A lifestyle
column18: Why does Starbucks avoid companies that restrict competition?
column20: It is focused on maintaining open markets.
column21: Which is NOT a way for Starbucks partners to report an unethical issue or act?
column23: Call the media

column9: Carla is taking 30 days off of work to organize a breast cancer awareness program in her community. This is an example of what type of work-life program:
column11: Leave of Absence/Vacation
column12: Work-life balance is:
column14: an organizational concept that empowers employees to split time and energy between work and other important areas of their life successfully.
column15: Businesses offer work-life balance programs in order to _____
column17: reduce turnover.
column18: XYZ Corp. will allow all office workers the chance to work from home on Fridays. This is a _____.
column20: Flexible work arrangement
column21: The owner of James' Small Engine Repair has decided to purchase gym memberships for all of his employees. This is an example of a _____ work-life program.
column23: fitness and healthy living

column9: What are the three types of organizational justice?
column11: Distributive, procedural, interactional
column12: Robert was disciplined at work and was told to appeal via an online document. When he looked online, the document was not there. This would be a problem for which form of justice?
column14: Procedural
column15: Clarence was laid-off. During the processes, it was made clear that Clarence was good at his job and that the decision was strictly a financial decision following a last-in, first-out pattern. Why would this type of assurance be important to Clarence?
column17: This offers positive interpersonal justice
column18: Which of the following would be used in informational justice procedures?
column20: A well documented report of an employee's transgression
column21: What justice is about employees' concerns of the fairness of outcomes they receive?
column23: Distributive

column9: How does a company become socially engaged?
column11: A company should go all in. Engage with the aspects of social responsibility, review them and determine how the company can support them.
column12: How can a company be considered socially responsible?
column14: By minimizing its carbon footprint
column15: Which of the following is NOT an example of social responsibility?
column17: Implementing a hiring freeze for a three-month period
column18: Why have many companies decided to adopt a socially responsible stance when they conduct their business?
column20: Because they care about the environment and want to make the world a better place
column21: Which of the following phrases BEST describes social responsibility?
column23: A company that works to benefit society during the course of its business dealings.

column9: What are the five types of ethical climates?
column11: Instrumental, caring, law and order, rules, and independence.
column12: Neris is the owner of a small business which has a caring ethical environment. Why might Neris want to change this environment?
column14: Her employees keep breaking rules to help their peers
column15: The Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX) is a law that enforces proper reporting and oversight for publicly traded companies. What type of ethical climate will this create?
column17: Law and Order
column18: Bob is a problem-solver. What type of ethical climate would be best for him?
column20: Independence
column21: What type of ethical environment is driven by self interest, resulting in the biggest issues with unethical behavior?
column23: Instrumental

column9: All of the following are examples of the way Enron and its senior executives violated the code of business ethics, EXCEPT?
column11: They bought and sold energy.
column12: A CEO of a large company is having some difficulties in dealing with his subordinates. They complain that he is not specific enough about the tasks he assigns them. He is having a problem addressing _____.
column14: Employee relations
column15: How are vendor relations and investor relations similar?
column17: They are unimportant to the company from a financial standpoint.
column18: Investors depend on which of the following governmental organizations to ensure the stock market stays in order.
column20: The Securities and Exchange Commission
column21: An employee of a large multinational firm makes a mistake with a client's account. Company policy dictates that he immediately contact the client and let them know what happened. However, he knows he can fix the mistake easily, without worrying the client. What would the ethical course of action be?
column23: Follow the rules of conduct set up by the company and tell the client what happened.

column9: Which of the following is TRUE of Nordstrom, Inc.?
column11: Nordstrom, Inc. doesn't have a detailed employee handbook.
column12: Nordstrom, Inc. focuses on which of the following to provide top-notch customer service?
column14: Employees
column15: What are a company's values, attitudes, relationships, and behaviors?
column17: Organizational culture
column18: How would we describe Nordstrom, Inc.'s organizational culture?
column20: Customer service
column21: Which of the following statements is TRUE of Nordstrom?
column23: Nordstrom believes in hiring nice people.

column9: During World War II, Unilever's corporate culture was one of _____?
column11: independence
column12: Why did Unilever implement a sustainability strategy?
column14: It implemented a sustainability strategy to minimize its environmental footprint and promote positive social efficacy and outreach.
column15: Why are Unilever's regional teams an integral part of a business?
column17: Needs vary depending on a country's culture and product usage.
column18: When a company becomes known for interacting or behaving in a certain way, we call this _____.
column20: corporate culture
column21: After World War II, Unilever's corporate culture was influenced most by which of the following?
column23: Globalization

column9: The foundation of workplace spirituality is:
column11: Inner life and meaning
column12: By adopting a highway, the Cosmos Hotel provided a way for the members of their organization to experience workplace spirituality in which area:
column14: Feeling like part of their community
column15: Ebenezer Inn and Cosmos Hotel were competing for the same employees. They offered the same wages, but the Cosmos Hotel supported positive employee relationships. More employees chose to work for the Cosmos Hotel. Why did this occur?
column17: The Cosmos Hotel promoted a sense of community amongst workers.
column18: Members of organizations seek workplace spirituality in what three areas?
column20: Connecting to other people, feeling like part of a community, and finding meaning and purpose in their work.
column21: Why is it important for a company to adhere to a culture of spirituality?
column23: To improve productivity and reduce turnover from their employees.

column9: KCK Manufacturing has developed a very strong company culture. Employees are aware that deadlines and quotas are most important to the company and that management will usually turn a blind eye if a few corners are cut to meet target time frames. What impact could this strong company culture have on employees?
column11: Employees may not act ethically because the culture does not discourage unethical behavior
column12: As CEO, you expect to create an ethical workplace in your start-up organization. Which of the following strategies is counterproductive to establishing an ethical culture?
column14: Provide ethical training only to upper management
column15: Which of the following are traits that would be MOST expected in a company culture that encourages ethical behavior?
column17: High risk tolerance, low aggressiveness and a concern with the methods used to achieve goals
column18: The ethical climate of an organization is determined by:
column20: The content and strength of the company's culture
column21: Workplace behavior is considered unethical if it _____.
column23: does not adhere to the standards set by the company culture

column9: How can the culture of an organization act as a barrier to an acquisition or merger with another organization?
column11: The culture of an organization acts as a barrier if the workforce of the organization is not diverse.
column12: What is the name of the process that occurs when the culture of an organization becomes so well-established that it is understood by people inside and outside the organization?
column14: Institutionalization
column15: Which of the following scenarios depicts a situation in which the culture of a company would be likely to become a barrier to change?
column17: An established telephone company with a strong company culture is confronted with the need to adopt new technologies and processes to stay up to date in the rapidly changing phone industry.
column18: Thomas is the CEO of a large sports equipment company that has been in the business for over thirty years. The employees of the company feel like they are all family and consider themselves fortunate to be part of the company's longstanding culture. Thomas is unsure of how well the company will fare as they work to keep up with sudden rapid changes in the sports equipment sector. What three things in this scenario point toward a barrier that Thomas might encounter as he guides the company toward change?
column20: The company is established. The culture is established. They are in an environment facing sudden changes.
column21: Which of the following is FALSE regarding a diverse workforce?
column23: A diverse workforce often leads to difficulties in company-wide decision making.

column9: What option would be available to a candidate who finds a conflict between their values and the core values of an organization during the selection process?
column11: Disqualify themselves as a candidate for the position.
column12: When does the socialization of a new employee begin?
column14: Before the new employee joins the organization.
column15: How does an employee proceed through the stages of the socialization process?
column17: Pre-arrival, encounter, metamorphosis
column18: Which of the following is NOT a method in which a new employee learns the culture of an organization?
column20: Metamorphosis
column21: How does the selection process help to maintain the culture of an organization?
column23: Ensuring there is a match of values for the organization and the job applicant.

column9: When hiring new people, organizations use a selection process to determine which two things?
column11: If the new employee is capable of doing the job and if he or she has values that match those of the organization.
column12: Buddy is very concerned with supporting the culture of his business, Brick Head's Pizza. He decides to hire a new manager, named Tank, for the pizza chain. Why did he MOST likely hire Tank?
column14: Buddy knew that Tank's values matched the values of Brick Head's Pizza.
column15: How is culture sustained in an organization?
column17: Founders reinforce core values to top management and hire like-minded people.
column18: What is the initial source of an organization's culture?
column20: The founder of the organization.
column21: The method that adapts new employees to the culture of an organization is known as:
column23: the socialization method.

column9: Tina's Tarts has a strong organizational culture that values attention to detail. How does the president of Tina's Tarts communicate the importance of meeting her high standards to members of her organization?
column11: She gives her employees a way to actively participate in meeting the high standards by providing them with a Stop the Line button.
column12: Which of the following statements are true about an employee who works in a weak cultural environment?
column14: The employee must rely on formal rules when making a decision in their workplace.
column15: Which of the following statements are false regarding strong vs. weak organizational cultures?
column17: Organizations with strong cultures spend more to produce their products than organizations with weak cultures.
column18: How does a weak culture affect the quality of a product?
column20: Since the employees do not know the company's core values, they do not know what quality to achieve.
column21: Which of the statements below is true?
column23: Organizations where most people are committed to the core value have a strong culture.

column9: Bob is a pie baker at Grandma's Apple Pies. He has been baking pies longer than anyone else in the organization. Which of the following statements is most likely true?
column11: Bob is a member of the pie baker subculture and the subculture that consists of the longest tenured employees.
column12: The sales force at Grandma's Apple Pies belongs to a subculture based on the shared experience of not working in the office every day and traveling to make sales calls. This is a subculture that formed due to which area of differentiation?
column14: Functional specialty
column15: Grandma's Apple Pies has recently hired a new Vice President of Finance. She has over 30 years of experience in the finance industry, but has only been at Grandma's Apple Pies for two weeks. Which subcultures is she likely to be a member of?
column17: The upper management subculture and the newly tenured employees subculture.
column18: The core values which provide boundaries for, and shape the behavior of, all members of an organization are known as the _____.
column20: subculture of an organization
column21: A group of people may feel that they belong to a subculture within an organization when they _____.
column23: share a common problem or experience that is unique to them

column9: A culture that is rule-oriented and bureaucratic in nature is likely to place a high value on which of the characteristics of organizational culture?
column11: Stability
column12: Which of the following statements is true regarding the seven characteristics of organizational culture?
column14: How members of an organization perceive the value placed on each of the characteristics determines the unique culture of the organization.
column15: Tammy is employed at a beverage company and is free to develop new flavors and concepts for sodas targeted towards teenagers. If one of her new drinks flops in a test market, she is not chastised for her efforts and is encouraged to go back to the drawing board to develop a new beverage. Her organization places a high value on _____.
column17: innovation
column18: Elaine is hired by a telemarketing company to sell burial plots over the phone. The culture of the organization places a high value on achievement orientation. How would Elaine's manager reinforce this with her?
column20: By telling Elaine that he expects her to sell four burial plots a day using any means necessary
column21: New employees to an organization are expected to learn the system of shared values, beliefs, and assumptions that govern how people behave, which is known collectively as _____.
column23: organizational culture

column9: Christopher's assistant, Max, recently started accompanying him on the safety trainings he gives to subsidiaries. Christopher has involved Max in gathering information for the trainings, and using the company resources to customize each one. Christopher is involved in which part of mentoring?
column11: Teaching
column12: Finding ways to be profitable while limiting negative outcomes is an important part of becoming a manager. When a mentor guides a protÃ©gÃ© on how to successfully do this, he or she is involved in which part of mentoring?
column14: Finding ways to manage risk
column15: Which of the following scenarios do you think would most highlight the mentoring techniques used at Build-A-Bear Workshop for a new advertisement for employees?
column17: An employee telling a friend about the very rewarding programs, great pay, and receptive managers at Build-A-Bear.
column18: A mentor is someone who _____ an employee to become a better _____.
column20: coaches, leader
column21: Build-A-Bear Workshop's founder, Maxine Clark, credits whom for her success?
column23: Her mentor

column9: Prior to advertising an open position, what process needs to occur to identify a list of duties and responsibilities for a particular job?
column11: Job task
column12: What is a contemporary solution for hiring an employee who is well qualified but lives far away from an organization?
column14: Telecommuting
column15: If job tasks need to be added or revised to meet current needs, how would an organization address this challenge?
column17: Task revisions
column18: Techno stress, job sharing, and alternative work patterns are all examples of what?
column20: Contemporary issues in job design
column21: If an employee needs to pick up their children from school every afternoon, what arrangement would assist both the employer and employee deal with productivity issues?
column23: An arrangement for flex hours

column9: Which job redesign strategy encourages respect for coworkers doing other jobs ?
column11: Job rotation
column12: How might job redesign benefit an employee?
column14: It will make a job more interesting.
column15: Maria is a teller at a bank. She was recently given the task of helping customers with the paperwork for opening checking accounts. This is an example of _____.
column17: job enlargement
column18: How might job rotation benefit a company?
column20: It provides employees with a broader perspective on how the organization operates as a whole.
column21: How does job enrichment differ from job enlargement?
column23: Job enrichment provides additional responsibility and authority; job enlargement just adds extra tasks

column9: According to the job characteristics model, which characteristic describes 'the amount the job requires an employee to finish the completion of a product or process from beginning to end'?
column11: Task identity
column12: Which of the following is NOT one of the five characteristics of the Hackman & Oldham job characteristics model?
column14: Training
column15: According to Hackman and Oldham, which job characteristic is concerned with the amount of impact the employee has on other people and their work?
column17: Task significance
column18: Which of the following psychological states is NOT a component of Hackman & Oldham's job characteristics model?
column20: Corrective analyzing
column21: Janet runs a clothing store, and she's noticed that her employees don't seem to have a deep sense of responsibility about their jobs. How can she change this situation?
column23: By offering more autonomy.

column9: What are the three ways to provide empowerment?
column11: Job redesign, quality work circles, and teams.
column12: Sally, a supervisor, has been getting lots of feedback lately from employees about the business. She would like to get these suggestions on an ongoing basis. Which job enrichment method should Sally use?
column14: Quality work circles
column15: Ed, an executive, believes he has a great group of employees. He would like to let the employees have more control over how they do their jobs. Which job enrichment method should Ed use?
column17: Job redesign
column18: Mark, a manager, has seen many changes to the production methods in his department. He believes his employees may be unsure about their new tasks and require help. Which job empowerment method can Mark use to BEST address this issue?
column20: Teams
column21: Which of these is the best strategy for improving motivation and retaining employees?
column23: Empowerment

column9: What is the value of interdisciplinary job design for organizations?
column11: It offers different job design alternatives for different disciplines.
column12: Which interdisciplinary approach to job design considers scientific management work simplification, so that jobs are based on tasks and repetitive movements?
column14: Mechanistic
column15: If a company is concerned about skill, task identity, employee autonomy and feedback, which of the following job design approaches should be adopted?
column17: Motivational
column18: Which interdisciplinary approach to job design is also known as the experimental psychology approach?
column20: Perceptual-Motor
column21: An organization needs to design jobs based on the physical work that employees will be doing, such as lifting and exertion on the shop floor. Which interdisciplinary approach would be the most appropriate for designing these types of jobs?
column23: Biological

column9: What are the four behavioral approaches to job design?
column11: Job enrichment, job characteristics, autonomous teams, and a modified work schedule.
column12: Joe believes his employees at the pizza shop would be more motivated if they handled orders from start to finish. They will prepare and bake the pizza themselves rather than doing specialized tasks. Which job design approach will Joe implement?
column14: Job enrichment
column15: Paula is the head of public relations, and has many single moms on her staff. She would like to give them the option to write their press releases from home rather than doing them in the office. Which job redesign approach should Paula implement?
column17: Modified work schedule
column18: Maria, a manager, would like to free up some of her supervisor's time by letting employees solve production problems by brainstorming in groups. Which job redesign approach should she implement?
column20: Autonomous teams
column21: Julio is a teller at the bank. He will be given the opportunity to work with new customers at the business development desk every Friday. Which job enrichment approach is Julio involved in?
column23: Job characteristics

column9: All of the following are characteristics of job design EXCEPT _____.
column11: Provides salary and benefit information
column12: Which of the following is a potential problem with the job enrichment approach?
column14: The employee can become overwhelmed with responsibilities
column15: What are the four approaches to job design?
column17: Scientific Management, Job Enlargement/Job Rotation, Job Enrichment and the Job Characteristic Theory
column18: John is concerned that the workers in his manufacturing plant will become bored with their jobs, due to performing the same task over and over. Which job design approach might John take to provide variety to workers?
column20: Job Rotation
column21: To increase productivity, Mary has decided to design a job to match the traits of her most talented employees. This job design approach is known as _____.
column23: Job Characteristic Theory

column9: Which book played a role in Knudstorp's ah-ha moment?
column11: Profit from the Core
column12: Based on the story of the Lego Group and the concepts learned in this lesson, what advice would you offer the CEO of a struggling tech firm that was initially focused on consumer electronics, but started falling apart after expanding their products?
column14: Bring consumer electronics back into focus. Put other products and services into independent units, and then turn your focus to your core: consumer electronics.
column15: How did Knudstorp manage the Lego Group after his meetings with Zook?
column17: He put all units except the core product on cruise control, letting them fail or thrive, and focused on the toy bricks.
column18: What type of strategic challenge was the Lego Group facing in the early 2000's?
column20: External environment
column21: What organizational structure change did the Lego Group make that ended up saving the company?
column23: They changed the CEO.

column9: What about the traditional Japanese business structure created an environment that led to massive product recalls in 2009 and 2010?
column11: The hierarchical business model promoted hiding of product defect knowledge by upper level executives.
column12: In contrast to a centralized organization structure, what did the shift to a global organizational structure enable Toyota to accomplish?
column14: Delegate more authority away from the top of the organization and create more openness in communication.
column15: How does the just-in-time production system benefit manufacturing organizations like Toyota?
column17: Raw materials arrive at the production facility as needed, limiting storage of excess components on-site.
column18: Following problems in the 2000's, Toyota reorganized into what type of organizational structure?
column20: Global organizational structure
column21: What year did Toyota restructure its organization?

column9: The organizational behavior theory that suggests there is inherent conflict in what the owners of a business want and how the employees of a business will naturally behave is known as the _____.
column11: principal-agent theory
column12: Which type of organizational structure does the following image represent?
column14: Divisional
column15: How is the matrix system beneficial to organizations?
column17: It combines the important benefits of the functional and divisional structures.
column18: Julia is a line manager in a large manufacturing organization. Most of the decision-making takes place at the upper levels of the company, and the lower-level employees simply carry out the orders. Which type of approach is the organization using?
column20: Centralized
column21: Why may costs be higher with informal design structures?
column23: Less supervision may not be enough to motivate employees to work as hard.

column9: An organization that is E-business enabled could be defined as a company that _____.
column11: works both manually and operates online
column12: Why is it NOT likely for an E-business enhanced company to provide live face-to-face consultations regarding its products?
column14: Such companies usually work via the Internet only.
column15: Which of the following BEST describes the role of the Internet for E-business enhanced companies?
column17: Lifeline
column18: How is the level of a company's involvement in E-business determined?
column20: By the type of products or services they provide
column21: All of the following activities are considered part of the e-business for Acme Products Ltd except
column23: Acme uses a new strategy to be more efficient in answering phone calls.

column9: What is the main point of focus for all members of an organization with a lean structure?
column11: The value stream
column12: Which of the following differences between lean organizations and traditional organizations is FALSE?
column14: Lean organizations are less efficient than traditional organizations.
column15: Which of the following is TRUE about a value stream?
column17: A value stream is the sequence of activities required to design, produce, and provide a good or service as seen from the customer's perspective.
column18: Which of the following statements about organizational structures is FALSE?
column20: An organization that uses a traditional structure encourages employees to interact with lots of individuals from outside of their departments.
column21: What comparison can be made about a traditional organization and a lean organization?
column23: Workers in a lean organization are more empowered to improve processes and eliminate waste.

column9: The Droopy Dog, a small motel, and Silver Spike, a huge resort, both increased the number of their employees in the last year by 30%. Which statement MOST likely describes how the change in size affected these organizations?
column11: The Silver Spike did not experience a large impact on its structure due to the increase.
column12: Choose the answer that best describes how the size of an organization affects the structure of the organization.
column14: A large organization with a tall structure will have many vertical levels.
column15: Which statement is true regarding formalization in large and small organizations?
column17: Small organizations have fewer members and fewer rules and regulations than large organizations.
column18: Which statement below is true regarding work specialization in large and small organizations?
column20: Large organizations tend to break jobs down into more tasks and assign each task to a separate employee.
column21: Choose the answer below that best characterizes departmentalization in large or small organizations.
column23: Small organizations use a low degree of departmentalization because there are fewer people to get the tasks done.

column9: Which term describes informal conversations between organizational members that are NOT officially sanctioned?
column11: Grapevine
column12: If a company had primarily a formal organization with very little informal organizational structure, how would this be bad?
column14: There would be low morale
column15: Which term is characterized by personal relationships, communities of shared interest, and social networks that arise as employees associate with one another in a workplace setting?
column17: Informal groups
column18: Which type of organizational structure is seen in the organizational chart or hierarchy?
column20: Formal organizational structure
column21: Which type of organizational structure is focused on the employees, their relationships, and the unofficial power inherent within those relationships?
column23: Informal organizational structure

column9: Rachel works for an organization that has become stagnant and is falling behind its competition since it is no longer incorporating customer feedback. This is a negative consequence of which of the following types of boundaries?
column11: External Boundary
column12: Why did Jack Welch want to restructure his multibillion dollar organization to operate similarly to a family grocery store?
column14: All answers are correct
column15: What type of boundary acts as a barrier between members of the same organization who are physically separated?
column17: Geographic Boundary
column18: Which of the following is a method to reduce or eliminate horizontal boundaries within an organization?
column20: Introducing a functional area rotation program
column21: Which type of boundary impedes communication and interaction between organizational members who operate at different levels within an organization?
column23: Vertical Boundary

column9: Why is the team organizational structure utilized?
column11: To break down functional barriers among departments to strengthen working relationships and improve efficiency.
column12: Which type of organizational design structure keeps the core functions of the business internal while outsourcing non-core functions to third parties?
column14: Network
column15: What does the organizational matrix structure focus on?
column17: The use of cross-functional teams.
column18: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of a network organizational design structure?
column20: Increased employee retention
column21: Robert works in a large informational technology company that uses a matrix structure. Joanna is his manager in the programming department. Tristan leads the project that Robert is currently working on. Robert reports to which of these individuals?
column23: Both Joanna and Tristan.

column9: Sales and marketing, finance and accounting, customer service, and human resources are a few examples of groupings within which organizational design type?
column11: Functional
column12: How does having a top-level executive impact divisional structures?
column14: It makes them more successful by ensuring that someone who has authority is available at all times.
column15: All of the following are traits of the simple organizational design structure, EXCEPT:
column17: High departmentalization
column18: Why is a divisional design structure used?
column20: To create several semi-autonomous units that focus on a narrow sector of business.
column21: Why are functional structures used by an organization?
column23: To have specialized work units that maximize functionality.

column9: Why is having a suitable organizational structure important for the company?
column11: It will allow the company to implement proper operating procedures and decision-making processes.
column12: A state university has a system where most of the decisions are made by the top level of management and the subordinates are not supposed to question them. There are no complex decision-making processes that involve multiple parties and most of the communication goes from the bottom toward the top. Why is this NOT a common mechanistic structure?
column14: Because most of the communication goes from the bottom toward the top
column15: Why is it impossible to institute standardized processes and procedures in an organic structure?
column17: Because of the uncertainty of organic organizations
column18: Which of the following is a characteristic of a mechanistic structure?
column20: Individualized job specialization
column21: Why is the mechanistic structure often referred to as a bureaucratic structure?
column23: Because the organization has a formal network

column9: How does organizational strategy affect organizational structure?
column11: An organizational strategy is crucial to developing and implementing a viable organizational structure
column12: Why does an organic structure work best for an innovation strategy?
column14: This combination encourages input and decision-making by all members of the organization
column15: How does a mechanistic structure differ from an organic structure?
column17: The organic structure is usually far less formal and departmentalized
column18: An IT company focuses on copying and mass-producing computer hardware that is similar to successful devices developed by companies that follow an innovation strategy. Which of the following structures would best suit the IT company's strategy?
column20: Both the mechanistic and organic structure
column21: A small business sells computers directly to customers. It does not incorporate excessive innovation and spends little on advertising. The environment at the company is very informal and could best be described as organic. Why is this NOT a common cost minimization strategy?
column23: There usually is a strong hierarchy in a cost minimization strategy

column9: How might new organizational design strategies negatively affect an organization's culture?
column11: Employees who are content with the status quo may resist innovation that may affect the company's competitive edge.
column12: Patricia works for a company that manufactures DVD players. The company is experiencing a decrease in profits since most consumers who were interested in purchasing a DVD player have already done so. Patricia's company is in which of the following stages of the organizational life cycle?
column14: Decline and death
column15: Don works for a major healthcare system in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Recently a patient was admitted for treatment who was diagnosed with the Ebola virus after returning from a trip to West Africa. Don's hospital is now in the process of training all of its staff on the proper procedures for donning personal protective equipment and notifying the proper government agencies when treating these types of patients. This is an example of a change to organizational design due to _____.
column17: strategy
column18: How is decision-making impacted when individuals work for a large organization?
column20: They have less input in decision-making.
column21: Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between organizational structure and organizational design?
column23: Organizational structure is the formal lines of authority and power, while organizational design is a formal process of integrating information, technology, and people to achieve objectives.

column9: What are two elements of organizational design?
column11: Plan and process
column12: The Sarbanes-Oxley Act requires the chief executive officer and the chief financial officer be responsible for the reporting of financial statements. How would this affect the organizational design of a company?
column14: These external regulations create a hierarchy of authority
column15: Referring to organizational design, the acronym PARC stands for:
column17: People, architecture, routine, and culture
column18: What type of organizational design has minimal job specialization, few layers of management, decentralized decision-making and not much direct supervision?
column20: An organic organization
column21: How do heterarchy and responsible autonomy differ from other organizational designs?
column23: The designs do not have strict hierarchies of authority.

column9: Which of the following is NOT an example where negotiations are likely to achieve the best result?
column11: When there are really no conflicts between the parties.
column12: Two companies, Thomson Incorporated and Johnson International, are having a dispute about a joint venture they started. Thomson Incorporated is claiming that Johnson International is not providing the logistical support it promised. The companies have agreed that negotiations will last up to one week and that, if the conflict is not resolved by then, they will abandon their attempt at a joint venture. Which step of negotiation are the companies currently in?
column14: Definition of ground rules.
column15: A consulting firm and a bank are trying to resolve issues regarding a possible breach of contract obligations. They are in the negotiation phase and have agreed that the consulting firm will withdraw its lawsuit against the bank in return for a 3-year contract, where they will receive roughly $100,000 each year. The initial offer of the bank was $75,000, but after a lengthy discussion they decided to increase it. Why is this an example of the bargaining and problem solving phase?
column17: Because there were compromises made in order to achieve a satisfactory result.
column18: Which of the following is NOT a step in the negotiation process?
column20: Conclusion and evaluation.
column21: Two companies, one worth $10 million and the other worth $20 million, have started exporting products together to the European market. The company that is worth $10 million stated that the minimum price for which it would work for the larger company was $1 million. The expected profit from this joint export is $3 million. What is the bottom line in this scenario?
column23: $1 million

column9: Jane and Thomas are disputing over methods for advancing their company's image. Thomas wants to use online social media, whereas Jane believes most of their customers are older and should be contacted by mail. A person from outside the company is brought to weigh in on both sides of the argument and move them towards a more constructive dialog. The mediator maintains an impartial stance and keeps extensive notes that she presents to Jane and Thomas to resolve their conflict. Which of these in this scenario is NOT common for mediators?
column11: The mediator keeping written records.
column12: How does the role of the facilitator differ from that of the mediator?
column14: The mediator needs to use a hands-on approach, while the facilitator is less involved.
column15: Why is it sometimes necessary to bring in a third party to resolve a conflict?
column17: Because the parties involved cannot reach an agreement themselves.
column18: Which of these individuals would focus on understanding the reasons behind a conflict in order to plan a resolution strategy?
column20: A consultant
column21: Why is arbitration considered the most aggressive third-party intervention?
column23: Because the decision is binding and cannot be changed.

column9: Mark from the IT sector and Wayne from the accounting sector are supposed to develop a strategy that will accommodate the long-term needs of the company. Mark thinks they need to buy the best computers on the market, while Wayne wants them to pick the cheapest. After an open disagreement, Mark has taken a 2-week leave in order to not have to disagree about the issue again. Which of the following best describes this conflict resolution style?
column11: Avoidance
column12: Which of the following is a profile of a person likely to use accommodation as a conflict management style?
column14: A person with a high need for approval
column15: Which of these conflict management styles attempts to resolve a conflict by finding a middle ground?
column17: Compromise
column18: Which of the following is the feeling that is most crucial after collaboration?
column20: That both parties are satisfied without feeling a sense of sacrifice
column21: Jonathan and Sam are employed at a PR company in Boston. Both of them want the company to fund projects they've been working on for the past three years, but senior management has informed them that the company will only fund one of the projects. Which one of the following options best explains why this situation resulted in competition?
column23: The objective of each party was to win at the other party's expense, regardless of the cost.

column9: Which of these behaviors is a characteristic of functional conflict?
column11: Constructive criticism.
column12: Which of the following is NOT a positive result of functional conflict?
column14: Emotional bonding
column15: Why do most dysfunctional conflicts come about?
column17: Emotional or behavioral issues
column18: In which of these scenarios is mediation most likely to be successful?
column20: Both parties are committed to finding a solution which benefits everyone.
column21: Why is mediation useful?
column23: It help the parties communicate their issues to one another.

column9: Why can task conflicts be beneficial for the organization?
column11: They can cause a good discussion and create streamlined productivity.
column12: Tom works in middle management and is often rude and overly critical of his workers. He has recently had a strong disagreement with a few employees because he had to limit their project budgets due to the company cutting production costs. He has also had arguments because he called workers fat underachievers. He usually uses personal insults when he feels that his authority is threatened. How would you categorize these conflicts?
column14: The budget cutbacks represent a task conflict; everything else is a relationship conflict.
column15: Tom from marketing and John from accounting are working on the launch strategy of a new product line. Tom is strongly advocating spending a lot of money on TV advertisement, while John wants to curb the spending as much as possible. Why is this an example of a task conflict?
column17: They are disagreeing on details regarding achieving the company's goals.
column18: Which of the following is NOT an example of a process conflict?
column20: Two workers argue about their relative salaries.
column21: What is a disagreement between groups or employees regarding work-related issues?
column23: Organizational Conflict

column9: What type of perspective believes that conflict is dysfunctional unless everyone involved positively benefits when the conflict is resolved?
column11: Interactionalist
column12: What is another name for the managed conflict perspective?
column14: Human Relations
column15: A manager with an open door policy for employees to share problems they see within the organization is an example of which conflict perspective?
column17: Managed
column18: The three workplace conflict perspectives are:
column20: Traditional, Managed, and Interactionalist
column21: A manager who is quick to resolve problems on their own, ignoring employee input for change, is operating under which conflict perspective?
column23: Traditional

column9: How can group polarization be prevented?
column11: Use a neutral facilitator to navigate all of the different views.
column12: Why does group polarization occur?
column14: It occurs due to the idea of social comparison and the persuasive arguments view.
column15: How did Social Comparison drive Messy Chocolates to make the wrong decision with the Cricket Chocolate Bar?
column17: Individuals tend to move to an extreme position and enjoy the attention in hopes to be categorized as a leader in thought.
column18: What is group polarization?
column20: the idea that groups make decisions that are more extreme than the original thoughts and views of the individual team members
column21: A sales group is discussing ideas for a new potato chip. Two ideas are presented, a chip that is tube shaped and a square chip. As the group continues to discuss the pros and cons of the two shapes, one group member blurts out, 'Why don't we just make squid flavored chips.' This gives the group a new direction in which to think and they eventually decide to go with the idea of a squid flavored potato chip. What explains the group's decision to make this not-so-appetizing flavor of potato chip?
column23: the persuasive arguments view of group polarization

column9: It is essential that a team be able to uncover the _____ of a problem before identifying any possible solutions.
column11: root cause
column12: Which of the following elements is NOT part of the resolution step in the problem solving process?
column14: Revising the process
column15: Linda is a production manager at a warehouse where robots assist on the assembly line. She is informed that some customers are receiving their orders late. Linda arranges a meeting with her staff to get to the bottom of the problem. She encourages her team to think outside of the box to figure out a possible solution, and assures them that no idea will be criticized. This is an example of _____.
column17: brainstorming
column18: What should a team do once a solution is in place?
column20: Monitor the solution for a specific time period
column21: Why is it important for team members to define and understand the problem?
column23: To ensure agreement on the solution that is chosen.

column9: Brett is a member of a high-performing team facing a deadline for passing an audit. The team still has to review existing procedures, draft new procedures, and revise any outdated procedures. In addition, the materials need to be arranged in a manual. How can they get all of this work accomplished in just a few days? The team members should _____.
column11: split up the duties to ensure there is no double work
column12: Lily offended George. He felt she took an idea he told to her in confidence and implemented it as part of their project. This made George feel he did not receive the credit he had coming to him. How do George and Lily handle this conflict as members of a high-performing team?
column14: George and Lily continue to work professionally while resolving the issue.
column15: Which one of the following individuals would be the BEST addition to a high-performing team?
column17: An individual who can take direction and has a great attitude.
column18: Which one of the following phrases MOST accurately describes a high-performing team?
column20: A group of individuals who share a common goal and challenge each other to accomplish great results
column21: Which of the following is a characteristic of high-performing teams? Team members _____.
column23: trust that other teammates are doing their best

column9: What is a preventative measure that can be taken to reduce the chances of groupthink?
column11: All the answers are correct.
column12: The king of a small country wants to go to war. Everyone agrees with him in an attempt to gain his favor, even though they would be attacking a much larger nation. This an example of:
column14: groupthink
column15: Which of the following describes the likely outcome of decisions shaped by groupthink?
column17: They have a low probability of success
column18: Groupthink occurs:
column20: When a group makes faulty or ineffective decisions for the sake of reaching a consensus.
column21: Groups that experience groupthink disregard _____ in order to maintain harmony in the group.
column23: alternatives

column9: When an individual has a position of power over others, but it is not part of the hierarchical structure of the organization, it is called:
column11: Informal power
column12: This type of power is bestowed upon an individual due to their position within the organization.
column14: Formal power
column15: This is a culture defined by a culture where issues are fully detailed and spelled out.
column17: Low Context
column18: The principles that govern a person's or group's behavior are called:
column20: Ethics
column21: This is a type of culture that makes a lot of assumptions about the commonality of the communications, views and knowledge.
column23: High Context

column9: The marketing manager at Speedy Cellular has just sent her analysts a third survey about advertising ideas for a new cellphone. Which group decision technique is she applying?
column11: Business Questioning
column12: A company seeking ideas for new products wants to generate as many ideas as possible from a group. Which group decision technique will they MOST likely use?
column14: Brainstorming
column15: The top executives at XYZ Corporation are deciding how much to offer the owners of a smaller company to buy them out. Each executive writes down an amount on a piece of paper, and, after a brief discussion, they make the final decision by secret ballot. Which group decision making technique are they applying?
column17: Nominal
column18: The analysts at Magic Marketing are meeting to discuss ideas for a new campaign for an important client. The facilitator leading the discussion advises the analysts not to criticize any new ideas at this point. Which group decision-making technique are they applying?
column20: Brainstorming
column21: What are the three types of group decision making?
column23: Nominal, Delphi, and Brainstorming

column9: A _____ represents one person getting feedback from the group but making a decision on his or her own.
column11: consultation
column12: The following is TRUE in regards to group or individual decision making.
column14: All are correct.
column15: A cohesive, agreeable decision made by more than one person is called a:
column17: Consensus
column18: If the decision is going to be made to raise the price of a product, a group consensus of _____ may be beneficial.
column20: All are correct.
column21: When to use group or individual decision making really comes down to these factors:
column23: Power, Complexity, Structure

column9: How does the lack of any conflict impact the work environment?
column11: It may expose conformity and lack of diversity.
column12: How does a perceptual set of beliefs, values and attitudes influence the behavior of people?
column14: Each individual interprets factual situations in a different manner, which can lead to conflict.
column15: Thomas and Jane are working on a proposal for a new PR strategy for their company. Thomas believes that they should focus on TV ads, while Jane believes they should focus on the world of social media because most other forms of communication are outdated. Identify the kind of conflict in this situation and the reason behind it.
column17: It is a task conflict, because they are proposing alternative methods to achieving the same goal.
column18: Which of the following is a major source of people conflict in teams?
column20: Perceived inequality
column21: Two coworkers are having a dispute about how to achieve the goal of their company, which is to introduce the most competitive product in the smart phones industry. In the heat of the argument, one of the workers calls the other a lazy good-for-nothing. Why is this an example of a people conflict?
column23: Because such situations often happen in the IT industry.

column9: What does the T stand for in the S.M.A.R.T. goal checklist?
column11: Time
column12: Which of the following is an example of a S.M.A.R.T. goal?
column14: The travel finance office will process 100% of all travel vouchers within 15 days of receipt.
column15: What is the ultimate end of team goal making?
column17: Accomplish the company's mission statement
column18: A company sets a production goal of 150 units each shift. The team has determined that they can currently only achieve production of 100 units per shift. Which of the following suggestions might be an effective solution to realign the goals of the team and the company?
column20: The team might be able to suggest purchasing an updated tool that will decrease production time.
column21: Which of the following is true of team and company goal alignment?
column23: Team goals must support company goals.

column9: During which of these steps will a project leader check with human resources and department managers to assess potential team members?
column11: Recruit team members.
column12: During which of these steps will a project leader make a list of characteristics that someone would need in order to accomplish project goals?
column14: Determine attributes.
column15: What is one of the most effective ways of selecting team members for a project?
column17: By assessing their strengths and aligning them with project goals
column18: Which of these would NOT be considered a benefit of aligning individual strengths with project goals?
column20: Project leaders get to delegate leadership responsibilities.
column21: During which of these steps will a project leader determine how many team members he or she will need to complete project tasks?
column23: Break down project goals into tasks.

column9: Why is it important to set measurable goals?
column11: To have clear answers on whether or not you managed to achieve them.
column12: Which of the following is NOT part of the SMART goals?
column14: Tactical
column15: Which of these does NOT describe a way to involve a team member in the goal-setting process?
column17: Take a survey to determine what the team member's personality is so that you can create effective project teams.
column18: Why is it important to include team members in the goal-setting process?
column20: To earn team member buy-in
column21: What does the S stand for in SMART goals?
column23: Specific

column9: A team of people is organized such that each member has a different expertise. Why will this group function as a work team?
column11: They have a common mission.
column12: Ciera was supposed to collect all of the monthly reports for the year. In doing so, she used the calendar year instead of the fiscal year. Ciera blamed her secretary. In this case, what was she lacking?
column14: Accountability
column15: When managing a work team, what things do we need to look for to improve our chances of success?
column17: Planning, accountability, and conflict resolution
column18: Three members of a division came together to determine what jobs would be offered telecommuting one day a week. How would we describe these members?
column20: Work team
column21: Team JAC was put together to redesign the company's common areas. In the process, Andy started looking for another job and often skipped meetings. Team JAC lacked what key parts of an effective work team?
column23: Commitment and trust

column9: Which of the following is the BEST example of a clear performance goal?
column11: Increase sales by 30 percent in the next quarter
column12: The understanding of what a team is trying to accomplish, or what it is working towards, is called the _____.
column14: meaningful common purpose
column15: Why is diversity important in a team?
column17: More perspectives and varying viewpoints are represented
column18: The sharing and understanding of data and information as sender and receiver is _____.
column20: Communication
column21: Which is more important in team effectiveness?
column23: Clear performance goals for the team to work towards.

column9: WhWhich of the following is NOT a type of work team common in contemporary organizations?
column11: Culturally-diverse team
column12: Vivian works in housekeeping at a resort hotel. She manages the laundry division and has three dozen valets and laundry attendants reporting directly to her, in addition to six contracted tailors and furniture upholsterers. Why is this a functional work team?
column14: The team members all perform tasks specific to the function of the department
column15: How do functional teams differ from self-directed teams?
column17: Members of self-directed teams have significantly more authority than those in functional teams
column18: Why do organizations use work teams?
column20: Work teams offer the benefit of combined experiences, ideas and opinions
column21: Howard is vice president of media relations. Keisha is a senior web developer in marketing. Both are part of a team of high-level employees from various departments that will determine how best to present the company's new line of products to the public. Although each team member has authority over company policy, there is no designated group leader. Why is this a cross-functional team?
column23: Each member lends expertise in their particular field and is empowered to make decisions for the company

column9: A team of employees in the time and attendance group were charged with creating a training presentation for new hires to learn how to enter their vacation and sick time into the company's time tracking system. When the weekly meetings were held, one of the employees consistently showed up late and never had any suggestions or input for the presentation. This is an example of _____.
column11: Social Loafing
column12: In regard to group dynamics, what would you expect to see in a small group made up of only five people?
column14: Group dynamics being easily visible
column15: Richard was working with a group that was tasked with recommending a new project management software. Three vendors gave presentations on different software packages. The majority of the group members were certain that one of the software packages was the best and should be purchased. Although Richard felt differently and wanted to recommend a different product, he simply went along with the others due to group pressure. This is an example of _____.
column17: Groupthink
column18: When members of a group try harder because they know that the group is watching them, this is known as _____.
column20: Social facilitation
column21: What is the difference between the dynamics of Synergy and Groupthink?
column23: Synergy is where the group's results are greater than the sum of its parts, and Groupthink is where the group begins to make poor decisions due to overall group pressure.

column9: How would you expect five closely knit coworkers to work as a team versus five representatives from different areas, none of whom have met before? Why?
column11: The closely knit coworkers will be more effective, because of their shared history of social interaction.
column12: How many characteristics of group behavior influences are there in an organization?
column14: Many more than five.
column15: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic that influences group behavior at work?
column17: Individual salaries
column18: _____ is when all members of a group are focused on accomplishing the same outcome.
column20: Commonality of purpose
column21: Which characteristic of group influence has to do with how individuals see their own roles and jobs within the group?
column23: Perception of a group

column9: Which roles are critical to the cohesive nature and direction of the group?
column11: Maintenance roles
column12: Why is the perception of events so important?
column14: Because the way a person perceives a situation leads to their thoughts on the reality of the situation.
column15: How do expectations and perception impact the possibility of conflict?
column17: They can impact the possibility of conflict because opinions are to some degree shaped by expectations and perception.
column18: Tom works for an IT company and is considered by most of his coworkers to be friendly, laid back and willing to help whenever possible. When there is a tight situation, or the group cannot make a decision, he always tries to remove barriers to the problem, although he hates to embrace challenges. Why is Tom's role NOT that of a shaper?
column20: Because he hates to embrace challenges.
column21: Jane works as a manager in a media outlet and is known for her capacity to get jobs done and turn discussion into real deliverables. Which best describes Jane's role?
column23: An implementer

column9: A company created a new group to start work on a specific project, but there are not enough workers to do all of the required tasks. How will the group MOST likely be expected to handle this amount of bandwidth?
column11: Workers will be expected to cover more ground and increase their abilities.
column12: Which of the following is FALSE regarding mechanical aptitude?
column14: It's an intangible skill.
column15: _____ can be defined as the accumulated information and skills a person develops through expertise and education.
column17: Knowledge
column18: The CEO of a large company is trying to coordinate the launch of a new product. Most of his workers describe him as a positive leader who provides clear instructions and feedback about their job performance. Why is this CEO a good communicator?
column20: Because he provides his employees with clear and concise instructions.
column21: A team manager is having difficulties with his team because the individual he chose as his deputy is described by coworkers as difficult to work with and needlessly melodramatic. What form of knowledge will help the manager resolve this situation?
column23: Social knowledge

column9: A Provost at a University is giving a presentation and asks to have the Dean of the Business School (Gregg) and the Department Chair of the Management Department (Daniel) with him during the presentation. Gregg and Daniel make up a _____ group.
column11: command
column12: At Janet's workplace a group of employees who are interested in learning more about public speaking have decided to meet in an effort to form a local chapter that will help them to improve their skills in that area. This is an example of a/an _____.
column14: informal group
column15: Mark is new to his workplace. After talking with a group of guys that he sits with at lunch everyday, he realizes that they all share a love of softball. He decided to organize a softball team that will play in a community league on the weekends. This is an example of which of the following types of groups?
column17: Friendship
column18: Which of the following would NOT be a reason for employees to form an interest group?
column20: To serve meals together at a soup kitchen
column21: What is the main difference between task and command groups?
column23: A task group has multiple tasks to accomplish, and a command group has one specific task to accomplish.

column9: How did Dell's approach to communication with analysts differ from their approach to communication with customers?
column11: With analysts, they focused on changes in sales, while with customers they focused on new products.
column12: Which of the following is NOT part of the strategic management process model?
column14: Return on communication
column15: What does the strategic management process call customers, employees, investors, and managers?
column17: Constituents
column18: In which process are various kinds of information passed along to members of an organization, with feedback being returned?
column20: Strategic communication
column21: Why is strategic communication useful?
column23: It adds value to the product/service of the company.

column9: What issue did FedEx have to deal with when they were communicating with employees, customers, and other stakeholders in 2001?
column11: An explanation as to why they had to layoff nearly 13,000 employees
column12: FedEx would be acknowledging which employee value by writing We understand how hard this layoff may be for you and your family?
column14: Empathy
column15: How did FedEx make the bad news of a layoff more tolerable for its laid off employees?
column17: Offered early retirement or voluntary severance
column18: What is FedEx's communication strategy called?
column20: Integrated communication function
column21: Who did FedEx turn to for help with sending their message of appreciation to the laid off employees?
column23: Customers

column9: Mike, Operations Manager for Solar Solutions, has had communication difficulties about the daily production of steel in his meetings with James, one of the shift supervisors. Assuming this is an issue of hierarchy, the barrier they face is related to _____.
column11: Status differences
column12: A U.S. marketing manager is irritated that his counterpart in Japan limited eye contact during a recent visit to his facility. Eye contact is a sign of attentiveness to one but represents inappropriate behavior to the other. What type of barrier is this?
column14: Cultural
column15: Which of the following best describes what barriers do to communication?
column17: Hinder employee relations but have no bearing on company sales.
column18: Ellen in the Los Angeles, California office is frustrated over a teleconference meeting she had with Donald and James from the London, England office. Because this meeting necessitated the use of Skype, Ellen tried to push aside her preference for a face-to-face discussion and focus on the task at hand, but the meeting was cut short when the Skype connection was lost, adding to Ellen's frustration. Ellen MOST likely experienced what barrier(s) in this scenario?
column20: Gender and Physical Separation Barriers
column21: Mr. Levenda, Assistant Superintendent of Curriculum at Valley School District, sends a memo to all teachers requesting that the DVMA and DVRA must be administered by quarter's end so struggling students can be referred for additional RTI and MTSS. Mr. Levenda's use of acronyms confuses many new teachers. This scenario illustrates what type of barrier?
column23: Language

column9: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of implementing an open communications policy?
column11: Increased rumors
column12: Which of the following types of communication is used to communicate department goals and provide instructions on how to complete a new project?
column14: downward communication
column15: Messages, emails, and voicemails that are used to transmit information between individuals in an organization are known as _____.
column17: workplace communication
column18: Michael's company is having a difficult time recruiting employees fresh out of school. He tells his supervisor that the company should consider changing the vacation policy from five vacation days and fifteen sick days for a new employee to a paid time off policy of fifteen days. This would provide employees with a larger bank of available time off and make the company more in line with others in the industry. Michael's conversation is an example of _____.
column20: upward communication
column21: Is it possible to have too much communication in the workplace?
column23: Yes, if employees receive repetitive information or too many messages it can affect their productivity.

column9: Which communication style attempts to bring understanding to how employees of different cultures speak, communicate and perceive the world around them?
column11: Cross-cultural.
column12: If a company has employees who are direct, individualistic and base their decisions on facts, they are an example of what type of culture?
column14: A low-context culture.
column15: Jack made a business mistake when he asked Yamato's workers for their thoughts on his business ideas. The management structure that exists in Yamato's business is an example of what?
column17: A high power distance.
column18: What are the major factors that affect cross-cultural communication?
column20: Language differences, high context vs. low context, nonverbal differences, and power distance.
column21: How is eye contact viewed in certain cultures of the Middle East and Asia?
column23: Inappropriate and rude.

column9: Why is it important for an organization to utilize strategic communication?
column11: It better facilitates the flow and scope of information both within and outside of the organization.
column12: Baki Imports developed a rewards program last year in which employees go to an Intranet site to nominate their coworkers for a job well done. However, the program currently is underutilized because most employees are unaware of it. How can HR resolve this issue?
column14: They can draft an email to employees notifying them of the new program and its benefits.
column15: Which of the following would be involved in the receiving end of an external communication?
column17: The general public
column18: Which of the following is the BEST example of an internal form of communication?
column20: PowerPoint slides for a finance meeting
column21: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of strategic communication in organizations?
column23: It helps an organization to accomplish short-term goals and reinforce its vision.

column9: Tom the tech used to love building computers and game boxes in his parent's garage. Now that he has a job in tech, his boss tells him which projects to work on and enforces company rules that Tom must follow. According to the Cognitive Evaluation Theory, what is the effect of the job on Tom's motivation?
column11: Intrinsic motivation is reduced, while extrinsic motivation increases.
column12: Which of the three inherent psychological needs are satisfied for potential lawyers when they pass the bar exam their state requires before they can practice law?
column14: Competence
column15: Andrea, the accounting manager, only cares that her employees turn in all assigned tasks at the end of the day. Her employees are free to do the work as they choose. Which of the three inherent psychological needs does Andrea satisfy for her employees?
column17: Autonomy
column18: Which statement is true regarding intrinsic and extrinsic motivation?
column20: If you are viewing this lesson because you like the learning process, you are taking it for intrinsic reasons.
column21: Terri is taking a new job as an elementary school teacher. Her job requires her to join the teachers' union. Which of the three inherent psychological needs does this satisfy for Terri?
column23: Relatedness

column9: Directing a contractor to lay floor tile in a Versailles pattern with a half-inch grout joint is an example of:
column11: Providing a specific goal
column12: Identify the positive feedback message that provides the most specific feedback that could be used by a manager who follows Locke's Goal-Setting Theory.
column14: The cream filling in the cake you just now made is so smooth and delicious!
column15: Which of the following does NOT occur with goal commitment?
column17: Goals are kept secret
column18: When task complexity is high, an employee will be:
column20: More motivated
column21: Locke's goal setting theory states that goals should have all of the following elements, EXCEPT:
column23: Ease of attainment

column9: All of the workers at Ted's Emporium have been shown the cold warehouse where employees who break any of the company rules are sent to work. Just thinking about the possibility of being sent into such a bleak work setting keeps most new employees from even considering breaking a rule. In this situation, management is successfully using the technique of _____ in order to encourage good behavior.
column11: avoidance
column12: Which of these techniques is used to reward desirable behavior with the intent of increasing the likelihood that the pleasing behavior will be repeated?
column14: Punishment
column15: One week, shortly after her mother's death, Sarah arrives at work an hour late on two different occasions. Considering Sarah's personal circumstances, her manager decides to ignore the behavior in the hopes that it will disappear over time. Sarah's manager is using the _____ technique.
column17: extinction
