column18: Jim's manager catches Jim breaking one of the company rules. He decides that the best course of action will be to take away one of Jim's company privileges as a response. In terms of Thorndike's theory, how is Jim's manager responding to the incident?
column20: He is using punishment in order to decrease the probability of repeated inappropriate behavior on Jim's part.
column21: Why would a manager incorporate reinforcement theory in dealing with his or her employees?
column23: In order to influence employee motivation

column9: How would XYZ Corporation implement Vroom's expectancy theory regarding promotions in the company?
column11: By informing employees that promotions are tied to their performance and only promoting the best workers
column12: How can Vroom's expectancy theory be used to explain employee motivation?
column14: Once the relationship between effort and reward is linked in the employee's mind, he will work harder.
column15: Identify the three components of expectancy theory.
column17: Expectancy, performance, reward
column18: Which person developed expectancy theory?
column20: Victor Vroom
column21: Which component of Vroom's expectancy theory refers to the level of effort an employee is willing to exert in hopes that the increased effort will result in better performance.
column23: Expectancy

column9: Which of the following is NOT one of the referent groups that individuals use for comparison?
column11: Self-in between
column12: When a graduate assistant makes the following comment to a fellow graduate assistant, this is known as _____.Â 'That professor gets paid 150% more that we do, but does he complete 150% more research surveys?'
column14: output-input ratio
column15: Which of the following is an example of the equity theory?
column17: Sandy thinks that she works a lot harder than Shelly even though they get paid the same, so Sandy becomes unmotivated and her performance suffers.
column18: Which of the following is an assumption of equity theory?
column20: People care about what happens to someone else in their assessment of equity and justice.
column21: Which of the following statements best describes equity theory?
column23: Individuals are motivated by fairness and adjust their behaviors to align their input/output ratio with their referent group.

column9: Rachel is applying to business school programs. She has been avoiding schools that do not require an entrance exam, because she thinks the program might not be rigorous enough if they accept too many people. At the same time, she is also avoiding the most elite schools in her area because she is worried those programs will be too challenging. Based on the acquired needs theory, what type of need is strongest for Rachel?
column11: Achievement
column12: Which of these theories is based on the premise that one's needs are acquired over time as a result of their experiences and includes the needs of achievement, power, and affiliation?
column14: McClelland's Acquired Needs Theory
column15: Tom is the manager of a sales team. Becky is one of his employees with a need for affiliation. What type of work environment would be most beneficial to Becky?
column17: A cooperative team environment
column18: An individual with the _____ will desire agreement and compliance.
column20: need for power
column21: Phil is a leader within a political campaign. He has recently been named campaign manager because of his ability to coordinate and motivate his team of people. What type of need does Phil likely have?
column23: Need for institutional power

column9: Ginger just got the promotion she has been after for a very long time. She will be in charge of the entire creative division of her company. What need, according to Alderfer's ERG theory, will be satisfied?
column11: Growth need
column12: If Dennis, top producer at a financial firm, breaks his leg, what need from Alderfer's ERG theory would he likely try to satisfy?
column14: Existence need
column15: Frustration-regression involves:
column17: getting burned out and giving up on fulfilling needs
column18: All of the following are true of Alderfer's ERG theory EXCEPT:
column20: It suggests that fulfilling one need lowers the motivation to fulfill another.
column21: The 'ERG' in Alderfer's ERG Theory stands for:
column23: existence, relatedness and growth

column9: In employee motivation, the opposite of satisfaction is _____.
column11: no dissatisfaction
column12: How did Herzberg develop the two-factor theory?
column14: He interviewed employees to determine what made them feel good and bad about their jobs.
column15: _____ cause dissatisfaction in the workplace, are extrinsic to the work itself, and linked to compensation and job security.
column17: Hygiene factors
column18: According to Herzberg, how can employee dissatisfaction be reduced while at the same time building employee satisfaction?
column20: By finding the right balance between hygiene factors and motivators.
column21: _____ are linked to employee motivation and arise from intrinsic conditions of the job itself.
column23: Motivators/satisfiers

column9: How can employers use the behavior-based theory of motivation to increase worker output?
column11: Set clear goals with the employee and assign clearly defined tasks.
column12: According to the needs-based theory of motivation, employees are more likely to be productive if their _____ needs are met.
column14: Primary and secondary
column15: Behavior-based motivation says employees can be driven by _____.
column17: opportunities to do meaningful work
column18: Which of the following is an example of a situation that would satisfy a secondary need?
column20: Getting an assignment where you supervise 10 employees.
column21: An employee's primary needs include _____.
column23: safe working conditions

column9: Joe thinks that his workers hate their job and only come to work to earn their paychecks. However, he is satisfied with their creativity and imagination when they work on projects. Is Joe a typical Theory X manager?
column11: No, because he believes in their creativity and imagination.
column12: Mike is a Theory X manager. Which of these does he assume about his employees ?
column14: They would rather be told what to do instead of directing themselves
column15: Rebecca runs a research department with specific goals for new product ideas. She lets employees work on their own new product ideas every Friday with little supervision. Rebecca is practicing _____ management.
column17: Theory Y
column18: Mary allows her employees plenty of leeway in how they do their jobs and expects them to motivate themselves to be high achievers. She sets the standard by coming in early and working as hard as they do. The self fulfilling prophecies predict that her employees _____
column20: will motivate themselves and achieve the goals she sets.
column21: Which of the following is credited with the development of the Theory X and Theory Y?
column23: Douglas McGregor

column9: You are working for a large international company. One of your project proposals raised the revenue of your department by 5%. Your boss said, You are an exemplary employee and your work ethic and efficiency is at such a level that the entire company should strive towards it. Which of Maslow's five needs would your boss's comment satisfy?
column11: Esteem needs
column12: Which of Maslow's five needs can a manager fulfill by providing challenging work, inviting employees to participate in decision-making, and giving them flexibility and autonomy in their jobs?
column14: Self-actualization needs
column15: What does a manager need to provide in order to satisfy his employees' physiological needs?
column17: Comfortable working conditions, reasonable work hours, and the necessary breaks to use the bathroom and eat and/or drink.
column18: Which of the following is necessary in order to satisfy Maslow's safety needs?
column20: Having job security and receiving a salary
column21: Each of the following answer choices represents the fulfillment of one of Maslow's needs. Identify the answer choice that represents achieving the HIGHEST need on Maslow's Hierarchy pyramid.
column23: Tom started working at 8:00. At 8:15, his team-leader told him that the work he had recently done was excellent and he said if Tom kept up with the good work he would surely be promoted very soon.

column9: Which two researchers are most commonly associated with the second Hawthorne Studies experiment?
column11: Mayo and Roethlisberger
column12: Which term describes a psychological phenomenon in which participants in behavioral studies change their behavior or performance in response to being observed?
column14: The Hawthorne effect
column15: How did the Hawthorne Studies affect thinking about management theory?
column17: They were the foundation for the Modern School of management.
column18: How would a modern day manager best implement what was learned in the Hawthorne Studies?
column20: Ensure that work areas have adequate lighting
column21: How did the Hawthorne Study of five women in a bank writing room change perceptions about what motivates workers?
column23: They showed the importance of financial compensation to employee motivation.

column9: How many days does Marriott generally train an employee before the employee starts their job independently?
column11: 30 days
column12: Why does Marriott believe so strongly in taking care of employees?
column14: Happy employees provide better guest service.
column15: Which of the following is one of the ways that Marriott motivates employees each day?
column17: Pre-shift dancing
column18: When an employee is qualified to work in several departments within the company, they are _____.
column20: cross-trained
column21: Marriott Corporation is known for offering their employees perks. Which of the following perks helps employees to attain a work/life balance?
column23: Flexible hours

column9: You have a great idea that you want to be considered by upper management. Which of the following scenarios would increase management's receptiveness?
column11: You have had some good ideas in the past, which have saved the company money.
column12: Which of the following are forms of representative participation?
column14: Works councils, board representatives, quality circles
column15: Why do some companies use representative participation instead of participative management as a type of employee involvement program?
column17: Participative management involves all employees which is usually impractical to large companies.
column18: Employee involvement programs motive employees by doing which of the following?
column20: Give employees more control over how they perform their jobs.
column21: Companies that use employee involvement programs realize which of the following benefits?
column23: Increased productivity

column9: When employees are empowered there is _____.
column11: increased motivation and job satisfaction
column12: Empowerment is thought to come from the _____.
column14: individual
column15: What should Manny the manager NOT do if he wants to empower his employees?
column17: Promote competition between employees
column18: To effectively empower employees, employers must do all of the following EXCEPT:
column20: Establish a clear hierarchy
column21: What could Manny the manager do to motivate employees and increase productivity in the workplace?
column23: Encourage participation in decision making processes

column9: A company has stated that its organizational goal is to increase customer care quality. David, an employee in the marketing division, has created a new software that helps the company achieve that, and the customers are very satisfied with his work. Why should he be rewarded?
column11: Because he helped the company in achieving its organizational goal.
column12: Which of the following is an example of an extrinsic reward?
column14: A worker met a sales quota and was awarded a large bonus to his salary.
column15: How do extrinsic rewards differ from intrinsic rewards?
column17: Intrinsic rewards are self-administered, while extrinsic rewards are offered by a supervisor or manager.
column18: Thomas is an employee who has helped his IT company increase its revenue by 5% in the first quarter. The company CEO has asked the head of the HR department how they could best provide Thomas with an intrinsic reward. Which of the following is a likely response by the head of the HR department?
column20: You should give him more meaningful work, that might help him be more productive.
column21: Employees who are _____ motivated tend to work at higher levels of productivity and strive to develop professionally.
column23: intrinsically

column9: Which of the following is an example of an employee who is intrinsically motivated?
column11: Delegating work to team members
column12: Why should employees know what motivates them?
column14: It helps them determine which positions provide the best motivation for their particular needs.
column15: How does extrinsic motivation differ from intrinsic motivation?
column17: Extrinsic motivation tries to motivate by using external forces while intrinsic motivation results from factors inside the employee.
column18: Which of the following is an example of an employee who is extrinsically motivated?
column20: Receiving overtime pay for working long hours
column21: Managers who understand what motivates each employee are better able to determine:
column23: Which strategies and incentives to use to increase worker satisfaction and productivity.

column9: An example of a culture that utilizes low context communication would be _____.
column11: Switzerland
column12: How should a manager handle a situation where there are employees from low as well as high context cultures?
column14: The manager should manage the interaction and ensure both cultures communicate effectively.
column15: How are messages expressed in a low context culture?
column17: In a very specific and thorough way.
column18: An example of a culture with high context communication would be _____.
column20: Japan
column21: How are messages communicated in a high context culture?
column23: Messages are implied and quietly understood.

column9: Which of the following BEST describes why power type is important to an organization?
column11: The distribution of power types can impact how members of an organization behave.
column12: Which of the following roles is the BEST example of a position that comes with formal power?
column14: A construction crew chief
column15: Joel works on night shift at Betty's Books with a crew of five other employees. He has been working there the longest and other employees often come and ask him what to do, despite the fact that they are all in the same position. What type of power does Joel have?
column17: Informal power
column18: Cheryl has a Master of International Affairs degree. Because of this, the sales team always consults with her when preparing to negotiate deals with foreign companies. Cheryl has which type of power?
column20: Expert power
column21: Why would an American company with a multicultural mix of employees from Asia, North America, and South America expect varying perceptions about power distance?
column23: The employees' diverse cultural backgrounds result in different interpretations of power distance

column9: An example of a country that would subscribe to polychronic time would be _____.
column11: Brazil
column12: An example of a country that would subscribe to monochronic time would be _____.
column14: Germany
column15: Cultures that follow _____ are very well organized and work systematically.
column17: Monochronic time
column18: Cultures that follow _____ don't see a work schedule as a way of living their lives.
column20: Polychronic time
column21: How would a manager effectively deal with different concepts of time in their workplace?
column23: A manager would establish a polychronic time pattern to avoid arguments and frustration.

column9: The boss reprimands a production worker for poor performance. He says the employee is lazy and inattentive. He fails to consider the employee works with an old machine that is constantly breaking down. Which of these best describes the mistake in the boss's reasoning?
column11: Fundamental attribution error
column12: When Cal has success selling a vehicle, he attributes it to his preparation and superior selling skills. When he fails, he usually blames it on the customer. Which of these best describes the type of error Cal is making?
column14: Self-serving bias
column15: When individuals make an assumption about others without having all the data they need to be accurate, this is called:
column17: Attributional bias
column18: The district manager sees that sales figures have declined at a store for three straight months. He decides to replace the store manager. Which of these best describes the error in the district manager's thinking?
column20: Attributional bias
column21: What should company managers making decisions about employees do to remove attributional biases from their thinking?
column23: Take the time to gather all of the facts

column9: Two people speak to a poorly performing football team. The first is the coach. He yells and uses profanity. The second is the owner. She calmly lays out consequences if the losing continues. Attribution theory would say the coach and owner have _____.
column11: Low consensus
column12: Which term describes the cause of Joe's behavior when he arrives at work in an unusually foul mood because of traffic delays on the way in?
column14: External attributes
column15: Carla is always cheerful and positive at work regardless of the situation. Which term best describes her behavior?
column17: Consistent
column18: How people interpret events and, in their minds, relate them to the way they think or behave is called _____.
column20: Attribution theory
column21: Mary is confrontational with her mother, but then goes out a few hours later with friends to laugh and have a good time. This means Mary's _____.
column23: Distinctiveness is high

column9: What is the difference between a sycophant and a goodie two-shoes?
column11: The sycophant is simply telling people what they want to hear, and the goodie two-shoes is withholding information to not hurt individuals.
column12: Stacy and Margaret are tellers at a bank. Stacy recently told Margaret that she is having problems balancing her drawer at night, so she is adding her own money to it to ensure she does not get written up or fired. When Margaret's manager asks her how Stacy is doing, she simply says that she seems to be learning the job just fine. Margaret is an example of a _____.
column14: goodie two-shoes
column15: Ken and his supervisor were interviewing candidates for an open position on their team. Ken's supervisor really liked one of the candidates in particular, a woman named Julia. Ken did not feel that there was anything special about Julia, but he knew that he could work with her. When Ken's supervisor asked him his thoughts on Julia, he agreed that she was an excellent candidate and should be the one who they extend the employment offer to. Ken has taken on the role of a _____ in this example.
column17: sycophant
column18: Which of the following statements is true regarding impression management?
column20: Impression management can be either positive or deceptive in nature.
column21: When an individual in the workplace influences another person's interpretation of a person, place, or thing by controlling the information that he receives, this is known as _____.
column23: impression management

column9: As Petra heads to her desk, she notices the smell of fresh brewed coffee as well as the sound of raised voices coming from her boss's office. In this instance, Petra is acting in the role of:
column11: A perceiver, who is aware of things or events through her senses
column12: Mark walks into the office break room at 8:15 am and sees two employees fully engaged in a friendly card game. Why would Mark perceive this as odd?
column14: Factors in the situation do not match Mark's idea of a typical work environment
column15: Julia, a new employee, is forming opinions about other workers in the office. In this situation, her previous work experience, motivations, and attitude toward managers would all be considered _____.
column17: factors in the perceiver
column18: Kesha is given a tour of her new workplace and introduced to her coworkers. Kesha's perception of the corporate campus and employees will affect her _____.
column20: thoughts and actions
column21: Which of the following workplace scenarios is NOT an example of perceiving factors in the target?
column23: Wade perceives that he has poor finances and lack of opportunities for promotion

column9: Why is organizational identification important?
column11: The employees identify with the company's values and goals to work better as a team.
column12: Which of the following is NOT a positive outcome of organizational identification?
column14: Lack of employee pride
column15: The degree with which a company and the people within the business share the same goals, values, and desires is known as _____.
column17: organizational identification
column18: Why does Apple have a strong organizational identification?
column20: When walking into a company store, customers see that Apple is a way of life.
column21: How does organizational identification help companies to achieve their goals?
column23: Employees who share a closeness in values and beliefs want to excel in customer service and produce a high-quality product.

column9: Bob works for ABC Law Firm. If Bob saw himself as a corporate citizen, which of the following would be a natural result?
column11: Helping with tasks that have no immediate benefit for Bob, but help establish the company's future.
column12: An employee who believes in organizational citizenship _____.
column14: has an eye out for the company's best interest at all times.
column15: Which of the following is a reason companies want their employees to be corporate citizens?
column17: To ensure they look out for the company.
column18: Organizational citizenship is a perspective that employees have whereby they _____
column20: extend their behaviors beyond the normal duties of their position.
column21: In organizational citizenship, a company can be compared to which of the following?
column23: A city

column9: How might an employee exhibit abuse of property in the workplace?
column11: Driving a company car for personal reasons.
column12: How might an employee exhibit unproductive behavior in the workplace?
column14: Hanging out in the lunchroom.
column15: Which statement does NOT contain a possible result of deviant behavior in the workplace?
column17: It can make a company more productive.
column18: Which of the following does NOT illustrate how deviant behavior can impact a company?
column20: The company's workforce is unaffected.
column21: All of the following represent ways in which an employee might exhibit aggressive behavior in the workplace, EXCEPT _____.
column23: reporting a coworker's refusal to follow instructions

column9: What general four categories does job dissatisfaction fall into?
column11: underpaid, limited career growth, poor management, lack of interest
column12: Why is it important for a company to monitor levels of employee dissatisfaction?
column14: Dissatisfied employees may create high turnover
column15: Julie has worked in the same position for a financial firm for six years. She is generally happy but would like a new challenge. After two years, a new position finally becomes available, and she applies for it. She is qualified but is rejected in favor of Karen, an outsider with more experience. What can company management expect from Julie?
column17: Julie may become dissatisfied and perceive the firm as limiting her career growth.
column18: How should a company respond if employees voice their issues or appear dissatisfied with their jobs?
column20: Be attentive and try to resolve employees' concerns
column21: Joe works in the data entry department. He has become dissatisfied with his job. He never used to take time off, but lately he has been taking sick days. His work is now sloppy and full of errors. Which response to dissatisfaction is Joe demonstrating?
column23: Neglect

column9: Barbara owns a boutique hotel staffed by 45 workers. Her relationship with her employees has always been congenial; however, she still wants to gather information from them in order to assess their job satisfaction. Which of the following methods BEST suits her situation?
column11: Interviews
column12: What is the relationship between job security and job satisfaction?
column14: Job security provides job satisfaction for employees seeking employment stability
column15: Which of the following is TRUE about using surveys to measure employees' job satisfaction?
column17: Surveys are likely the most common tool for measuring job satisfaction
column18: Which of the following statements about job satisfaction is FALSE?
column20: Any form of reward will increase job satisfaction for all employees
column21: What is the issue with using performance monitoring to measure employee job satisfaction?
column23: Job satisfaction has no direct bearing on whether employees achieve their goals

column9: How does job involvement differ from employee engagement?
column11: Employee engagement reflects how much an employee is connected to all aspects of the company. Job involvement shows how much a person enjoys his job.
column12: John is a worker at an IT company. He never complains about his job, but isn't really satisfied with it either and when asked about the quality of his job he answers: It pays the bills. Identify which type of general attitude towards his job John has:
column14: Job-Doer
column15: How does a person's feeling about his job impact his performance?
column17: It strongly impacts how well or how poorly he performs.
column18: Which of the following is NOT an example of organizational commitment?
column20: Paying workers for the jobs they are expected to do
column21: Sarah is mostly satisfied with her job. Which of the following is NOT an element that contributes to her job satisfaction?
column23: The feeling that she needs new work challenges when there are no other opportunities.

column9: The behavioral component that centers on individuals acting a certain way towards something is called _____.
column11: Conative
column12: Judy has been assigned to complete an important project using new software. She is afraid that she will be unable to do so. Judy's fear is an example of the _____ attitude component.
column14: Affective
column15: With respect to the workplace, attitudes are defined as _____.
