column14: Ensure that states honor the court judgments of other states
column15: Which of the following situations is most applicable to the Full Faith and Credit Clause?
column17: A child support order made in one state but enforced in another.
column18: At the time the Constitution was drafted, the framers primary motivation for including the Full Faith and Credit Clause was to_____ .
column20: Prevent debtors from escaping their debts by fleeing to another state
column21: The Full Faith and Credit Clause applies to all of the following EXCEPT
column23: To prevent federal and state courts from hearing similar issues

column9: Why is the necessary and proper clause in the Constitution?
column11: To allow Congress to pass legislation that is not covered specifically in the Constitution.
column12: Because Congress has the exclusive power to regulate commerce between the states, states may not restrict trade between the states. Which clause in the Constitution prevents states from restricting interstate commerce?
column14: The dormant commerce clause
column15: Congress can make appropriate laws that are designed to meet a legitimate end. Which case established this power?
column17: Katzenbach v. Virginia
column18: What is commerce that takes place between two or more states known as?
column20: Interstate commerce
column21: The Constitution gives Congress the exclusive power to regulate commerce between the states. What clause gives Congress this power?
column23: The commerce clause

column9: Due process has to do with
column11: procedures followed by courts to ensure fair treatment.
column12: The Miranda Rights do what?
column14: Protect an arrested person from self-incrimination
column15: Surry wants to become a dog groomer. Therefore, she sets up shop in her home and sends invitations to all of her pooch-loving friends. After several months in business, the city shuts her down, citing that she does not have a license to groom dogs. Horrified, she cries foul play. Can they do that?
column17: Yes, if her city has a law requiring dog groomers to have a license.
column18: What is the main difference between the Fifth and the Fourteenth Amendments?
column20: The Fifth Amendment deals with those accused of a crime and the Fourteenth Amendment deals with government interference of rights of all citizens.
column21: What is one of the ways in which a person can be stripped of his right to liberty under the Fifth Amendment?
column23: Indictment by a grand jury

column9: Amad's parents came to the United States on a visa program from a Middle Eastern country. While they were here, his mother gave birth to Amad. Once their visa expired, immigration officials denied the family an extension and claimed that Amad was considered only a citizen of his parent's home country. What protection would Amad have under the law?
column11: The 14th Amendment states that any person born in the United States has the right to citizenship.
column12: The 5th Amendment that no one can be deprived of life liberty or the pursuit of happiness without due process.
column14: 5th Amendment protection
column15: How are the 5th and 14th Amendments similar?
column17: Both have a due process clause.
column18: Smitty was arrested on his way home. When he was brought into the police station, he was locked up for over 6 days without being informed of the charges. What type of due process was violated?
column20: Substantive due process
column21: Joe was arrested for loitering. Upon his arrest, he was denied a phone call. What type of due process was he denied?
column23: Procedural due process

column9: Once enough evidence is provided to a judge about the criminal activity of a suspect, what is issued?
column11: Arrest warrant
column12: Identify which of the following cases is protected by the expectation of privacy:
column14: A police officer climbing the fire escape to take a look through your window and seeing that you have a gun on your bed for which he arrests you.
column15: Why was the Kyllo v. U.S. case controversial?
column17: The police used an infrared device which disclosed evidence that was cause for a subsequent search warrant, thus making the case controversial.
column18: The police suspect that a few apartments in a complex are involved in prostitution. They are uncertain about which apartment it is, but would like to search all of them. Why would a search without a warrant be illegal?
column20: Probable cause has not been proven.
column21: Milford passed a police officer. The officer noticed a strong smell of marijuana on him. What can the officer do?
column23: A stop and frisk

column9: In order to adhere to place restrictions, where might an adult magazine be legally displayed?
column11: On the highest shelf with covering
column12: Which protections are found in the First Amendment of the Constitution of the United States?
column14: Freedom of speech, religion, and the press
column15: Under the First Amendment, which advertisement would be appropriate?
column17: Lose up to 20 pounds. Results not typical.
column18: In business, the First Amendment provides:
column20: Less government protection for businesses
column21: What can the government do when a business falsely advertises?
column23: Demand the company cease and desist

column9: The ethical climate of an organization is determined by:
column11: The content and strength of the company's culture
column12: KCK Manufacturing has developed a very strong company culture. Employees are aware that deadlines and quotas are most important to the company and that management will usually turn a blind eye if a few corners are cut to meet target time frames. What impact could this strong company culture have on employees?
column14: Employees may not act ethically because the culture does not discourage unethical behavior
column15: Which of the following are traits that would be MOST expected in a company culture that encourages ethical behavior?
column17: High risk tolerance, low aggressiveness and a concern with the methods used to achieve goals
column18: Workplace behavior is considered unethical if it _____.
column20: does not adhere to the standards set by the company culture
column21: As CEO, you expect to create an ethical workplace in your start-up organization. Which of the following strategies is counterproductive to establishing an ethical culture?
column23: Provide ethical training only to upper management

column9: Which of the following statements are true about an employee who works in a weak cultural environment?
column11: The employee must rely on formal rules when making a decision in their workplace.
column12: Tina's Tarts has a strong organizational culture that values attention to detail. How does the president of Tina's Tarts communicate the importance of meeting her high standards to members of her organization?
column14: She gives her employees a way to actively participate in meeting the high standards by providing them with a Stop the Line button.
column15: Which of the following statements are false regarding strong vs. weak organizational cultures?
column17: Organizations with strong cultures spend more to produce their products than organizations with weak cultures.
column18: Which of the statements below is true?
column20: Organizations where most people are committed to the core value have a strong culture.
column21: How does a weak culture affect the quality of a product?
column23: Since the employees do not know the company's core values, they do not know what quality to achieve.

column9: The core values which provide boundaries for, and shape the behavior of, all members of an organization are known as the _____.
column11: dominant culture of an organization
column12: A group of people may feel that they belong to a subculture within an organization when they _____.
column14: share a common problem or experience that is unique to them
column15: Grandma's Apple Pies has recently hired a new Vice President of Finance. She has over 30 years of experience in the finance industry, but has only been at Grandma's Apple Pies for two weeks. Which subcultures is she likely to be a member of?
column17: The upper management subculture and the newly tenured employees subculture.
column18: Bob is a pie baker at Grandma's Apple Pies. He has been baking pies longer than anyone else in the organization. Which of the following statements is most likely true?
column20: Bob cannot belong to more than one subculture.
column21: The sales force at Grandma's Apple Pies belongs to a subculture based on the shared experience of not working in the office every day and traveling to make sales calls. This is a subculture that formed due to which area of differentiation?
column23: Functional specialty

column9: What is true about the relationship between organizational culture and organizational climate?
column11: Only organizational climate can be measured or easily changed
column12: Which of the following statements is true regarding the culture and/or climate of an organization?
column14: The climate of the organization is like the mood of the organization
column15: Which of the following is not a possible dimension of organizational climate?
column17: Upward Mobility-Oriented
column18: Which of these best represents a goal-oriented climate?
column20: signs on the wall show the targets for production and people feel pressure to produce
column21: How does the upper management of an organization go about measuring the climate of an organization?
column23: By surveying organizational members with descriptive questions to gauge how they feel about their work environment.

column9: Elaine is hired by a telemarketing company to sell burial plots over the phone. The culture of the organization places a high value on achievement orientation. How would Elaine's manager reinforce this with her?
column11: By telling Elaine that he expects her to sell four burial plots a day using any means necessary
column12: Tammy is employed at a beverage company and is free to develop new flavors and concepts for sodas targeted towards teenagers. If one of her new drinks flops in a test market, she is not chastised for her efforts and is encouraged to go back to the drawing board to develop a new beverage. Her organization places a high value on _____.
column14: innovation
column15: New employees to an organization are expected to learn the system of shared values, beliefs, and assumptions that govern how people behave, which is known collectively as _____.
column17: organizational culture
column18: A culture that is rule-oriented and bureaucratic in nature is likely to place a high value on which of the characteristics of organizational culture?
column20: Stability
column21: Which of the following statements is true regarding the seven characteristics of organizational culture?
column23: How members of an organization perceive the value placed on each of the characteristics determines the unique culture of the organization.

column9: Which statement about internal communications is FALSE?
column11: Because they are private, internal communications do not need to be held to a quality and accuracy standard.
column12: The CEO of a large retailer writes a memo directing the individual stores to re-train all staff on sexual-harassment policies. The memo is read by the district general managers, who hand off the memo to the store general managers. The general managers are tasked with scheduling the training, and the employees will be required to attend a class session. Which role is MOST responsible for making sure the end-goal is crystal clear?
column14: The CEO issuing the memo.
column15: When performing after-action reviews of adverse events, such as a serious on-the-job injury, _____ is almost always a primary cause or a contributing cause of the negative outcome.
column17: Miscommunication
column18: Issuing a press release, holding a press conference, or posting a public blog to a website are all examples of _____ organizational communications.
column20: external
column21: Which statement about improving organizational communication is FALSE?
column23: When an organization experiences a serious adverse event, the best communication strategy is usually to lay low and wait it out.

column9: One generational difference in workplace communication is the tendency of _____ workers to use formal language, while _____ workers have a preference for informal language.
column11: older; younger
column12: Which of the following is NOT a factor that affects communication in a diverse workplace?
column14: Employees' preference for timely communication
column15: In some cultures, _____ in face-to-face communication is considered aggressive and intrusive.
column17: making eye contact
column18: Kelly manages a small team and noticed that for the last few weeks, Dashawn has been incredibly efficient and his work error-free. She wants to praise him; however, she is unsure whether to compliment him in front of his coworkers or in a private email. Kelly should acknowledge Dashawn's good work based on:
column20: How he has responded to compliments in the past.
column21: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of communication in a diverse work environment?
column23: A diverse workforce supports the company's predominant culture.

column9: Mr. Levenda, Assistant Superintendent of Curriculum at Valley School District, sends a memo to all teachers requesting that the DVMA and DVRA must be administered by quarter's end so struggling students can be referred for additional RTI and MTSS. Mr. Levenda's use of acronyms confuses many new teachers. This scenario illustrates what type of barrier?
column11: Language
column12: Which of the following best describes what barriers do to communication?
column14: Misrepresent or avert communication within the group.
column15: A U.S. marketing manager is irritated that his counterpart in Japan limited eye contact during a recent visit to his facility. Eye contact is a sign of attentiveness to one but represents inappropriate behavior to the other. What type of barrier is this?
column17: Cultural
column18: Mike, Operations Manager for Solar Solutions, has had communication difficulties about the daily production of steel in his meetings with James, one of the shift supervisors. Assuming this is an issue of hierarchy, the barrier they face is related to _____.
column20: Status differences
column21: Ellen in the Los Angeles, California office is frustrated over a teleconference meeting she had with Donald and James from the London, England office. Because this meeting necessitated the use of Skype, Ellen tried to push aside her preference for a face-to-face discussion and focus on the task at hand, but the meeting was cut short when the Skype connection was lost, adding to Ellen's frustration. Ellen MOST likely experienced what barrier(s) in this scenario?
column23: Gender and Physical Separation Barriers

column9: How can a grapevine be used as a positive communication channel?
column11: It can be used to communicate deadlines, meeting dates and even reminders of corporate events.
column12: Official, corporate-endorsed communication channels are what type of network?
column14: Formal
column15: If a CEO sends out an email to all employees explaining about an upcoming merger, this would be:
column17: Centralized communications
column18: What are three important parts of a grapevine?
column20: Friendship, usage and efficiency
column21: Tex wanted to quickly disperse negative rumors and he was able to communicate with the entire company by just passing the information to key links in the grapevine. What part of the grapevine did Tex use?
column23: Efficiency

column9: If you receive a company memo from your supervisor, what's the best description of this communication?
column11: Formal vertical communication
column12: Which one of the following is the best explanation of internal organizational communication?
column14: Transmission of information between different people or parts of an organization
column15: You are having lunch in the company's break room with a co-worker who starts to talk about a work project. What type of communication is this?
column17: Horizontal informal communication
column18: You are a department head of the marketing department having a conference with the department heads from the financial department and production department about budgeting for a special project. What type of internal communication is being used in this situation?
column20: Horizontal formal communication
column21: You are at a company picnic talking to your manager about the upcoming professional baseball game. He casually asks you about the status of a current project. What type of communication is this?
column23: Vertical informal communication

column9: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of implementing an open communications policy?
column11: Increased rumors
column12: Which of the following types of communication is used to communicate department goals and provide instructions on how to complete a new project?
column14: downward communication
column15: Michael's company is having a difficult time recruiting employees fresh out of school. He tells his supervisor that the company should consider changing the vacation policy from five vacation days and fifteen sick days for a new employee to a paid time off policy of fifteen days. This would provide employees with a larger bank of available time off and make the company more in line with others in the industry. Michael's conversation is an example of _____.
column17: upward communication
column18: Is it possible to have too much communication in the workplace?
column20: Yes, employees should be kept on a 'need to know basis.'
column21: Messages, emails, and voicemails that are used to transmit information between individuals in an organization are known as _____.
column23: workplace communication

column9: Which of the following would be involved in the receiving end of an external communication?
column11: The general public
column12: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of strategic communication in organizations?
column14: It helps an organization to accomplish short-term goals and reinforce its vision.
column15: Why is it important for an organization to utilize strategic communication?
column17: It better facilitates the flow and scope of information both within and outside of the organization.
column18: Which of the following is the BEST example of an internal form of communication?
column20: PowerPoint slides for a finance meeting
column21: Baki Imports developed a rewards program last year in which employees go to an Intranet site to nominate their coworkers for a job well done. However, the program currently is underutilized because most employees are unaware of it. How can HR resolve this issue?
column23: They can draft an email to employees notifying them of the new program and its benefits.

column9: In which of the following scenarios should external communication be utilized?
column11: When a company wants to communicate with its stakeholders
column12: Thomas from marketing and James from accounting have been appointed to formulate the company's new PR strategy. They are both heads of a department, and the upper management wants them to cooperate in forming this new strategy. Why is their discussion of a new strategy an example of horizontal communication?
column14: Because they are of the same rank in managerial hierarchy
column15: Organizational communication should be used to communicate which of the following pieces of information?
column17: All the answers are correct
column18: The manager of a company wants to inform his employees that they will not receive a high holiday bonus because revenue is down by 5%. He doesn't want to use formal methods of communication because if the information leaks it would further harm the company's stock, but he is sympathetic towards his employees and wants them to be able to plan their finances. Which method of communication should he use?
column20: The grapevine
column21: Mark is not satisfied with how his employer, Johnson Electronics, distributes products to customers. He believes that the process is inefficient and costs far too much. He has some ideas as to how the distributing cost could be decreased. Mark would like to share his ideas with his superiors. Which form of communication is best suited for such a situation?
column23: Upward communication

column9: For an organization to be considered a learning organization, they need to take in new ideas and be willing to do what?
column11: Take action on them.
column12: Why is measuring the success of organizational learning important?
column14: All answers are correct.
column15: Using systematic problem solving means that you rely on _____ and not _____.
column17: data, assumptions
column18: When you review past successes and failures, what should you do with the information?
column20: Share it with the employees so they can learn from it.

column9: How did Peter Senge help to popularize the idea of learning organizations?
column11: Through the publication of his book, The Fifth Discipline
column12: Sam's Gear is a very traditional organization that manufactures camping equipment. Stellar Trek is a learning organization that also manufactures camping equipment. How might the two organizations vary in their approaches to an economic slow down in a way that CLEARLY demonstrates their organizational difference?
column14: Sam's Gear might continue manufacturing their best selling line of gear, while Stellar Trek might create a new line in response to changing consumer desires.
column15: Which of these is NOT considered to be a benefit of becoming a learning organization?
column17: Allows the organization to attract and retain the best talent
column18: Which of these answers BEST describes a learning organization?
column20: One in which organizational members are constantly learning from everything they do.
column21: Why did Senge include personal mastery as one of his five disciplines?
column23: Because individual workers need to have something to focus energy on and personal professional goals provide this

column9: Collaborative research occurs when the views of all project members are considered equally important and _____ is reached as a group.
column11: a solution
column12: Which step of the action research process is concerned with how learning and results can be used to help future issues within the organization?
column14: Specifying Learning
column15: Reflexive critique is the need to consider evidence-based information in a work setting to determine the actual situation. All of the following are ways to gather this information EXCEPT:
column17: conference calls
column18: Which step in the action research process looks at alternative paths of action?
column20: Action Planning
column21: The five steps of the action research process are:
column23: diagnosing, action planning, taking action, evaluating, and specifying learning

column9: What are the main requirements for effective leadership in change management during organizational change?
column11: Clear vision and effective communication
column12: In which stage of Lewin's process of organizational change should a sense of urgency be avoided?
column14: Change
column15: During organizational change, why is the democratic leadership style more likely to reduce resistance to change?
column17: Staff members are asked for their opinions on how the change can be completed.
column18: During organizational change, which of the following can be done to reduce resistance to change?
column20: Get staff to appreciate the need for change.
column21: Which model of organizational change is more concerned with the interdependence of areas of the organization, rather than a step-by-step process?
column23: McKinsey's

column9: What is a learning organization?
column11: A company where employees are continually learning new things that help the company to continually adapt and innovate.
column12: Which of the following statements about leaders in a learning organization is NOT true?
column14: They do not avoid decisions; instead they implement new ideas by directing those who report to them to implement them per a detailed plan.
column15: Which of the following is NOT one of the '5 disciplines' as defined by Peter Senge?
column17: Team building exercises
column18: What would be the desired impact of creating a learning organization?
column20: The company would continually innovate.
column21: Which types of leaders does a learning organization need, according to Peter Senge?
column23: All of these answers are correct

column9: Because it tends to lack specifics, the _____ theory of change is sometimes of limited use to businesses.
column11: dialectical
column12: In Lewin's change theory, the _____ stage is characterized by preparing the organization and its people that a change is being initiated.
column14: unfreezing
column15: Strategic planning and TQM are change theories that are consistent with the _____ theory of change.
column17: teleological
column18: The _____ change theory is characterized by a three-stage process consisting of the unfreezing stage, the change stage, and the refreeze stage.
column20: Lewin
column21: Which change theory places a strong emphasis on the role of human influences on change?
column23: The teleological model

column9: Which step in Kotter's change model involves making clear links to customer satisfaction, profit, and performance?
column11: Anchoring the change in corporate culture.
column12: _____ is the best approach for companies that are planning careful, sequential changes, while _____ is best for companies that are implementing simpler changes.
column14: Kotter's Change Model; Kurt Lewin's Change Model
column15: Elizabeth is a new HR Generalist. She conducts an anonymous attitude survey of employees at her steel manufacturing company, and the results are shocking to her. Employee morale is at an all-time low, so Elizabeth feels the safety risk is high. She meets with management to brief them on the results of the survey, so they can see for themselves that there is a need for change. Which stage of Kurt Lewin's Change Model does this scenario describe?
column17: Unfreezing
column18: The three stages in Kurt Lewin's change model are:
column20: Unfreezing, changing, and refreezing
column21: Why is strategic change management essential for companies?
column23: Change is necessary for companies to continue to thrive and to meet or exceed their competitors.

column9: One of the best ways to deal with change is to _____.Â Which of these fits the blank?Â A. Simply notice that you are in the midst of change and that change is a part of you.Â B. Welcome change as a positive opportunity.Â C. Realize that change will happen once in a while, and when you fight it, you feel better about yourself.Â D. Face your feelings about the change.
column11: A, B and D
column12: The knowledge economy can be defined as _____.
column14: a system of consumption and production that is based on intellectual capital
column15: Define change-savvy.
column17: To understand and grasp change as it happens and realize what it can mean to your company, position and life
column18: A person who acts as a catalyst for change is called a(n) _____.
column20: change agent
column21: Which of these products would be most likely to drive change in the world?
column23: A new high-speed transportation system

column9: Which of the following is theory O NOT concerned with?
column11: shareholder value
column12: Which of the following describes the leadership under theory O?
column14: setting clear deadlines
column15: Why is theory E referred to as a 'hard approach'?
column17: It involves just looking at the numbers
column18: What are 'autonomous work groups'?
column20: A group of employees supervising themselves
column21: Which of the following rewards would be a combination of theory O and E?
column23: Reward for signs of commitment to change

column9: A company's research and development department BEST reflects the use of _____.
column11: routinizing organizational programs, procedures, and processes
column12: Which of the following is an example of fear-induced change?
column14: Updating a human resources policies to comply with changes to employment laws.
column15: How does learning impact organizational change?
column17: It leads to increased fears, which can negatively impact organizational change.
column18: What is the primary approach taken in studying organizational change?
column20: An interdisciplinary approach
column21: Which of the following is NOT a component of organizational learning under the Carnegie School model?
column23: Information distribution

column9: The CEO of a company executed a plan to increase production by 25%. After all employees began following the plan, she tracked its overall success. Which of the following steps in implementing organizational strategy is this an example of?
column11: Evaluation
column12: Peggy works at a financial institution where there is high morale and employees are all willing to jump in to answer questions for each other and assist when someone needs help or faces a critical deadline. Peggy's workplace has a _____.
column14: positive organizational climate
column15: What is the main focus of the organizational development process?
column17: to improve efficiency and effectiveness within the company
column18: Rod prides himself in being a self-starter who exceeds expectations. However, at his new place of employment teamwork is paramount. Although his manager values the skill set that he has brought with him to the new position, he will now be judged more on how he accomplishes goals with others. His organization placing a high value on collaboration describes its _____.
column20: culture
column21: Which of the following phrases best describes organizational development?
column23: the process of helping a company improve through changes in power, leadership, policies, or job redesign

column9: How does process change differ from strategic change?
column11: Process change is based on everyday operations, while strategic focuses on long-term goals.
column12: Which of the following changes occur as a result of structural, strategic, people, and process changes in an organizational environments?
column14: Internal
column15: ABC Corp wants to improve employee performance, skills, attitudes, behavior and loyalty to the organization. What type of changes should they make?
column17: People changes
column18: An IT company has decided that you no longer need to report to your supervisor before you make minor changes to software. Instead, you can now simply post the minor change on the company's community forum. Why is this an example of a structural change?
column20: Because there is a change in the administrative procedures
column21: How should the external environment of a company impact its strategy?
column23: It should be monitored, and at times even the company's fundamental approach to business may be altered due to it.

column9: Because front-line employees do not have direct lines of communication to project teams, a manager must function as a _____ in order to connect the two groups effectively.
column11: liaison
column12: Why is the managerial role of the communicator possibly the most important of the five major roles during a strategic change in the business?
column14: Misunderstandings can have a detrimental effect on change planning and execution.
column15: Jim is a mid-level manager for a furniture warehouse. A vendor change has resulted in the need for front-line employees to assemble some furniture instead. If Jim makes a change plan that involves him spending an entire week in the warehouse physically demonstrating the way to facilitate the change, which management role is he exercising?
column17: Coach
column18: During the strategic change planning process, an operations manager identifies three employees that she expects will respond very negatively to the plan. What should she do?
column20: Take on the role of resistance manager to reduce the resistance, catering to the source of their hesitancy
column21: In the strategic change planning process, when acting in the role of a communicator, a manager must answer which questions for his or her staff?
column23: All of the above.

column9: Pete manages employees who coordinate training programs. He wants registrants to receive notification of a training program cancellation due to low enrollment within two weeks of the start date. After a warning and a period of retraining, one of Pete's employees, Ralph, is still notifying attendees under the two-week mark. Pete has decided to give Ralph a final written warning and let him know that if he does not improve this could lead to his termination. Which step of the controlling process is this an example of?
column11: Taking corrective action
column12: Which of the following elements is NOT involved in the controlling process?
column14: Determining how to distribute resources
column15: Why is it important for a manager to include his employees when setting goals that are part of their performance appraisals?
column17: Employees are more likely to achieve their goals if they have input in the goal setting process.
column18: Controlling is the fourth step in a larger management process that involves which of the following?
column20: Planning, organizing and directing

column9: Jessica is a leader in her organization, and as such, she knows communication is important for the success of any organization. Which of the following would you recommend that she do to encourage communication within her organization?
column11: Foster a discussion of feelings
column12: An employee will voluntarily follow an effective leader because _____.
column14: he or she is inspired by the leader
column15: Manager Mike offered incentives, allowed his employees to voice their opinions, and communicated positive messages. How do these actions demonstrate good leadership?
column17: By increasing morale
column18: Major McCarthy shares personal stories of his first time in battle and his rate of successful missions with his nervous troops. By taking this action, he demonstrated what result of good leadership?
column20: He inspired his followers.
column21: Which of the following actions is an example of good leadership?
column23: Remaining aloof from employees, especially subordinates

column9: Marisol is using an organizing process in her business. How will the final outcome of this process address Marisol's position as the boss of the company?
column11: The organizational structure will show her as the top of the chain of command.
column12: Which of these is completed as part of the organizing function?
column14: Delegate authority
column15: Which of these is necessary to be in place before the organizing function can be carried out?
column17: A plan
column18: Which of these is the end result of the organizing process?
column20: The organizational structure
column21: Which managerial function is used by a manager to determine how they will distribute resources and organize employees according to a plan?
column23: Organizing

column9: Why do managers create contingency plans?
column11: In case the original plan fails to produce the desired results
column12: Why is a tactical plan relevant for the functioning of each company?
column14: Because it deals with the responsibility and functionality of lower-level departments.
column15: How are strategic, tactical, and operational plans related to each other?
column17: Operational plans are necessary to fulfill tactical plans, which lead to achievement of strategic plans.
column18: Managers use operational plans to _____.
column20: regulate the day-to-day affairs of each department.
column21: A procedure that details how to take an inventory is an example of a(n) _____ plan, while a promotional advertisement is an example of a(n) _____ plan.
column23: ongoing, single-use

column9: Which of the following is true of planning?
column11: It assists in assessing what an organization wants to accomplish.
column12: Which of these is considered an advantage of planning?
column14: It examines critical issues facing the organization.
column15: Which of these describes the purpose of planning?
column17: To work towards accomplishing an organizational goal
column18: Where does planning fall in the order of managerial functions?
column20: First
column21: Ricky is a new employee with years of experience in planning. He is committed to the processes and creates a plan that looks one week into the future. Which of his characteristics would be considered a barrier to effective planning?
column23: Not looking far enough ahead when planning

column9: Daniel manages a team that has missed their production goals for the past three months. After reviewing each employee's performance record, Daniel adjusted the sales goal to take additional quality control measures into consideration. Why is this an example of controlling?
column11: Because Daniel looked at team results and took appropriate corrective action.
column12: Matthew manages a mobile phone retail store. He has set a specific sales goal for his team to achieve by the end of the month. Matthew created a detailed action plan to help reach the sales goal. Which managerial function has Matthew performed?
column14: Planning
column15: Pick the answer choice that represents an example of organizing:
column17: Tom is a project manager at an IT company and is determining how he should distribute resources and allocate roles.
column18: Sylvia is a manager at an accounting services firm. She is designing a four-step process based on the functions of management, which include:
column20: Planning, organizing, leading, and controlling
column21: _____ is often called the fifth function of management. It involves the evaluation, recruitment, selection, training and placement of individuals in specific job roles.
column23: Staffing

column9: The _____ will contain a final review of potential alternatives, defending the final choice and strategy, determining how much value the change will add, and input from the stakeholders.
column11: transitional analysis
column12: In the _____, an organization will revisit the foundations of the organization, including its mission, vision, and values.
column14: present state analysis
column15: In a risk analysis, opportunities can also be referred to as _____.
column17: positive risk
column18: In a SWOT analysis, an organization is defining its _____.
column20: strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats
column21: Although it is not set in stone, change planning is generally most effective when it follows what chronological order?
column23: Present state analysis, future state analysis, risk analysis, transitional analysis

column9: Why are tariffs usually imposed?
column11: To make domestic producers more competitive
column12: Why is it important for a business to understand the culture of a country?
column14: Because it can help the business satisfy specific consumer preferences
column15: Which of the following BEST describes a foreign subsidiary?
column17: This is a form of business in a foreign country that it will own and control. It is organized and subject to the laws of the country in which it resides.
column18: Which of the following is NOT a barrier to trade?
column20: Economic integration
column21: How does an embargo differ from a tariff?
column23: An embargo is when a business' government prevents it from engaging in trade with another country, while a tariff is a tax on imported products.

column9: How does the internal social environment of a business differ from its external social environment?
column11: A business has more control over its internal social environment than external social environment.
column12: The product development team of a large pet food company considers adding cheap, low-quality ingredients as a filler in one of its popular products. Based on the strength of the company brand and management's approval, the team decides to go ahead with developing the product despite each member having private concerns. This scenario illustrates which concept and why?
column14: Groupthink, because they are placing group cohesion first.
column15: A social environment is BEST described as:
column17: Society's artificial constructs in relation to the natural environment.
column18: A business influences its external environment by:
column20: Utilizing advertising and public relations strategies.
column21: Why is a diverse workforce important for a business?
column23: Businesses are strengthened when they integrate the values and beliefs a diverse workforce offers.

column9: What is a condition that gives a business a competitive advantage in the marketplace?
column11: Perceived difference in product or service's importance to consumers compared to competitors
column12: How is an imperfect competition defined?
column14: A relatively small number of firms competing in a market with differentiated goods or services.
column15: In the year 2100, the economic market now reflects the theoretical idea of perfect competition. James is deciding which car he will buy. What will be the only perceived difference for him?
column17: Price
column18: How does a cost leader attempt to maximize profits?
column20: By producing goods or services at a lower cost; thus, gaining a competitive advantage
column21: Why would a niche strategy represent an example of a selective strategy?
column23: It aims to produce a certain product at the highest level of quality possible.

column9: Ultimately, technology can be divided into what two categories?
column11: Products and processes
column12: How is technological process different from technological product?
column14: A product is a finished good for customers, while a process is used to improve products.
column15: When does creative destruction occur in business?
column17: When a new technology creates a new product or process but destroys an old product or process at the same time
column18: Which of the following is NOT true about technology?
column20: It's always good for everyone.
column21: How is technology best described?
column23: Application of knowledge to the world to affect the environment by controlling or changing it

column9: How does a supply that exceeds the demand impact the price?
column11: It causes the prices to decline
column12: Which of the following is a factor of microeconomics?
column14: Supply and demand for a commodity
column15: Which of the following is considered part of an external business environment?
column17: Fiscal policy that affects export
column18: Which of the following statements about the legal environment of a business is FALSE?
column20: Violations of laws governing a business can include fines but not criminal penalties.
column21: How do macroeconomic factors and microeconomic factors differ?
column23: Macroeconomic factors focus on unemployment, inflation and taxes, while microeconomic factors deal with individual decision-making.

column9: When an environmental disaster, like an oil spill, starts a dialog among Congress and the President about changes to regulation, which type of force is at work?
column11: Political
column12: Which of the following is the best example of an economic force?
column14: The impact on the auto industry when interest rates drop and financial institutions can offer 0% financing.
column15: What does the acronym PEST stand for?
column17: political, economic, social, technological
column18: When consumers boycott a company because they discover business practices that violate human rights, which type of force is at work?
column20: Social
column21: The increase of streaming TV and movies online is an example of:
column23: Social and technological forces working together

column9: As an external stakeholder, what interest would a company's supplier have in a company?
column11: The supplier would want to be paid for the purchases made by the company on a timely basis.
column12: As an external stakeholder, what interest would the government have in a company?
column14: The government is interested in the company's ability to pay taxes so it can fund programs such as education and health care.
column15: Which of the following individuals or groups represents an internal stakeholder?
column17: Employees
column18: Which of the following groups or individuals represent external stakeholders?
column20: Creditors
column21: As an internal stakeholder, what interest would owners or shareholders have in a business?
column23: Owners or shareholders are interested in the company's ability to pay its taxes.

column9: What is your business environment?
column11: The setting or conditions, both internal and external, that your company operates in
column12: What is the internal business environment?
column14: The conditions inside your business that affect your operations
column15: Why should you analyze both internal and external business environments?
column17: You want to get a more inclusive picture of what is happening because each environment has a different effect on your business.
column18: Which of the following is an example of a condition in your internal environment?
column20: Your general manager and assistant manager can't agree on anything. They make separate decisions and tell their subordinates different rules. This has caused confusion among staff and has resulted in delays on orders.
column21: What is the external business environment?
column23: The conditions outside your business that affect your operations

column9: Some examples of internal environmental factors in an organization are _____.
column11: All of the answers are correct.
column12: Which of the following are NOT part of external environmental factors for an organization?
column14: Poor performance from upper management
column15: An example of an opportunity in business could include a good economy, emerging markets and _____.
column17: a little industry competition
column18: Organizations need to be able to make changes to their business model because _____.
column20: change is always happening (both internal and external) to the organization)
column21: What part of a SWOT analysis is based on looking at external factors?
column23: Opportunity and Threats

column9: Package delivery methods are expected to change greatly in the upcoming years as drones develop. Which external change influence does this represent?
column11: Technology
column12: Slim Down Soda Company created a top-level position for a corporate officer in charge of work-life balance initiatives. Which force of internal change does this address?
column14: Employee Expectation
column15: What term describes a change occurring due to deliberate decisions made in an organization?
column17: Planned Change
column18: XYZ Corporation reorganized the sales division to meet competition from other countries. What external force is influencing this change?
column20: Globalization
column21: Crazy Kids Clothing implemented new standards for fireproofing its' products. What caused this change?
column23: Ethical Behavior

column9: The following are representative of an organization's internal environment EXCEPT the _____.
column11: availability of product manufacturing materials
column12: Which term describes the act of monitoring the organization's internal and external environments for early signs that a change may be needed?
column14: Environmental scanning
column15: To remain competitive in the marketplace, Mary and her leadership team conducted a SWOT analysis to develop new strategies. This analysis could include studying all of the following EXCEPT:
column17: tactics within the company's external environment
column18: The following are representative of an organization's external environment EXCEPT _____.
column20: the ability to attract good employees
column21: ABC Company manufactures various electronic items for sale in an online market. Recently, sales have dropped off and, after doing some research, the management team discovers that an upstart company is selling to a portion of ABC's long-standing customer base. In response, ABC's management elects to launch a new marketing strategy to rebuild its customer base. This action represents _____.
column23: changing for the external environment

column9: If an organization does not develop its own organizational structure, it might _____.
column11: self-organize
column12: How does organizational structure impact the functioning of the company?
column14: It links organizational departments, functions or geography to accomplish the company's goals.
column15: Most companies plan a _____ to go to market with their products.
column17: strategy
column18: Why does leadership strategy change with the larger labor pool brought about by globalization?
column20: Leaders in other countries may be better for the job.
column21: Why does globalization impact MOST businesses today?
column23: Changes that result from technology make it more efficient to blend cultures, forcing businesses to adapt.

column9: An organization in which of the following stages of the Organizational Life Cycle is most likely to have the greatest number of rules and regulations for organizational members?
column11: Maturity Stage
column12: What can organizational managers do to attempt to avoid the Decline Stage of the organizational life cycle?
column14: Acquire other companies and/or expand their product lines in order to renew growth in the organization.
column15: Hazel rented space in a commercial kitchen and began hiring people during which stage of the organizational life cycle?
column17: Growth Stage
column18: An organization reaches a size that fits its environment and no longer needs to grow at the beginning of which stage of the organizational life cycle?
column20: Maturity Stage
column21: An organization in which stage of the Organizational Life Cycle is most likely to be informally run by one person?
column23: Start-Up Stage
column24: Which statements are true regarding the organizational life cycle?

column9: An IT company focuses on copying and mass-producing computer hardware that is similar to successful devices developed by companies that follow an innovation strategy. Which of the following structures would best suit the IT company's strategy?
column11: Both the mechanistic and organic structure
column12: A small business sells computers directly to customers. It does not incorporate excessive innovation and spends little on advertising. The environment at the company is very informal and could best be described as organic. Why is this NOT a common cost minimization strategy?
column14: There usually is a strong hierarchy in a cost minimization strategy
column15: How does a mechanistic structure differ from an organic structure?
column17: The organic structure is usually far less formal and departmentalized
column18: Why does an organic structure work best for an innovation strategy?
column20: This combination encourages input and decision-making by all members of the organization
column21: How does organizational strategy affect organizational structure?
column23: An organizational strategy is crucial to developing and implementing a viable organizational structure

column9: An organization structure lays the foundation of how a company ________.
column11: operates
column12: Which type of organizational structure enables a company to better serve the local market?
column14: Geographical organizational structure
column15: With a formal and appropriate organizational structure in place, which of the following statements is true?
column17: All of the answers are correct.
column18: Which type of structure is used when a company has locations in multiple cities?
column20: Product organizational structure
column21: Companies use the _________ organizational structure when they want to arrange their organization by department.
column23: functional

column9: How does having a top-level executive impact divisional structures?
column11: It makes them more successful by ensuring that someone who has authority is available at all times.
column12: Why are functional structures used by an organization?
column14: To have specialized work units that maximize functionality.
column15: All of the following are traits of the simple organizational design structure, EXCEPT:
column17: High departmentalization
column18: Sales and marketing, finance and accounting, customer service, and human resources are a few examples of groupings within which organizational design type?
column20: Functional
column21: Why is a divisional design structure used?
column23: To create several semi-autonomous units that focus on a narrow sector of business.

column9: Which of the following departments is an example of a functional organizational structure?
column11: Marketing Department
column12: A(n) _____ organizational structure separates a company based on a product, service, or type of consumer.
column14: divisional
column15: Which of the following organizational structures would have a Large Household Equipment Sales Manager?
column17: Matrix Structure
column18: Which of the following departments is an example of a divisional organizational structure?
column20: Large Household Appliances Department
column21: A(n) _____ organizational structure has departments that focus on a specific business activity or purpose.
column23: functional

column9: If you are a senior vice president and you have ten people on your staff, you have _____ power over those people based upon your title.
column11: Positional
column12: Bosses who are bullies or manipulators might tend to use what kind of power?
column14: Coercive
column15: Is any one of the five sources of powers more prone to misuse than any of the others? Why or why not?
column17: No, they can all be used as tools in good or bad ways.
column18: If you are a boss who doles out favors to all of your friends and ignores others who deserve the same treatment, you are abusing which form of power?
column20: Reward
column21: Hiring outside consultants because of their expert power might be viewed negatively by internal staff unless:
column23: Leaders seek buy-in from internal resources before making the decision.

column9: How can expert power turn a power relationship upside down?
column11: It can come into play when a subordinate has specialized knowledge required for a superior to accomplish a necessary task.
column12: Which of the following best describes a serious problem with expert power?
column14: If a manager shares his knowledge, he may lose his power, but if he doesn't share his knowledge, the organization will not be as effective.
column15: Where might expert power not be present?
column17: Stuffing envelopes
column18: Which is an example of expert power?
column20: A manager that has specialized knowledge for an important work task that no one else in the organization possesses
column21: What is expert power?
column23: Expert power is power based upon the perception that any member of an organization has a high level of knowledge or a specialized set of skills that is relevant to his or her job.

column9: Which of the following is important for a manager to be aware of when modeling behavior?
column11: Gender of employees
column12: Why is the term 'referent' used in this theory?
column14: The term is used because a manager's modeled behavior provides a reference point for an employee's action in a particular circumstance; the employee refers to the modeled behavior in an attempt to emulate it
column15: What are two features of referent power?
column17: Modeling and trust
column18: In which of following contexts would application of referent power be most effective?
column20: A small business with long-term employees and little turnover
column21: What does referent power encourage?
column23: Employee empowerment

column9: What advantage does an intangible reward have over a tangible reward?
column11: An intangible reward doesn't cost much
column12: Which is an example of an intangible reward?
column14: Getting off the night shift
column15: What's an example of a tangible reward?
column17: Lunch with the boss after completion of an important project
column18: What are the two types of rewards a manager can use?
column20: Tangible and intangible rewards
column21: Which of the following is not a disadvantage of using rewards?
column23: Rewards always cost money and resources

column9: Which of the following is not a disadvantage in the use of coercive power?
column11: It's illegal
column12: Why might application of coercive power in the workplace provide an obstacle to innovation and creativity?
column14: It's an obstacle because it creates an environment of fear and insecurity
column15: What is coercive power in leadership and management?
column17: Coercive power is forcing employees to follow orders by use of threat of punishment
column18: What is an advantage of coercive power?
column20: It can be effective in the short-term
column21: Which of the following is not an example of coercive power in the workplace?
column23: Writing up an employee that told a racist joke

column9: How might a manager with legitimate power supplement it?
column11: By supplementing his legitimate authority with other bases of power such as referent power, expert power or charismatic power.
column12: Which of the following is not an example of a person holding legitimate power?
column14: An informal leader of a team
column15: What's a disadvantage of legitimate power?
column17: It doesn't necessarily create loyalty to the manager or the organization
column18: Which of the following does not make legitimate power effective?
column20: Motivating employees through team-building activities
column21: What's the basis of legitimate power?
column23: Power based upon the position a person holds within the organization's hierarchy of authority

column9: Joe was 15 minutes late returning from lunch break today. Jill, his supervisor, tells Joe he must stay 15 minutes extra after work today to make it up. Jill is using _____ power.
column11: coercive
column12: Sam is a sales manager at a car dealership. He is instituting a salesperson of the month program where the top seller gets a plaque to hang on their office wall along with a free lunch. Sam is using _____ power.
column14: reward
column15: A key to a manager's success is the ability to use _____ to influence employee behavior.
column17: a combination of personal and positional power
column18: The main bases of positional power include:
column20: legitimate, coercive, and reward.
column21: Juanita is a manager at the bank. This morning she advised her staff that she wanted all pending credit applications completed and on her desk for review by 3 PM. Juanita is using _____ power.
column23: legitimate

column9: What's the best explanation of where a person's formal power comes from?
column11: It stems from a person's appointed position.
column12: Which of the following is NOT a basis of formal power?
column14: power coming from the popularity of the manager and his or her ability to create relationship with employees
column15: What is the basis of personal power?
column17: It is intrinsic to the person who has it.
column18: What is another way to characterize an individual who possesses personal power?
column20: an autocratic authority
column21: What's the best explanation of power?
column23: regulating the course or direction of activities according to your will and purposes

column9: Which of the following is NOT one of the main styles of leadership?
column11: Busy body
column12: What form of leadership usually has the lowest productivity?
column14: Lassiez-faire
column15: Which of the following is NOT a trait of lassiez-faire leadership?
column17: The leader clearly outlines how projects are to be done.
column18: What is a key characteristic of authoritarian leadership?
column20: The leader is often very strict.
column21: What is a key factor in democratic leadership?
column23: Encouraging employees to participate and share

column9: Tiana is a manager at a software company. She does not concern herself with production or employee needs. The work does not get done, and the employees are miserable. Which type of leader is Tiana?
column11: Impoverished leader
column12: Thomas is a CEO of a large PR company. As a team leader, he believes that _____.
column14: the company must be productive, but it is equally important that its employees are also satisfied with their working conditions
column15: Which of the following is a likely trait of a produce or perish leader?
column17: Authoritarian tendencies.
column18: Tom is a manager that allows employees to relax on the job. He often asks questions like, How are you? Is there anything I can do to help? and Are you satisfied with the working conditions here? Why is this an example of a country club leader?
column20: Because he cares about his employees mental state and happiness.
column21: Which of the following is the most important for a middle-of-the-road leader?
column23: A balanced concern for both production and his employees.

column9: Who is considered to have developed the idea of bureaucratic leadership?
column11: Max Weber
column12: In which of these situations would a bureaucratic leadership style be most effective?
column14: Samantha supervises an auto service shop. It is her responsibility to ensure the cars her team services are repaired properly and are safe to drive.
column15: Bureaucratic leadership follows a _____ management philosophy.
column17: by the book
column18: Which of the following scenarios depicts a bureaucratic leader?
column20: Aiden is head of security for a large software company. He is meticulous and carefully handles all security incidents according to the company's policies, rules and procedures.
column21: In which of these situations will bureaucratic leadership fail?
column23: When an organization needs to promote change and take risks on a regular basis.

column9: Mike coaches boys baseball. During practice, Mike spends a lot of time working with each of the boys on specific baseball skills. On game day, however, Mike becomes very directive, giving rapid instructions to the boys. This is an example of situational leadership based on the _____.
column11: situation
column12: Which of the following is NOT an example of situational leadership?
column14: Quentin is a project manager who really admires Abraham Lincoln. He studies Lincoln's leadership style and makes a conscious effort to modify his style to match Lincoln's.
column15: According to situational theory, _____.
column17: leaders should adjust their behavior depending on circumstances
column18: Anne coaches girls soccer. This season she is working with teams from two different age groups, one team is for 8-9 year old girls, and the other is for 14-16 year old girls. How can Anne apply situational leadership based on the capacity of the followers?
column20: Anne could provide more specific instruction to the girls on the younger team.
column21: Which school of thought produced situational management?
column23: Classical

column9: Which of the following scenarios best depicts authoritarian leadership?
column11: Arnold does not trust his employees to work unsupervised. He is constantly interfering in their work to make sure things are completed to his standards.
column12: Drawbacks of the authoritarian style of leadership include all of the followingÂ EXCEPT
column14: Autocratic leaders are regarded by subordinates as inferior.
column15: Benefits of the authoritarian style of leadership include all of the followingÂ EXCEPT
column17: Autocratic leaders empower their subordinates and are pleasant to work for.
column18: Autocratic leaders have complete control over
column20: decision making
column21: Autocratic leaders
column23: expect their subordinates to trust that they have come to the best possible decision on their own.

column9: Sarita recently transferred to a newly-created learning and innovation department at her company. Her new supervisor leads a team of eight but does all the decision making on new projects. Is the supervisor an effective or ineffective leader and why?
column11: Ineffective; the supervisor does not appear to value his subordinates' input
column12: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a participative/democratic leader?
column14: Focuses on what a subordinate is doing wrong
column15: When is the participative/democratic leadership style considered effective?
column17: In a team environment where productivity and efficiency are secondary to quality
column18: When is the participative/democratic leadership style ineffective in the workplace?
column20: In a deadline-driven environment where speed and efficiency are stressed
column21: Employees under a participative/democratic leadership tend to have a high level of _____ and _____.
column23: loyalty; benefits

column9: Laissez-faire leadership is most likely to be effective with which of the following groups of employees?
column11: A team of experienced landscapers who have worked together for years and enjoy tackling new projects.
column12: At which point will the laissez-faire leader intervene in an employee's work?
column14: At the employee's request
column15: Laissez-faire is a French phrase that translates into:
column17: Leave it be
column18: Monitoring employees is a critical activity for the laissez-faire leader for all of the following reasonsÂ EXCEPT
column20: it empowers employees by shifting the focus to them and away from the leader.
column21: The laissez-faire leader provides their employee with which of the following?
column23: All of these

column9: Pamela is a CEO who makes employees feel special by celebrating and promoting their work activities as well as supporting their professional and personal development. She also treats customers with the utmost care. However, Pamela's behavior toward the company's other executives is dismissive; she does not respect their work ethics. Pamela does NOT exhibit servant leadership because:
column11: Her supportive behavior does not extend to her peers
column12: Which of the following statements is TRUE of philanthropic characteristics in a leader?
column14: It is a testament of character and a requirement of being a true leader
column15: All of the following are examples of philanthropy EXCEPT:
column17: Tutoring a refugee in English
column18: Which of the following is NOT a trait of a servant leader?
column20: Spending more time talking than listening
column21: Which of the following is NOT one of Greenleaf's tenets of leadership?
column23: A real leader ensures his/her own highest priorities are served ahead of others'

column9: Charismatic leaders use their _____ to appeal to followers.
column11: magnetic personalities and charm
column12: All of the following can occur when a charismatic leader has personal motives EXCEPT:
column14: Allowing subordinates to share in the decision making
column15: Charismatic leaders are good role models because they _____.
column17: exhibit desirable values
column18: Why are subordinates willing to follow a charismatic leader?
column20: Because of how the leader treats them
column21: The charismatic leader's influence over others is due to his/her _____ power.
column23: referent

column9: Transactional leadership assumes people are motivated by _____.
column11: extrinsic rewards
column12: Wendy's supervisor constantly monitors her performance closely. He scrutinizes her work for potential problems and quickly jumps in to correct her to prevent additional errors. Which type of management is he exhibiting?
column14: Active management by exception
column15: What is most important to a transactional leader when delivering rewards or punishment to subordinates?
column17: Employee performance
column18: After Mario completes his monthly report, his boss reviews it to see if the standards were met. If there are errors, Mario is told he has to work an extra hour each day for the next two weeks. This is an example of which type of management?
column20: Passive management by exception
column21: Which of the following statements about transactional leaders and the chain of command is FALSE?
column23: Chain of command promotes employee dependence which decreases accountability

column9: What sets the transformational leader apart from many other leadership styles is their ability to influence others to follow them through all of the following, EXCEPT _____.
column11: extrinsic rewards
column12: The transformational leader uses individualized consideration, intellectual stimulation, charisma, and _____ to convince employees to transcend their personal interests for the sake of the larger organization.
column14: idealized influence
column15: Which of the following scenarios depicts intellectual stimulation?
column17: Whenever John's team is beginning a new project he holds brainstorming sessions, and encourages them to propose new, creative ideas for completing the project.
column18: The transformational leader uses _____ to control how they are viewed by their followers.
column20: impression management
column21: How is vision central to a transformational leader's goal?
column23: Before anyone can follow a leader, they need to have an idea of where they are going and why through vision.

column9: Which of the following is a characteristic of a task-oriented leader?
column11: staying accountable for assigning work
column12: Which type of leader is concerned with making employees happy by supporting, developing, and accommodating them?
column14: people-oriented
column15: The degree to which one is either task-oriented or people-oriented is referred to as one's _____.
column17: leadership orientation
column18: Task-oriented leaders are more likely to take control of a process because they _____.
column20: want to find the best resources and people to complete the activity.
column21: How do people-oriented leaders try to focus their employees?
column23: By focusing on the needs of the employees in the work process.

column9: Which is the best leadership philosophy?
column11: It depends on the situation
column12: Jill leads an ad agency that she staffed with the best and brightest in the field. She spends most of her time doing her own work and doesn't provide much direction to team members. Jill is MOST likely a _____ leader.
column14: laissez-faire
column15: What leadership philosophy best encompasses the statement 'Friday is Save the Whales Day, and I would like us all to wear orange in support of this great cause.'?
column17: Democratic
column18: What leadership philosophy best encompasses the statement 'We are all going to wear orange on Friday'?
column20: Authoritarian
column21: Which leadership approach should an elected leader utilize?
column23: Servant

column9: Which of the theories is NOT about the leader personally but is about the leader's ability to encourage collaboration and sharing?
column11: Situational leadership
column12: Which of the following is the most likely to require power to be shared by the leader with the followers?
column14: Relational leadership
column15: _____ theory depends on the leader having a charismatic personality.
column17: Transformational leadership
column18: _____ has emerged because of all the scandals in the business world.
column20: Values-based leadership
column21: Many theories see followers as someone to work with, whereas one theory in particular sees employees as needing to be pushed and even punished, if necessary. Which one?
column23: Transactional leadership

column9: Joe seems on edge and is short-tempered with everyone at work. His boss, Leon, thinks that Joe's behavior is caused by the extreme pressure of recent work deadlines and the current staff shortage. Leon is using _____ to explain Joe's behavior.
column11: false attribution
column12: Jeremy tends to use internal attribution in viewing his employees' behavior. Which of the following would MOST reflect this attribution?
column14: Jeremy thinks that Sarah's snapping at coworkers must be the result of a mental illness.
column15: Which of the following is an example of the Attribution Theory of Leadership?
column17: A leader sees Frank doing great work and decides he is a great employee.
column18: According to the Attribution Theory of Leadership, there are many ways in which an organization might be negatively impacted by a leader's attributions. How might that organization be positively affected?
column20: Employees could be recognized and accurately placed within the organization based on attributions.
column21: Which of the following is NOT correct regarding the attribution theory of leadership?
column23: Assumptions about others' behavior are generally wrong.

column9: Why are there opposing views on how the leadership of an organization should be conducted?
column11: Because there is a plurality of perspectives, none of which are necessarily wrong.
column12: How do democratic leaders significantly differ to laissez-faire leaders?
column14: Laissez-faire teams perceive and require the authority of the leader to a lesser extent than democratic teams.
column15: Which of the following is NOT an example of a behavioral theory leader?
column17: An emotional leader
column18: Your team leader has always been a natural communicator. He has performed his job well and he never doubted any of his team members. When working in a stressful environment, he always managed to achieve team coherency. Why is this an example of a trait leader?
column20: It isn't. It is entirely the responsibility of the rest of the team.
column21: How does the trait theory of leadership differ from the behavioral theory of leadership?
column23: The trait theory focuses on the characteristics of the leader, while the behavioral theory believes leaders can behave in different ways.

column9: Jane leads a team that is working in the R&D department, where they focus on developing new lines of products for customers. They are pretty used to working with each other more cohesively, and have given up on establishing some basic norms that they follow because they think it is a waste of time. Why is this NOT an example of routinization?
column11: Because there are no established basic norms.
column12: Which of the following is true in regards to Leader-Member Exchange Theory?
column14: Managers expect employees to work hard, be loyal, and trustworthy.
column15: Why is it better to be in the in-group rather than the out-group?
column17: The manager trusts the members in this group and begins to bond with them.
column18: John, a manager, is leading his team on a new promotional strategy to make the company best positioned for the acquisition of what used to be a very competitive company. He is trying to determine the skills of his workers, and what are their strengths and weaknesses. Why is this an example of role taking?
column20: Because the manager is assessing his employees' skills.
column21: Team members begin working on projects, and the manager begins to see how devoted they are to the work that needs to be done. What is this process called?
column23: Role making

column9: Krugman's new trade theory argued against the idea of comparative advantage as explained by which two economists?
column11: Smith and Ricardo

column18: Assume that you have two hours to spend at the mall. You can either visit the bookstore or enjoy a movie at the theater. The opportunity cost of watching a movie is equivalent to which of the following?

Mary Beth's business was no longer making a profit, and she was forced to close its doors. This led to people losing their jobs, such as journalists, printers, and newspaper delivery boys. Alan is finding out the tablet is hard to get a hold of because it is in such high demand, and the price keeps rising on the tablet at all the retailers Alan is visiting. Rachel is realizing that this is the case for many in New York and so the cost keeps increasing for this leather jacket she wants.Â What is the above scenario an example of?
