column9: What is a major benefit of a well-written chronological resume for the employer?
column11: The employer is able to see growth in skills and experience over time.
column12: A resume that focuses on skills is known as what type of resume?
column14: A functional resume
column15: Mrs. Smith is submitting a resume for an open English teacher position electronically. Since the resume is not being submitted through a website resume builder, what kind of resume should Mrs. Smith focus on writing?
column17: A scannable resume
column18: Which of the following is NOT TRUE about an online resume?
column20: An applicant's online resume will be filtered out of the potential candidate pool for a job if it does not include specific keywords to be read by a computer program.
column21: What is the PROBABLE reason that an entry-level resume is more likely to spend significant time outlining volunteering experience?
column23: A person seeking an entry level position generally doesn't have much work history.

column9: Which one is the first step of writing a memo?
column11: Deciding if a memo is necessary
column12: Which one is NOT a stage of writing the memo?
column14: Getting it approved by the CEO
column15: Why should you let HR read a memo on time-off policies?
column17: To make sure that the memo complies with company policies
column18: Who is the ideal target for a memo?
column20: The whole office
column21: Which one is not a part of a memo?
column23: Casting blame
column24: Which one would not be done when writing a memo?
column26: Include details of who is to blame for this change in procedure.

column9: Xander was asked by his boss to find out if there are any off-the-shelf alternatives available to replace the company's current database program. What would likely be the BEST type of memo for Xander to compose?
column11: A response memo.
column12: Jane is writing a memo to update her team leader on the progress of their team project. What type of memo is Jane writing?
column14: A status memo.
column15: What is the reason why an employee might choose to write a memo in the workplace?
column17: The message is too complicated for email, or confidentiality is important.
column18: Neil serves as the Secretary for the Board of Directors for Big Corp Inc. Part of his responsibilities in this role is to document what happens at the board's meetings. What type of memo may Neil prepare for this purpose?
column20: A meeting minutes memo.
column21: Ben works at his company's headquarters but just finished inspecting one of the company's foreign branch offices. What type of memo may he write about it?
column23: A field report memo.

column9: Which one is not a purpose of a memo?
column11: Pay slip
column12: Which section is not an essential component of a memo?
column14: Attachments
column15: What's the best description of the tone for a memo?
column17: Informal
column18: What is the first section of a memo?
column20: Heading
column21: Which one would be an appropriate recipient of a memo from the president of an American company?
column23: The professional staff of the company

column9: Joe is checking his email during the workday. Which of the following is NOT an appropriate use of email?
column11: Sending his Social Security number to Human Resources for the new payroll system.
column12: Although emails are quick and can be informal under certain circumstances, it is important to maintain a(n) _____ tone in a business email.
column14: Professional
column15: Why should emails always have a short but informative subject line?
column17: The recipient of the email will be able to identify the purpose of the message quickly.
column18: Which of the following is an example of a valediction?
column20: Sincerely yours,
column21: Which of the following is a best practice for formatting an email?
column23: Using headings and subheadings with a simple and common font.

column9: Why should someone write a business letter when most of today's communications are typically informal between companies and clients?
column11: To ensure that everyone is on the same page when it comes to business decisions
column12: Which of the following steps is included in the proper format for writing a business letter?
column14: Thanking the client for their business
column15: Which of the following is the first step of writing a business letter?
column17: Ensuring that the letter is truly necessary
column18: Mailing a business letter without editing and proofreading it beforehand could result in which of the following?
column20: All of the answers are correct
column21: Which of the following situations poses a need for writing a business letter?
column23: To confirm the points of a new contract

column9: In a business letter, the margins should be set at _____, and the font size should be set at _____.
column11: 1 inch, 12 pt
column12: The body of a business letter should contain which of the following?
column14: All of the answers are correct
column15: The opening section of a business letter contains the _____, _____, and _____.
column17: heading, recipient's address, salutation
column18: You are about to draft a business letter to a client named Theresa Hunt who was referred to you by a friend. You are not sure if she is married or not. Which of the following is the proper way to write the salutation?
column20: Dear Theresa Hunt:
column21: Which of the following is an appropriate closing phrase for a business letter?
column23: Sincerely

column9: Jennifer lives an hour north of where she works and is stuck in traffic due to a water main break that her teammates, who mostly live within minutes of the office, probably know nothing about. Jennifer needs to let them know that she will be late to work and will be unable to run an early morning meeting for a client. Which of the following is the best form of communication for her to use?
column11: Memo
column12: What is the role of instant messaging in an office?
column14: They allow for collaboration across the office.
column15: Becky works in a real estate office and wants to send a formal communication to thank a recent client for choosing her to market and sell his home. Which of the following form of communication should Becky utilize?
column17: Letter
column18: Mark is a manager who needs to communicate a new policy to his team members. Which of the following form of communication should Mark use for this purpose?
column20: Memo
column21: Sally needs to ask her manager if she can leave a little early this afternoon in order to take her dog, who has just fallen ill, to the vet. Which of the following form of communication should she use?
column23: Email

column9: Text messaging is an example of which one of the following?
column11: SMS
column12: What is instant messaging?
column14: An online service with compatible software that communicates instantaneously
column15: Which of the following is an example of NOT following the guideline to use correct grammar, punctuation, and word usage?
column17: RU coming 2 the meeting?
column18: If an employee emails confidential company information to a friend, which guideline(s) was NOT followed? Choose the best combination.Â I. Keep confidential information confidential.Â II. Use correct grammar and punctuation.Â III. Keep business and personal contacts separate.Â IV. Keep it short, sweet, and smart.
column20: I and III
column21: What is the most important item that a company should have relative to the use of mobile message communication?
column23: A mobile message policy

column9: What should a subject line of an email look like?
column11: Short and attention getting
column12: Which of the following is an example of understanding the rules and behaviors of email communication?
column14: Formality
column15: Regarding the proper structure of an email, the acronym CABS stands for: Correct closing statement, Address formally, Brief in length, and _____.
column17: Short title in subject line
column18: Which of the following elements should be included as part of a proper email closing statement?
column20: The sender's contact information
column21: Why should you never type an email in ALL CAPITAL LETTERS?
column23: The receiver will think you are shouting at him.

column9: Bob has been a loyal customer of Mary's Diner for several years. However, he recently mentioned to Mary that he's becoming annoyed by the volume of emails he receives describing the daily specials and new menu items being introduced. What can Mary do to help ensure she retains Bob as a customer? Choose the best answer.
column11: Assist Bob in opting out, or decreasing the number, of electronic communications
column12: Sending a monthly electronic message showcasing new car inventory would be an example of _____.
column14: an email campaign
column15: Electronic communication consists of _____.
column17: any communication sent by computer, phone or fax
column18: Which of the following is a disadvantage of electronic communication?
column20: Data overload
column21: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of electronic communication?
column23: Able to flood customers with email advertising every day

column9: A company has 15 different locations across the country in different states. It is experimenting with the use of a wiki so that engineers can collaborate on a new product design and share results from preliminary testing. What can the company do to ensure that all of the engineers are not overwriting important data posted by someone else?
column11: They can make someone in charge of maintaining the wiki and making corrections.
column12: What does asynchronous connection enable employees to do?
column14: Work without time constraints.
column15: In a business context, what is a wiki?
column17: A text oriented website that is hosted on an intranet within a company that allows all employees to add, remove, edit, upload and share content.
column18: A disadvantage of wikis is:
column20: You can work internationally.
column21: What is one benefit of using a wiki in the workplace?
column23: Allows companies to publish and share documents easily.

column9: Which section of the executive summary shows the important discoveries made during the research process?
column11: Findings or issues
column12: Why is it important for the executive summary to be able to stand alone from the original business report?
column14: Upper management reviews the summary to decide whether or not to read the entire report, so it needs to contain all pertinent information
column15: No more than one page
column17: No more than one page
column18: The subject matter, background problem, _____, methods of analysis, findings or issues, and the final section containing arguments, conclusions, & recommendations are six sections that make up the executive summary.
column20: Range of investigation
column21: The _____ section of the executive summary explains the reason for the report.
column23: Background problem

column9: What are repetitive patterns such as growth or decline data over time?
column11: Data trends
column12: How would the planning process for an analytical report differ from that of an informational report?
column14: Analytical reports require more research, data analysis and recommendation writing
column15: As part of your new position, you have been asked to prepare a monthly report on the number and types of mortgage loan applications that were received. What would be your first step as you begin to develop this informational report?
column17: Analyzing the situation
column18: Suppose that when preparing the monthly mortgage report, management has also requested that you analyze the data for trends in mortgage loan applications. What would you need to do differently when preparing this analytical report as compared to an informational report?
column20: Offer a set of specific detailed action plans
column21: What characteristic defines an informational report?
column23: It offers data, facts, and feedback without analysis or recommendations.

column9: Which report provides critical feedback and updates on projects?
column11: Status
column12: Which report uses informational reporting that contains facts about monitoring and controlling operations?
column14: Decision-making
column15: Which report examines the success of past or current decision making?
column17: Feasibility
column18: Which report provides advantages and disadvantages of taking a specific course of action such as whether to purchase a competitor?
column20: nvestigating business opportunities
column21: A human resource manager for a small company is revising the company's employee handbook. Which report type should the human resource manager generate for this project?
column23: Policy

column9: A researcher is writing a report on how well a new type of medicine can improve the blood pressure of patients taking it. He is short on time though, and uses data that he finds in a filing cabinet that another researcher compiled. What this researcher is doing can be best described as which of the following?
column11: Plagiarism
column12: A researcher's group of participants includes 5 male students and 1 female student. The researcher reports the data with the participants separated by gender. The researcher has violated the _____ of the female student by allowing her data to be singled out.
column14: confidentiality
column15: Permission gained after explaining all possible risks and benefits is called _____.
column17: informed consent
column18: Which of the following is NOT an honesty issue in formal report writing?
column20: Confidentiality
column21: A teacher is studying the effects of a new teaching strategy on the success of her Algebra students. Since she wants her school to formally adopt this new method of instruction, she changes a few numbers in her data set to make the strategy seem more successful than it really was. Has the teacher violated any rules in her reporting?
column23: Yes, the ethical thing to do is to present the information clearly and accurately, despite the teacher's desire for different results.

column9: Carl was asked to create a report about sales trends over the past ten years. What kind of research data would Carl need?
column11: Quantitative
column12: Two types of research data can appear in reports. Which grouping below includes both types of research data?
column14: Qualitative and quantitative
column15: Kisha is creating a sales report. In it, she wants people to be able to quickly see how steeply sales have declined month over month. What kind of visuals would be most helpful for Kisha to use?
column17: Charts
column18: Which of these is an example of qualitative research?
column20: Concerns voiced by members of the sales floor team
column21: Jim's company has recently opened branch offices in several countries where they had not been located in the past. What technique might best help those reading Jim's report on the company's growth to quickly grasp this progress?
column23: A map highlighting countries where the new branch offices are located.

column9: Carol is writing an evaluation report for City Council. Council members are already familiar with the background of the issue and the criterion by which things are being evaluated. They are most interested in knowing her recommendations. Knowing this, which organizational structure should Carol use in her report?
column11: Executive
column12: In his report, Carlos discussed how a product lived up to each criterion. If you wanted to read this, what section of Carlos' report should you turn to?
column14: Evaluation
column15: Kathy received an evaluation report written by one of her employees. She immediately turned to the section labeled 'Criteria.' What should Kathy expect to find in that section?
column17: Information about which requirements will be used to evaluate the product
column18: LaToya created a chart showing her department's performance for each evaluation criterion. In which section would LaToya include this chart in her report?
column20: Conclusions
column21: James is writing a series of evaluation reports for the company's newly formed interdepartmental strategy team. Team members are from a variety of departments and are not universally familiar with the history of the issues or the criterion by which James is evaluating the data. Knowing this, which organizational structure should James use in her report?
column23: Traditional

column9: Why is the requirements section of a feasibility report often referred to the criteria section?
column11: Because it describes how the writer evaluates the feasibility of the proposed solution.
column12: Hector is writing a feasibility report and needs to include information about the history of the company and specific regulations that affect their work. Which section of the report should include this information?
column14: Background
column15: Under which set of conditions would you decide to follow a traditional organization within a feasibility report?
column17: When you need to prepare the report for a staff meeting with co-workers and are introducing the information for the first time.
column18: Under what circumstances would you need to write a feasibility report?
column20: When you need to examine a possible solution and determine whether it is possible, given certain constraints.
column21: Which organization follows the introduction with the conclusions and recommendation sections before explaining the background, requirements, and evaluation?
column23: Executive

column9: Theresa decides to use the _____ organization in her recommendation report since she knows that her manager wants to read the recommendation right away because he is in meetings most of the week. She also knows that he will go back and read the rest of the supporting detail contained in the report when he has more time and returns to the office next week.
column11: Executive summary
column12: The _____ organization of a recommendation report lists all seven sections in order to create a very long and detailed report.
column14: Traditional
column15: A/An _____ is a paper that compares two or more solutions or products and makes a recommendation about which is the best option.
column17: Recommendation report
column18: Clarissa is writing a recommendation report for an event venue, and she needs to explain why she is not considering all of the possible venues in town. Clarissa should explain how she narrowed down the list in the _____ section of her report.
column20: Options
column21: The criteria in the category-by-category comparison section are described in the _____ section.
column23: Requirements

column9: Which of the following is the appropriate part of a formal report to mention a survey of local citizens who don't think their town is the appropriate place for building a new sports stadium?
column11: Text
column12: When you are preparing a formal report for someone who may be unfamiliar with the type of work that you are describing, it is important to include a _____ of terms the reader might not understand.
column14: Dictionary
column15: Bob, the CEO of a company, receives a formal report from Sam, one of his executives. He is very busy though, and just wants the quick facts about the project covered in the report. What section should Bob read to meet his goals?
column17: Executive Summary
column18: What are the three main components of a formal report?
column20: Front matter, text, back matter
column21: A team of builders and architects are working together to design a new shopping mall in an existing building. It has been determined that there are some electrical problems in the building that will be used for the mall. The owner of the building is now considering scrapping the project because of the cost of repairing the problem. Is a formal report the appropriate way for the team to communicate their recommendations on the project to the owner of the building?
column23: Yes, because formal reports may be used to provide a recommended course of action.

column9: Analyze the report titles listed below and indicate which one is most likely a recommendation.
column11: Market Street or Main Street? The Best Choice for our New Location
column12: Tim's boss assigned him the task of determining if the company has the resources to open a second location. What kind of report will Tim write?
column14: Feasibility
column15: Ethan was assigned to write a report about new menu options for the restaurant. He included a few pages comparing customer preferences between booths and tables. What standard did Ethan violate in his report?
column17: Focused
column18: A formal report is most often distributed to:
column20: someone outside the writer's organization
column21: Kimberly needs to write a report that evaluates her program by set criteria to determine whether it is effective. What kind of report does Kimberly need to write?
column23: Evaluation

column9: The data Kevin found for his report says one thing, but his boss wants the report to say the opposite. Evaluate the choices below and select the most ethical choice Kevin can make in this situation.
column11: Include the evidence, even if the company won't like it.
column12: Ira has to write a report, and he realizes that he wrote a paragraph in an old report that would be great for the new one. If Ira takes the paragraph and adds it to the new report without mentioning his old paper, Ira is:
column14: guilty of plagiarizing his own work
column15: Cheryl is asked to provide an informal written report for her boss. Which format would be beyond the scope of her assignment?
column17: A thesis
column18: Cheryl is reviewing her report before presenting it to her boss. She is specifically checking the items listed below. Which of the items is not related to ethical issues of fairness?
column20: Formatting the report so that it is easy to read
column21: Informal reports are:
column23: between two or more people in the same organization

column9: Which of the following is FALSE about incident reports?
column11: They always include a recommendation.
column12: Which of the following is typically found in an incident report?
column14: Description of an event that took place
column15: Where would you include a discussion of the purpose within the actual incident report?
column17: Introduction
column18: What part of an incident report identifies any witnesses to the event and summarizes their respective testimony?
column20: The discussion
column21: A local grocery store stocks grapes in the produce section. A customer unknowingly knocks a grape off of the display. It is later smashed and mopped over by the janitorial staff. Because pieces of the grape dry on the floor, a small section becomes more slippery. Later in the day, another customer walks by the grape display and falls on that part of the floor. What would be the most appropriate style of discussion within the incident report?
column23: Chronological formatting, because a number of related events occurred within a period of time leading to the incident.

column9: Why is it important for a research report to allow others to replicate the results?
column11: To demonstrate the trustworthiness of the findings.
column12: Jim submitted a research report for publication. The publisher sent it back saying that Jim included too much unnecessary information in his report. The section headings of Jim's report are listed below. Indicate the section he could eliminate because the information in it is unnecessary for a research report.
column14: Prediction
column15: Why do research reports written with a specific format save other scientists time?
column17: Scientists can quickly find what they need.
column18: In her report, Rene wants to include the reason she chose her particular topic instead of other similar ones. In which section of the report should Rene include this information?
column20: Purpose
column21: Consider the accomplishments listed below. Which person would most likely need to include a research report?
column23: Someone who discovered a procedure that can help increase student test scores.

column9: Crystal is organizing the body of her progress report. Evaluate the options she listed below and choose the one that is best for her.
column11: Work Completed, Work in Progress, Work to be Started
column12: Mike's boss said he included unnecessary information in his progress report. Analyze Mike's section headings below and determine the one he could appropriately eliminate.
column14: Fees Associated with a Project
column15: A summary of the project and project goals are included in the _____ section of the progress report.
column17: Introduction
column18: A major client is bringing in a group of managers to see how well Jim's company is progressing on the project they hired Jim to do. What type of progress report will the client likely be expecting?
column20: Formal report
column21: An appraisal of how things are going and an approximate date for completion of the project are both included in the _____ section of the progress report.
column23: Conclusion

column9: LaToya noticed that her company was mentioned in three different letters to the editor in the local newspaper. She wrote up a report for her supervisor summarizing the content of these letters. What kind of report did LaToya write?
column11: informational
column12: Sheila is responsible for selecting a fleet of new vehicles for her company. She is unsure if a hybrid or regular car would serve best. She asks Jim to compare the two and give her a report with his recommendations. What kind of report is Sheila asking Jim to write?
column14: analytical
column15: Informal reports are usually relatively _____.
column17: short
column18: Jared's boss wants him to write a short report telling him what the sales team has accomplished so far on this quarter's goals. What kind of report will Jared write?
column20: progress
column21: A brief memo or email within an organization is called a(n) _____ report.
column23: informal

column9: When should you revise the product?
column11: After testing
column12: Which of these demonstrates why it is important to understand the intended users of an app?
column14: A bunch of college students may not have the necessary knowledge to use a manual for a rocket.
column15: How should usability testing handle large products?
column17: Divide them into smaller chunks.
column18: What is the first step of usability testing for an app or technical document?
column20: Defining the goals of the app or document
column21: Which of these does NOT require a usability test?
column23: All of these could benefit from a usability test.

column9: If you were writing a manual for a wide audience on how to assemble a bed, which of these should make up the majority of your test group?
column11: Random people
column12: Who should record the reactions of the test group during usability testing?
column14: The test group and those watching the test
column15: Which of these would likely require usability testing?
column17: A manual for a new productivity application
column18: How many rounds of usability testing are required?
column20: As many rounds that are economically viable and needed to get the final product right
column21: What criteria should you apply when selecting test participants for usability testing?
column23: The test subjects should resemble the user pool as much as possible

column9: What is the goal of usability testing?
column11: To ensure the document is accurate and complete so people can use a product.
column12: If a tester finds something that needs to be changed, what should they do?
column14: Write down the change and send it to the test coordinator.
column15: Which of the following would require usability testing?
column17: A furniture assembly manual.
column18: What is the purpose of technical writing?
column20: To quickly and efficiently transfer information or process knowledge.
column21: What should individuals do when performing usability testing?
column23: Follow the directions exactly as stated in the document.

column9: Which of these is an example of a formal written technical report?
column11: A typed update to a publisher on the status of a cookbook.
column12: Which of these is an example of an oral informal report?
column14: Leaving a voicemail on your teammate's cell phone.
column15: Sarah's boss asks her to prepare a formal report for their client. Which of the following options is most likely to align with her boss' expectations?
column17: A detailed presentation that includes charts and graphs.
column18: Which of the following is an informal written report?
column20: A quick note from a supervisor about a scheduling conflict.
column21: Daniel is phoning a potential employer after submitting his resume. Which of the following is Daniel doing?
column23: Making a formal oral report.

column9: Why does layout matter when writing a technical document?
column11: Documents that are difficult to read may be put aside and ignored.
column12: Which font would be the most appropriate choice for a technical document?
column14: Size 12 Times New Roman
column15: Which text should be highlighted (bolded, italicized, or underlined) within a technical document?
column17: Important pieces of information.
column18: Which of these is NOT acceptable in technical documents?
column20: Using attractive colors.
column21: You are writing a memo that will be shared with the rest of the organization. What type of layout should you AVOID using?
column23: One that looks like a resume.

column9: Corbin is reading a document report about something that is new to him. He comes across a word he doesn't know but seems essential to understand the meaning of the report. If the report is well written, it will include a/an _____ to help him make sense of the technical jargon.
column11: glossary
column12: What should be included in the body of the text to indicate a footnote?
column14: A superscript number
column15: Which scenario describes when a writer SHOULD NOT use a footnote in their writing?
column17: When the writer wants to add pages of extended commentary on a subject.
column18: Glossaries and appendices are contained in which part of the document?
column20: The end matter
column21: A writer wants to include additional information in her work for her readers. Which of the following belongs in the appendices to the document, and not in the main text or footnotes?
column23: Maps and photos

column9: Why should a company refrain from downplaying or ignoring negative data about a product?
column11: It can hinder sales and cause legal issues down the road
column12: Your company sells a weight loss shake, and 25% of your consumers have lost weight by drinking it. You then advertise that 75% of consumers lost weight by using the product in a bar chart in a commercial. Which of the following guidelines is the company not adhering to?
column14: Do not overestimate results
column15: An electronics store claimed, without any credible data, that sales of a particular 4DTV had increased after hiring a new group of sales representatives. Management displayed this information graphically on a bar chart and included it in a monthly report. Which of the following guidelines is not being followed?
column17: Do not imply cause and effect relationships
column18: Which of the following examples does not follow the guideline of providing accurate visuals?
column20: A photo of a diamond ring that implies the diamond is twice as large as it actually is
column21: What are ethical considerations?
column23: Morals and standards of right and wrong that are adhered to in a business communication

column9: Todd is collecting data via a survey to determine how satisfied his company's customers are with the service they receive after purchasing a product. Todd's survey utilizes a scale from 1 to 5 that represents 'very unsatisfied' up through 'very satisfied'. His survey is collecting _____ data.
column11: Ordinal
column12: Farah is using a bar chart to present the breakdown of customers who purchase her company's core product by hair color. This is an example of which of the following types of data?
column14: Nominal
column15: Alex needs to convey some precise financial information to his company's Board of Directors in a quarterly report. How should he present this information?
column17: Using a table
column18: Visual graphics_____, while textual graphics _____.
column20: illustrate relationships and communicate a pattern through bar, pie, and line charts; create a message of detailed data mainly through the use of tables
column21: Which of the following types of charts is best used to show cumulative totals?
column23: Stacked Bar

column9: Pictures, charts, and tables which help to illustrate data to form a business message are known as _____.
column11: visuals
column12: Fun Town wanted their shareholders to increase their investments in ride safety. The marketing team decided to show photos of injuries that customers sustained from their competitors who enacted new rides, but did not spend the money on additional security measures. This is an example of visuals _____.
column14: reinforcing a written or verbal message
column15: Aubrey is putting together her small business's quarterly report and has decided to include some pie charts to help explain the recent sales data and future projections. This is an example of what visual role?
column17: Summarizing information
column18: The use of visuals in online slideshare programs is an example of how a well-prepared visual communication message can globally reach viewers to share information easily by _____.
column20: overcoming language barriers
column21: Fun Town added photos of laughing families and smiling children to its slideshow to demonstrate how much consumers love their product. What is the role of visual communication in this example?
column23: Creating an emotional reaction

column9: When a recommendation is needed, what should the writer include in the first sentence?
column11: a clear statement of the basic problem for which the recommendation is being made
column12: When writing a recommendation in a technical paper, the conclusion statement should be sure to _____.
column14: create a connection between the data and the recommendation; lead into the recommendation
column15: Jaleel is an expert in the subject matter about which he is writing. Should he include a recommendation in his document?
column17: Even though he is an expert, Jaleel should only include a recommendation when the purpose of the document calls for one.
column18: In technical writing, what is a recommendation?
column20: suggested steps or actions to take as a result of the information provided in a document
column21: Jill is a civil engineer. She has been contracted by the city to design upgrades to an aging bridge in the center of town that will increase traffic flow in the area. During her evaluation of the bridge, she found some safety concerns due to its age and changes in the surrounding geography. Jill's report on the bridge will now include a recommendation to enhance safety. What should Jill include in her recommendation?
column23: a specific plan for what she thinks should be done to fix the problem

column9: What should the first sentence of the conclusion focus on in a technical document?
column11: A general finding that emerged from the data
column12: Why should personal pronouns be avoided in conclusions of a technical document?
column14: To prevent the reader from assuming the conclusion is based on opinion instead of research.
column15: Which data should be included first in a technical document?
column17: The data that most strongly supports your claim.
column18: What is the difference between a conclusion and a summary in a technical document?
column20: A summary analyzes data, while a conclusion restates what the document said.
column21: What should be included if you present contradicting data in a technical document?
column23: An explanation of how your original conclusion is still the most logical based on a combination of all the data.

column9: What type of language should be used in the introduction?
column11: Specific language to identify the specific topic being discussed
column12: Why is providing background information important?
column14: It provides context for the specific topic being discussed
column15: What is the purpose of an introduction?
column17: To provide a preview of the document's content, while explaining why the information is needed
column18: How are introductions and abstracts different?
column20: Introductions set the context, purpose and structure of the document while abstracts explain the results and conclusions of the research
column21: How should the purpose statement be written?
column23: By using a declarative sentence that states the desired outcome of the document

column9: John's team is tasked with creating the closed specifications of a complex new product that a company has developed. When John presents these specifications to the manufacturer, what is the manufacturer expecting to find in them?
column11: Every requirement that must be met during production or assembly plus all third party requirements
column12: What are technical specifications?
column14: Detailed explanations of the required design and materials that must be used to create a product
column15: What are the two different types of specifications?
column17: Open and closed
column18: Why are most technical specifications from the government considered open specifications?
column20: Government specifications are open records and therefore can be accessed by any individual or corporation that wishes to see them.
column21: Why should a writer use the word 'shall' when drafting technical specifications?
column23: To clearly identify items that are required

column9: You are writing a long description and have documented a definition of an item. What additional information should be included to adequately describe the item?
column11: An explanation of the function and a description of the item's physical features
column12: What are descriptions in technical writing?
column14: Explanations of the physical qualities of an item
column15: When writing short descriptions, what information should be included?
column17: The name, necessary background information and physical features of the item
column18: Descriptions are used in technical writing when _____
column20: instructing customers how to use the features of a product.
column21: If you are describing the physical characteristics of an item, what types of information should be included?
column23: The size, color, texture, and shape of an item

column9: What type of words should be used when writing technical definitions?
column11: words that the general public can understand
column12: You have been assigned the job of writing a manual for some new software. In the phrase, 'download program updates conveniently from our website,' you need to define the term 'download.' Which of these should you keep in mind as you are composing the definition?
column14: You should use another verb to classify the term download.
column15: When writing a definition in a technical paper, how should one provide the information for the distinguishing features of the term?
column17: use phrases that are clear and concise, remove anything that is not vital to understanding
column18: Which of the following is the best example of classifying a term using specific language?
column20: A tractor is a type of motorized farm equipment that provides power to tools.
column21: Which of the phrases below best displays how a writer should use an example to expand the definition of a term in a technical document?
column23: _____ is very similar to the way water comes out of a faucet.

column9: Which of the following could be the result if you're caught falsifying data within a document?
column11: Negative consequences for your company's reputation.
column12: What should technical writers do to avoid plagiarism?
column14: Try to use only your own words and ideas or give credit to anything you get from another source.
column15: How can technical writers keep their documents unbiased?
column17: Choose words with a neutral tone.
column18: What should you do to ensure that all of your data is factual?
column20: Check your facts prior to finalizing a report.
column21: Mary is writing ad copy for a new product being marketed by her company. She includes language that implies the consumer would be a fool not to purchase such a wonderful, innovative new product. This would be considered an example of:
column23: Connotation

column9: Which of the following does NOT require preparation of a quick reference sheet?
column11: A three-page memo.
column12: What is a disadvantage of defining terms in margins?
column14: It can make the margins cluttered.
column15: Which of the following is an example of a good use of a quick reference guide?
column17: A list of abbreviations.
column18: In technical writing, when is it most appropriate to use an appositive?
column20: When introducing several new terms within a paragraph.
column21: You are writing a manual to introduce other employees to a new cloud-based software for your business. The software includes a number of terms that will be unfamiliar to most readers. What should you do to ensure the audience reads and learns the meaning of these terms?
column23: Prepare a glossary of terms that explains their meaning in detail.

column9: Why are extended definitions usually located in the introductory material of a document?
column11: The information is needed by readers to understand the subject matter of the document.
column12: Parenthetical definitions are _____, while sentence definitions are _____.
column14: a synonym or short phrase; an explanation of a word using one sentence
column15: What are the three parts of a sentence definition?
column17: The word, class, and distinguishing features.
column18: What should an extended definition start with?
column20: A sentence definition.
column21: Why are definitions included in technical writing?
column23: To improve reader comprehension.

column9: Which of the following is NOT an appropriate place to include a definition of a technical term?
column11: On the title page
column12: Which of the following is NOT important when determining the location of the definition?
column14: The reading level of the document
column15: When should a definition be used in technical writing?
column17: To explain the meaning of a word as it relates to the subject being discussed.
column18: Which of the following is NOT a good reason to choose a parenthetical definition over a sentence definition?
column20: To reduce the word count.
column21: While reading a piece of technical writing, you come across a sentence that defines a term. How can you tell whether this is a sentence definition or part of an extended definition?
column23: If the next few sentences continue to expand on the word's meaning, then it's part an extended definition.

column9: Why would executive summaries often contain specific financial data?
column11: They are written for business executives and managers.
column12: What are the three main types of summaries and abstracts?
column14: Descriptive abstracts, informative abstracts, and executive summaries
column15: Analyze the statements below and indicate which one provides the best guidelines for the recommended length for summaries and abstracts.
column17: Descriptive abstracts should be 1-2 sentences long while informative abstracts and executive summaries should be approximately 10% of the length of the document.
column18: The informative abstract that Sarah wrote is too long. She included the information listed below. Which information could Sarah remove from her abstract without negatively impacting it?
column20: Background information
column21: What is the purpose of a summary and an abstract?
column23: To help readers to decide whether or not they need to read the complete document.

column9: Why is it sometimes necessary to include front matter?
column11: Front matter provides the reader an understanding of who should read the document, what it will be about, and how it will be organized.
column12: If additional maps or diagrams are needed to further explain content in the body of the document, which of the below should be included in the end matter?
column14: Appendix
column15: What should be used to determine how much front and end matter to include in a document?
column17: The length and content of the document
column18: The information in the body of the document should be centered on what?
column20: The needs of the audience
column21: What information should be included in the executive summary?
column23: The cost and time associated with the subject

column9: Why are second level headings sometimes referred to as 'talking headers'?
column11: They 'speak' to the reader in more specific language about an upcoming topic
column12: Which of the following is NOT true of first level headings?
column14: First level headings are incredibly specific, so that readers can skip to the portion of the document they want to focus on.
column15: What type of language should be used to write titles?
column17: Short, easy-to-understand phrases
column18: Mrs. Jones is producing a document for her peers about the value of using paper books in comparison to e-readers in the college classroom. The title of her document is 'E-Readers vs. Paper Books: An Analysis.' What is LIKELY one of most appropriate second level headings for her document?
column20: Student Interaction with Text via E-Readers
column21: A student has just completed a major research paper for one of his courses. The document is over 20 pages long. Where should he place his title?
column23: On a separate title page, with the title at the top of the page.

column9: What is a self-assessment?
column11: An analysis an individual performs on their own work
column12: Bubba listened to Sunny explain that the customers who had issues with her table requests were there during the busiest time periods. Because of this, she was unable to service all of her tables' requests in time. This is an example of which constructive feedback guideline?
column14: Let the recipient of the feedback respond.
column15: How should feedback be delivered?
column17: It should be delivered in a private meeting.
column18: What is the goal of providing constructive feedback in the workplace?
column20: Provide information about performance to promote improvement at work.
column21: Which of the following is NOT a suggestion for giving constructive feedback?
column23: Never let the recipient give feedback.

column9: Michael Jones, living in New York City USA, is collaborating with Linda Yeo, living in Beijing China, to write a research document resulting from data they have collected by sending the same letter to many research subjects. Which one would they have used to be effective in this activity?
column11: Mail Merge and File merge
column12: What is the name given to font and layout setting templates that are used to standardize documents in word processing software?
column14: Style Sheets
column15: What tool places a ready-made block of text automatically into a document?
column17: Autocompletion
column18: What is another name for a template?
column20: Boilerplate
column21: What name is given to tutorials that help create documents such as resumes, letters, etc automatically?
column23: Spreads

column9: 'Beautiful Scenery would like to hear any feedback or changes in the proposal by March 14th, 2016' is an example of:
column11: Mentioning response requirements.
column12: If Bobby wanted to elicit a response by appealing to readers' priorities, which of the following should he NOT include in his email?
column14: Our decision on whether or not to increase the price will not be influenced by any responses to this message.
column15: Which of the following is NOT appropriate advice for message follow-up?
column17: After one month, send an irate message.
column18: Which of the following is the best description of a message follow-up?
column20: It is an act of contacting an individual again through email, fax, text, etc. in the hopes of bringing about a positive response.
column21: According to business etiquette, how long should an individual wait before sending a follow-up message?
column23: Seven days

column9: How can a writer create unity among different paragraphs in a document?
column11: By using the same organizing pattern for the sentences in paragraphs.
column12: If you were asked to review a document for a colleague, how would you evaluate it for unity?
column14: You would check to make sure that each paragraph focuses on one topic, all paragraphs focus on one thesis, and whether the writing follows a similar paragraph structure.
column15: What does the concept of unity in a document do for the reader?
column17: Unity helps the reader easily follow the progression of ideas in a document.
column18: How should a technical report begin in order to provide focus and unity to the entire document?
column20: With a thesis statement to explain the purpose of the writing.
column21: What is the purpose of writing a topic sentence within every paragraph of a report?
column23: A topic sentence answers questions the audience might have.

column9: When should the Table of Contents be included in a document?
column11: When the document is longer than ten pages.
column12: You are writing about the history of immigration into the United States during the 20th century. The main content includes the changing immigration policies during different administrations and the impact on the total population. What would be the most appropriate heading for the end of immigration following World War I in the 1920s?
column14: United States Immigration ends in 1920s
column15: What type(s) of information should be included as part of a List of Figures?
column17: The name of the figure and the page number where it is located within the document.
column18: Why should writers use headings in technical documents?
column20: To provide a visual cue for important topics and break the information into smaller chunks.
column21: What is the purpose of a typographical cue?
column23: To emphasize a point.

column9: How long should most paragraphs be?
column11: Five to six sentences
column12: Why should you include a conclusion in your technical document?
column14: To reinforce the points you made in your document.
column15: On what aspect should your choice of organizational patterns be based?
column17: Your audience's needs and your document's purpose
column18: A university president sent out a very detailed email message to faculty, staff and students discussing how to resolve the feral cat problem on campus. The message included a lengthy survey to assess opinions on wildlife, feral cats and problem-resolution. The response rate was very low since most on campus were not aware of such a large problem. What should have the president done to achieve better results from his message?
column20: The information should have been arranged more strategically to define the problem and then suggest potential solutions.
column21: What information should be included in the introduction to a technical document?
column23: What the document is, an overview of the main points, why it is being sent, and what action needs to be taken.

column9: Which of the following would be an example of an unclear reference?
column11: Review your textbook along with the related worksheet labeled anatomy of a cat and circle the location of its stomach.
column12: What important step can writers take to verify their written documents follow basic grammatical rules?
column14: Proofread the final draft of the document
column15: What are some potential problems with written documents that are not easily understood?
column17: the document could lead to frustration and work-related errors
column18: When writing a technical document, the sentence length should be evaluated against what standard?
column20: Aim for a length of 10-15 words per sentence
column21: What is one method of using words wisely to retain a reader's interest in a technical report?
column23: Including some variety in the way that sentences begin

column9: Why should you include visual cues in the text?
column11: To break text into easy to understand chunks and help readers quickly find information.
column12: Jeremy is writing the employee handbook for his organization. What visual cues could he incorporate to make the document visually complete?
column14: Create short headings that indicate the topic for each related group of paragraphs.
column15: How can you BEST ensure your document is usable?
column17: Make sure the information is easy to understand, engaging and valuable.
column18: Visual aids should be incorporated into a technical document:
column20: When words cannot convey an idea.
column21: Which of the following is NOT an element of textual completeness?
column23: Follow guidelines for length

column9: Which term is used to refer to a situation when the score is based on 100 points with a higher score reflecting an easier read of the document?
column11: Flesch Reading Ease Score
column12: The ball balloon magnetic block game is expected to exceed sales is an example of:
column14: Long noun grouping
column15: Which one would you be achieving when you avoid dangling modifiers?
column17: Conciseness
column18: Which one is the most appropriate way to reduce writing errors in your documents?
column20: Utilize Spelling & Review option in Word.
column21: Which one ranks written documents by grade level achievement to help determine readability?
column23: Flesch-Kincaid Grade Level Index

column9: Which words can be eliminated to improve conciseness?
column11: Words that don't add to or express the main point of the message.
column12: What does it mean to be concise in writing?
column14: Use only the necessary amount of words to describe an idea.
column15: How can conciseness be achieved in technical writing?
column17: By eliminating unnecessary words, phrases, and verbs.
column18: Why should clichÃ©s be avoided in technical writing?
column20: They can be interpreted differently by different people, which leads to confusion.
column21: What type of verbs should technical writers use?
column23: Action verbs

column9: Searching for spelling & grammar errors, checking for accuracy, and _____ are the steps involved in proofreading a message.
column11: Determining clarity
column12: Which of the following is a known way to assist a writer with creating a clear and organized message?
column14: All of the answers are correct
column15: _____ is the process of examining a document to search for writing mistakes and omissions.
column17: Proofreading
column18: Which of the following describes the accuracy of a message?
column20: The degree the information represented is correct
column21: Janet has just completed writing a press release for her company. Janet wants to ensure that she does not have any spelling or grammar errors in her work, so she asks her co-worker, Meghan, to review the press release for her. This is known as _____.
column23: Peer review

column9: How can a writer ensure that a document is contextually correct?
column11: Verify the sources and proofread the document
column12: Which of the following sentences is NOT punctuated correctly?
column14: My sister likes heavy metal music, my brother likes classical music.
column15: Why is using spell check not enough to ensure that the spelling in the document is correct?
column17: Spell check does not always pick up on incorrect word choice if the spelling of the word that is used is correct
column18: What can a writer do to ensure the style of the document is correct?
column20: Write in active voice, use an appropriate tone, and cut out unnecessary words

column9: Why should writers use an organizational pattern for their technical documents?
column11: To keep the writing clear and focused.
column12: Apple has recently released the newest version of their iPhone with some exciting new camera enhancements. The company wants to be sure that current iPhone users understand what makes the new smartphone so much better than the previous version. How should they organize their writing to promote the updates to readers?
column14: Utilize the compare and contrast style of writing.
column15: What should writers consider when choosing which organizational pattern to use in their writing?
column17: The audience and purpose of the document.
column18: Why might a writer choose to use the order of importance organizational pattern?
column20: To help readers understand that a certain issue needs to be addressed before other issues.
column21: Under which of the following situations would a writer consider using the spatial organizational pattern?
column23: When documenting the location of activities on a cruise ship.

column9: Why should acronyms not be used in technical writing until the original words are spelled out?
column11: The letters might mean different things to different people.
column12: How can writers ensure they include specific details in their documents?
column14: By addressing the 5 W questions and having someone review the piece for missed information.
column15: What is a possible problem when using cliches in technical writing?
column17: Not everyone is familiar with the expressions and can lead to misunderstanding of the information.
column18: Why is clarity important in technical writing?
column20: It will help prevent confusion among readers which will reduce frustration.
column21: Which of the following sentences is an example of writing using active voice?
column23: The board of directors approved a bonus of 25% for all employees.

column9: What is parallel structure?
column11: The use of the same grammatical form when presenting ideas.
column12: Which sentence has parallel structure?
column14: The writer must make strong points, stick to the subject, and use concise language.
column15: Why should parallel structure be used in technical writing?
column17: It creates equality among ideas and allows the writing to be clear and concise.
column18: Which sentence has parallel structure?
column20: He went to the store to buy an apple, a pear, a steak, a pineapple, a pie, and a pizza.
column21: Please choose the best option to complete the sentence below using parallel structure.Â In order to turn on your cell phone, you must
column23: hold down the ON button, wait five seconds, and swipe your finger across the screen.

column9: Check the parallelism of the following sentence. Choose the answer that best corrects the problem.Â Although he enjoyed running and to play baseball, he decided to try out for volleyball instead.
column11: Change to play baseball to playing baseball
column12: Check the parallelism of the following sentence. Choose the answer that best corrects the problem.Â He sat down at the table expecting to order, eat, and be enjoying his meal alone.
column14: Change be enjoying to enjoy
column15: When using coordinating conjunctions like but, and, or and so, writers should _____.
column17: edit to make the words on either side of the conjunction parallel
column18: Choose the most correct statement regarding parallel structure in a series of items.
column20: Parallel structure in a series often highlights verb tenses that agree.
column21: Check the parallelism of the following sentence. Choose the answer that best corrects the problem.Â We neither had money nor enough time to escape.
column23: We had neither enough money nor enough time to escape.

column9: What have you achieved when utilizing similar margins, typeface, typestyle, and colors throughout a document?
column11: Consistency
column12: What is the best margin format for business papers?
column14: Flush-Left

column17: Limit the charts and graphs to the minimum needed to communicate your message and remove wrapping text.

column20: Times New Roman

column23: Balance

column9: What way of organizing a message is about examining why something happened or the effects of something occurring at work?
column11: Cause/Effect
column12: Santino has been asked to write a message detailing the route followed by a delivery truck to local Whole Foods stores throughout the day, noting the amount of time completing the delivery at each store. Which type of message structure should he use to outline his message?
column14: Chronological order
column15: A company memo or lab report is an example of:
column17: General Organizational Pattern
column18: What is a method where a writer explains a business problem and develops a solution?
column20: Problem/Solution
column21: What organizational method involves organizing ideas in the order of most importance to least importance?
column23: Emphatic

column9: Which of the following is used to offer more evidence for the topic sentence?
column11: Supporting sentences
column12: Words or phrases that are used to help link a paragraph together and provide flow are known as _____.
column14: transitions
column15: Where does a topic sentence usually appear in a paragraph within a business communication?
column17: It is usually the very first sentence in the paragraph.
column18: What are the three key pieces of developing a strong paragraph?
column20: Topic sentence, supporting sentences and transitions
column21: Which of the following words or phrases could be used as a transition?
column23: However

column9: Rachel went to the bank, but it was closed for the Christmas holiday.Â Why is this structure considered a compound sentence?
column11: It is made up of two independent clauses.
column12: What are the four types of effective sentence structures for business communication?
column14: Simple, compound, complex, and compound-complex

column17: Complex sentence
column18: Rachel went to the bank.Â This is an example of a _____.
column20: simple sentence
column21: Why is the following structure a compound-complex sentence?Â Rachel went to cash her check to have some extra money for the after-Christmas sales, but the bank was closed due to the holiday.
column23: It contains two main clauses and at least one dependent clause.

column9: Passive verbs are usually recognized by _____
column11: the use of commanding verbs.
column12: 'At the Christmas concert, a woman from our church sang the soprano solo in 'O Holy Night'' is an example of which of the following?
column14: A sentence written in active voice
column15: Using active verbs strengthens the delivery of business writing by _____
column17: communicating something a person, animal or object can do.

column20: Passive voice is too direct.

column23: A sentence written in present progressive tense

column9: What would be an example of nondiscriminatory language to use when describing a blind worker?
column11: A person who has a vision disability
column12: What would be a gender neutral word choice for fireman?
column14: Firefighter
column15: Which of the following would be considered an example of discriminatory language?
column17: Old man, I wasn't even alive yet when you started working at this company.
column18: Which of the following is an area that can present nondiscriminatory language challenges in the workplace?
column20: All of these answers are correct.
column21: Assume that you were writing a job description for a position with your company. How would you include information that reflects a nondiscriminatory mention of age in describing desired applicants?
column23: We are interested in anyone with bakery experience who does not have disabilities that would affect their work.

column9: Directions provided to students in a communications class asked them to avoid 'extemporaneous preparations when planning required speeches'. The professor could avoid confusion by rewriting his directions incorporating which of the following strategies:
column11: Choosing recognizable words
column12: Steve has been asked to provide his staff an update on planned training activities for the next six months. In the past, he has received requests for clarification because his messages were excessively detailed and included glowing adjectives describing how great the sessions would be for employees. What should he do when writing the next message to provide more clarity and eliminate unnecessary questions?
column14: Choose robust/specific words including strong nouns and verbs.

column17: Corporate jargon
column18: Executive Director Tim enjoys sending out lengthy emails to his staff summarizing articles he reads on educational topics. Lately, he has been seeing software reviews that promise seamless integration with other software. His messages constantly reference how great it would be to purchase new software that offers seamless integration with current products. The use of seamless is an example of what type of communication mistake?
column20: Buzzwords
column21: Which of the following is NOT an example of a cliche?
column23: Total quality management

column9: What is the best tone for a business message?
column11: Professional and respectful
column12: What is another word to describe the personality of a message?
column14: Voice
column15: A review shows that your department is sending more documents with spelling errors than any other department. Which is an appropriate message to send to colleagues?
column17: Colleagues, spelling errors are giving this department a negative image; please spellcheck your documents.
column18: When is the best time for the writer of a message to ask the three key questions 'Why, Who, and What'?
column20: When developing a tone for the message
column21: What is the tone of a message?
column23: The author's attitude towards the reader of the message

column9: Sharing a characteristic or feature with the reader is referred to as _____
column11: commonality
column12: What is the best example of focused language that you would write to connect with an audience?
column14: You alone can reap the benefits by investing in Mostess and achieving a 40% return on your money.
column15: If you research the age, race, income, and lifestyle factors of your potential audience, what are you attempting to do?
column17: Collect demographic data to better tailor your message to audience needs and interests.
column18: Colin has to demonstrate credibility in the information he provides about the company Mostess. In order for the investors to want to invest they have to believe in the company's claims, financial promise and overall reputation. What type of information should Colin include in his appeal?
column20: Confidential information about new product development plans and projected sales revenue for the first five years.
column21: Which of the following is NOT a way to connect with your audience through writing?
column23: Offer many details and a long response.

column9: Do you need to cite a source when paraphrasing information using your own words?
column11: Yes, always.
column12: Plagiarism is...
column14: never acceptable in any form.
column15: What does it mean to plagiarize?
column17: To steal or pass off the ideas or words of another as your own.
column18: When checking for plagiarism, what is the purpose of searching a piece of information in a search engine?
column20: To find the sources which published the information you are using.
column21: Which of the following is NOT a question to ask yourself for determining if you need to cite a source?
column23: Does this sound like it came from me?

column9: Juan was analyzing a business he was thinking of buying. He looked at the daily sales records, the number of unique customers, and the number of repeat customers. He used statistics generated by this data to help him make his decision. What kind of research did Juan use?
column11: Quantitative research
column12: For her research project, Jerri interviewed ten people asking them the same open-ended questions. What type of research did Jerri engage in?
column14: Qualitative research
column15: LaToya looked for patterns and themes in the answers she got from the customers she had visited. What was LaToya doing?
column17: Analyzing qualitative information
column18: Bill completed both qualitative and quantitative research, analyzed the data, and interpreted his findings. What is Bill now ready to do?
column20: Make a recommendation
column21: Implying or inferring certain recommendations is the ability to do what?
column23: Drawing conclusions

column9: What writing skill condenses information and includes detail, while not being concerned about length?
column11: Paraphrasing
column12: What is it called when written information is transferred from the writer's words into a very short summary?
column14: Summarizing
column15: What writing skill takes word for word information from a source and gives credit to the original writer?
column17: Quotation

column21: You spend many hours researching and writing a paper for a class. Accidentally, you leave a draft copy in the library and it is picked up by another student. After you turn your final paper in, the professor does not return your paper with a grade but asks you to see her after class is finished. What is most likely her concern?
column23: You stole someone else's work and portrayed the work as your own when writing the paper.

column9: What does the research method of observation provide for the observer?
column11: People's initial, unbiased reaction to a product
column12: What is a potential downfall of relying on customer surveys?
column14: The rate of response is generally low.
column15: What is the difference between primary and secondary research?
column17: Primary research is a first-hand account, while secondary research comes from research that someone else has already done.
column18: How are inspections different from observations?
column20: Inspections require more active involvement than observations.
column21: What is one potential problem of solely using focus groups as your primary research method?
column23: The viewpoints of the group may not reflect the general public.

column9: What type of primary research is being carried out when an individual asks questions to collect specific facts, opinions, and attitudes?
column11: A Survey
column12: What type of research is being carried out when a researcher interacts with people to obtain facts, opinions, and attitudes?
column14: Primary Data Research
column15: What survey technique is being used when professionals are interviewed about a specific problem?
column17: Executive Survey
column18: What type of survey question encourages an answer phrased in the respondent's own words?
column20: Open-Ended
column21: What type of interview is being carried out when the researcher has apparently informal conversations, not based on set questions, with subjects?
column23: Unstructured interview

column9: Where can the most trusted online sources be found?
column11: Databases and Archives
column12: Why is the information on a Wiki not always reliable?
column14: Because often the information can be changed by the public
column15: How does a reader feel confident that the information in a source is reliable?
column17: The content is current, both sides are presented, and the information has been peer-reviewed.

column20: Finding general information on a topic
column21: Which aspect of a source suggests that it should NOT be used as part of academic research?
column23: One-sided opinion statements are used

column9: How current should an article be in order for it to be reliable?
column11: Less than 10 years old.

column14: Primary sources

column17: An article published in a scholarly journal that was reviewed by other experts in the field.
column18: Which of the following sources is the most reputable?
column20: New England Journal of Medicine
column21: Linda found several journal articles about scientific experiments that produced statistically significant findings. Because of this, Linda can conclude:
column23: Her articles had good research methods.

column9: For which type(s) of reference materials does Google News have indexes?
column11: Newspaper and online news information
column12: Which research material can be found in library databases such as EBSCO?
column14: Academic journal articles
column15: What differentiates academic journal articles from magazines?
column17: They are peer-reviewed.
column18: The topic assigned for your research paper is analyzing the spread of a newly-discovered, communicable air-borne disease. Why might a book NOT be the best source for the number of people currently infected?

column21: What is the most important first step when planning a research paper?
column23: Understanding the assignment

column9: Kevin was instructed to engage in some primary data research on his company's new product. What might Kevin do to be successful in this task?
column11: Conduct a focus group
column12: Jeanne, a local restaurant owner, is conducting a survey around coffee drinking. She concludes her survey with the question: 'Do you think drinking coffee is essential to the start of a good day?' The answer options range from 'strongly agree' to 'strongly disagree.' What type of question is this?
column14: Scaled-response question
column15: Mary Anne wants to know what percentage of parents who shopped at her store had their children ride in the shopping cart. What kind of research would most likely give Mary Anne the information she wants?
column17: Observational research
column18: Which of the following is a form of secondary research?
column20: US Census information
column21: Gail wants to see firsthand how potential customers will respond to her company's new handheld electronic device. What kind of research would most likely give Gail the information she needs?
column23: Focus group

column9: What is one disadvantage to using a visual communication channel?
column11: Visual communication takes a lot of time and money to produce.
column12: Gerald needs to communicate with a large number of people but needs to customize it with relative ease. Which communication channel would be a good choice for Gerald?
column14: Electronic

column17: Oral then written

column20: Oral, Written, Visual and Electronic
column21: In her haste, Kelly sent out an email to customers that was accidentally offensive. Because of this, a large number of subscribers chose to opt out. Analyze the statements below and indicate the one that best describes the problem Kelly's company will have because people chose to opt out?
column23: Kelly's company will need to send out apology emails to the customers who chose to opt out.

column9: Sarah wants to deliver an effective speech. Therefore, she needs to make sure her speech is:
column11: Impactful, clear, and relatable

column14: Values
column15: Why is it important to ensure that you give an audience a chance to respond?
column17: To offer immediate feedback and overcome objections.
column18: Why should a speaker analyze the audience during speech preparation?
column20: To ensure the successful delivery and reception of a message.
column21: In analyzing her audience, Joan noticed that the company that they worked for had recently laid off many workers. What should Joan carefully analyze about her audience because of this?
column23: Their attitudes

column9: What are the Five S's of a goodwill message?
column11: Selfless, Specific, Sincere, Spontaneous, Short
column12: Analyze the statement below and indicate which of the Five S's of goodwill is most represented by it.Â Sarah keeps a stack of thank you notes in her top desk drawer so that when she sees one of her employees doing something outstanding, she can quickly write them a note to show her appreciation.
column14: Spontaneous
column15: If the message is about conveying procedures or instructions, what type of message should be used?
column17: Informative

column20: Jack is congratulated for leading the company in sales for the third straight quarter.

column23: A type of persuasive message.

column9: Prewriting enables a writer to develop a plan for communicating their message effectively. Once you have established a purpose for writing and identified your intended audience, what would you do next?
column11: Gather information and details to assist in writing a complete and accurate technical report.
column12: Why is it important to follow the prewriting, writing and rewriting process when creating a technical document?
column14: To avoid wasted effort and to ensure effective communication with your intended audience.
column15: Why is it important to determine a formatting style during the writing process?
column17: So that you create a user-friendly document that enables readers to locate the information they need.
column18: What steps should one take during the rewriting process?
column20: Add details, delete words, correct grammar and examine the formatting.
column21: Sales of new tablets in your company have declined each of the last three quarters. Management is looking for recommendations on improving sales in the next year, and want specific strategies outlined. What style of organization should you select for writing this report?
column23: Problem-solution, because you will be able to define the problem and present potential solutions effectively.

column9: What should be the intended outcome of a technical document?
column11: The impact you want your document to have on the user.
column12: Why is it important to establish goals before beginning to write a technical document?
column14: To ensure your writing is clear and focused, and that your audience is able to quickly understand your message.
column15: You are writing a manual to train assembly line workers on how to identify and resolve problems with a new robot. It is likely that some types of problems will be experienced with more frequency and severity than others. Where should you include specific, important details about these kinds of problems?
column17: At the beginning of the document.
column18: Why is it important to consider the problem your document is addressing before you begin writing?
column20: To ensure that you clearly address the problem in your document.
column21: What will identifying your audience assist you in doing when writing your document?
column23: Choosing the appropriate words, depth and length of the document.

column9: What is LIKELY the purpose of Technical Marketing Communications?
column11: To persuade an audience of the need for, or to purchase, a product.

column14: The writer must anticipate problems or questions the consumer might encounter and provide solutions.

column17: Traditional technical document
