Besides a webpage, what is another type of technical marketing communication that he might use to spread the word about his new product?
column20: Fliers given to new mothers at a hospital event.
column21: Who is the target audience for an end-user document?
column23: The general public who purchase a product.

column9: Explicit communication:
column11: is straightforward and clear
column12: Implicit communication is:
column14: vague and hard to interpret
column15: Margie works on Roger's team, but she resides in a different state. Margie has been looking forward to receiving her performance review in person when Roger makes a planned trip to her office. He has promised Margie one hour of uninterrupted time. When the performance review meeting takes place, Margie receives praise for her work. However, Roger checks emails on his laptop during their conversation, seems stressed, and has an unhappy look on his face. His behavior is an example of which of the following?
column17: Implicit Communication

column21: Which of the following is an example of explicit communication?
column23: A person who gives a detailed demonstration of a procedure

column9: Which of the following is NOT an area of legal communication?
column11: Research Studies
column12: What is an ability to choose the best ethical path?
column14: Moral agency

column17: They need to minimize the potential damage to stakeholders and the local communities where the stores are located.

Why would they need to provide a disclosure that stated these people were paid product endorsers?
column20: Georgia Baked Chicken needs to be honest with consumers about their business practices.

They want to avoid the problems that McDonald's ran into when they were sued by a customer for burns from their coffee. What type of legal communication will protect them in the event of product misuse or misunderstanding by customers?
column23: Disclaimer

column9: What three factors should a writer consider when examining the rhetorical situation of a document?
column11: The purpose, audience, and context of the document.
column12: What is rhetorical awareness?
column14: Understanding that successfully fulfilling the purpose of your writing is dependent upon your ability to anticipate and address the needs of your audience.
column15: You are writing an instruction manual to accompany an unassembled IKEA desk. What is the BEST way to ensure your manual is user-centered?
column17: By using headlines, bullets, visual aids, and language your audience can understand.

column20: So that the audience is able to understand and apply the information quickly and easily.
column21: What does rhetorical situation refer to in technical writing?
column23: The factors that affect the development of the document.

column9: What is audience-centered communication?
column11: It is when a speaker analyzes the audience to determine the content, language usage and listener expectations.
column12: In preparation for his speech, Jeff is trying to get a better understanding of his audience's point of view on the topic. He is short on time and cannot do as much research as he would like. Of the four things listed below, choose the one that Jeff could skip and still have a good understanding of his audience.
column14: Seat Assignments
column15: Carol is an elementary school teacher who was asked to give a speech to business leaders. Without providing definitions to terms, Carol included phrases and terms like 'differentiated instruction,' 'Bloom's Taxonomy,' and 'Praxis scores.' What did Carol do wrong?

column20: Attitudes are immediate feelings while beliefs are thoughts based on previous experience.

column23: Mutuality, nonjudgmentalism, honesty, and fairness

column9: Kara's supervisor has asked her to write a technical document about the city's water shortage, to be included with residents' water bills. Which of the following titles is best for Kara's document?

column14: Include bold headlines and visual aids to better guide the reader.
column15: What is the subject of technical communications?
column17: Products and services.

column20: David should use an attractive layout, brief paragraphs and sentences, and clear language.

column23: A target audience who will be developing, marketing, or using a product.

column20: The author writes in a way that is clear, concise, and accurate

column23: To make information clear and understandable in order to make business more productive and consumer goods more convenient

column9: Which of the following BEST reflects an example of entrepreneurship?

column9: What are the factors of production?

column9: In a situation with two players, how do we find the optimal solution?

column14: Accounting profit can be positive when economic profit is negative.

The various payments made by the business amounted to $35,000. Calculate the economic profit of Judith's business in its first year.

column21: An opportunity cost that does not require the firm to spend money

column9: What is the formula to calculate per unit cost in a process costing system?

column9: What is product costing?

column15: If the cost-pool for labor has a total of $125,000 and the driver for that pool is 45,000 labor-hours, what is the activity-based costing rate for labor?

column23: a grouping of individual costs associated with the manufacture of goods

column9: How does marginal cost differ from total cost?

column23: An imaginary measure of utility.

column12: How did Crosby define quality?
column14: Quality was conformity to industry or organizational standards.
column15: Which of the following steps is NOT part of Deming's TQM philosophy?
column17: Evaluate
column18: Why did the quality of Japanese automobiles improve after WWII?
column20: Because the automakers adopted the TQM principles promoted by Deming
column21: Which of the following is NOT one of Crosby's Four Absolutes of Quality Management?
column23: Non-conformance to quality standards prevents waste.

column9: Processes and systems are developed during a company's implementation of Total Quality Management (TQM). Which of the following statements best describes these processes and systems?
column11: They are monitored and revised as needed, as they evolve
column12: Which of the following is NOT a reason for a company to implement Total Quality Management (TQM)?
column14: Middle management is not conducive to change at a company that has high customer satisfaction and employee engagement
column15: When a company decides to implement Total Quality Management (TQM), which of the following lists portray the correct order of the steps that are involved?
column17: Determining the company's purpose, vision, mission statement, and objectives
column18: Which type of objectives are considered when implementing Total Quality Management (TQM)?
column20: Objectives in all areas of the business
column21: Total Quality Management (TQM) involves which of the following?
column23: All of the answers are correct

column9: Identify which of the following is NOT a component of an organization's total quality management.
column11: The CEO of a competing company
column12: Why is it important to use various media sources for marketing when a company is in the phase of focusing on the customer?
column14: It helps to improve efficiency as no one really uses just one source of media, like email or texting.
column15: The company you work for wants to develop a strategic approach to improvement. In order to do so, it is considering how all processes in the company function and how to test the quality of their product. Your company is also considering launching a new line of products. Why is this an example of a strategic approach to improvement?
column17: Because they are developing a process to test the quality of their product
column18: An airline has employed an IT company to optimize their web service. In the airline's web service, you can purchase your ticket, as well as check in for your flight and purchase additional luggage space. Which of the following is essential if the company is in the phase of producing quality work the first time?
column20: Monitoring the web service and checking whether the customers are actually purchasing services or just browsing
column21: A large company is having trouble with the IRS because it seems that they have not paid enough taxes. Accounting says that they have done their job right, but that retail failed to disclose all of the new contracts. Retail and acquisition reported that they did all they could have, but that the procedure accounting set up was far too long and filled with needless bureaucracy. Identify the main problem this company is facing:
column23: Not having a strategic approach to improvement

column9: Why do the decisions of middle-level management impact profitability?
column11: Because they are in charge of implementing the strategic plans.
column12: Which of the following best defines productivity?
column14: The relationship between the amount of outputs and amount of inputs needed to produce a product.
column15: Annie is a lower-level manager who oversees daily production and scheduling. Which of the following issues should she watch out for to ensure there is not a negative impact on profitability?
column17: Work stoppage due to faulty production equipment
column18: Tom is a manager at a large firm. He has worked for the firm for a very long time and has spent much of his time focusing on the company's budget. Aside from that, he is also responsible for determining the 10-year goals of the company, one of which, is that every employee needs to have access to healthcare. Why is Tom an example of a top-level manager?
column20: Because he is responsible for designing the long-term company strategy.
column21: How can quality negatively impact profitability?
column23: Quality can only increase profitability.

column9: Your company is trying to determine how competitive it is in the market, and it wants to design the strategic goals of the company. Company A is a company that is just as good as your company, while Company B is a much larger company that can be considered a leader of the industry with far greater revenue than yours. Which company should you compare your company with in the case of best practices benchmarking?
column11: Compare with company B because you want to compare yourself to the leader of the industry.
column12: What do companies use benchmarking for?
column14: Companies use benchmarking as a way to help become more competitive.
column15: John works for a large company that is trying to assess its business through benchmarking. He has been developing surveys and has been told to contact representatives of other companies to seek cooperation. Which stage of benchmarking is John's company in?
column17: Planning and research
column18: How does SWOT differ from peer benchmarking?
column20: SWOT focuses on strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats in the environment while peer benchmarking focuses on organizations of a similar size to yours.
column21: You own a roofing company and wonder how your average prices compare to your competition. You find the average roof prices charged for a 1,500 square foot ranch home and compile the data below. Which of the following is true based on the data you collected?
column23: Your company is priced competitively being both below the average and having only one other company with a cheaper price.

column9: What must be done before a PERT analysis can take place?
column11: Determine the tasks that will be assigned to a particular project
column12: Pessimistic Time is defined as _____.
column14: The maximum possible time required to accomplish a task, assuming everything goes wrong (but excluding major catastrophes)
column15: Joe's supervisor has asked how long it will take for him to finish a project. Joe anticipates a 'best case' scenario of 4 hours, a 'worst case' scenario of 8 hours, and a 'probable' scenario of 5 hours. Using the formula to calculate 'Expected Time', Joe should tell his supervisor the project will take _____.
column17: 5.3 hours
column18: Optimistic Time is defined as _____.
column20: The minimum possible time required to accomplish a task, assuming everything proceeds better than is normally expected
column21: What does PERT stand for?
column23: Program Evaluation and Review Technique

column9: You work in an IT company that, so far, has only produced relatively cheap computers. Your company is trying to decide whether or not to introduce a new line of products. Why would a decision tree be useful?
column11: It would guide you, step-by-step, through the possible choices and the different paths/results derived from each.
column12: If we have an investment of $25,000, and will save $5,000 a year due to that investment, what is the payback time frame in years?
column15: Why are simulations useful?
column17: Because they allow employees to display an emergency scenario without the consequences.
column18: Which of the following best defines payback analysis?
column20: An analysis tool that takes into account investments and anticipated savings or cost increases that will result from that investment
column21: Why do managers use decision-making tools?
column23: To help them choose the best course of action.

column9: Jane, the CEO of a pharmaceutical company, has delegated the task of determining whether the firm should launch a new line of obesity-reducing pills. She instructs her subordinate to 1) assess the firm's current situation, 2) define all of the relevant variables, and 3) focus only on the issue of launching a new line when weighing any risks associated with the uncertainty of the outcome. What was unusual about this approach to weighing risk?
column11: Jane instructed her subordinate to focus on only one issue, without taking a look at the other possible issues.
column12: Which of the following are we trying to determine when we talk about weight risk?
column14: The certainty of a project's outcome
column15: One of the biggest mistakes a manager can make is to _____.
column17: have a sense of certainty and not look at any risk
column18: In which one of the following scenarios did the manager NOT have the proper motivation for making an informed decision?
column20: A manager invests in a firm without research to prove that he does not need to research in order to make a good call.
column21: You run one of the departments in a large company that works in government bonds, futures, and other financial papers. One of your coworkers is being tasked with deciding whether or not to invest in an African country that has had a civil war recently, and has been mostly closed off to the media. What would you advise that he do first as he prepares to make his decision?
column23: Research

column9: A company wants to offer a new line of luxury products. This line is worth at least five million dollars. Which answer represents a potential alternative that the company could pursue instead?
column11: All the answers are correct.
column12: A firm that works in marketing is using the decision-making process to decide on a new PR strategy. They have reached the final stage. What are they MOST likely trying to do?
column14: Implement a weekly system for budget review.
column15: John, a CEO of a company, is trying to fix certain aspects of his company. He started by thinking about what factors prevent the company from growing. He then started developing potential alternatives for his company. Why should John stop and start over?
column17: Because he needed to define his company's problem before doing anything else.
column18: Which of the following is the last step to occur in the decision-making process?
column20: Establish a control and evaluation system.
column21: A department manager is trying to make a decision about a new line of products. He just finished determining limiting factors. What should he do next?
column23: Identify possible alternative strategies for issuing a new line of products.

column9: How are globalization and diversity similar?
column11: They both display trends of the growing integration of culture.
column12: How does technology differ from the other functions of management?
column14: It is by far the function that moves at the quickest pace.
column15: Which of the following is NOT one of the key functions of management?
column17: Innovate
column18: A department manager is perceived by his employees to lack any business ethic. How will that impact his leadership?
column20: Negatively, because he may lose the respect of his employees.
column21: A development team at a large global technology company sells antivirus systems and offers a 10-year warranty for its bestselling water-resistant laptops and mobile phones. The team has just developed a new interactive website to market its products online. Which of the following would most likely be considered an innovation?
column23: The website to market the products

column9: What's the best explanation of the difference between a goal and an objective?
column11: A goal is something that you wish to accomplish in the long-term, while an objective is a short-term goal that helps you accomplish a long-term goal
column12: What step involves you setting goals and objectives?
column14: Action plan development
column15: Which one of the following is not one of the four elements of strategy design?
column17: Prepare your contingency plans
column18: What are the two steps in the strategy formulation process that you must always be taking at every stage of the process?
column20: Environmental scanning and continuous implementation
column21: What does SWOT stand for?
column23: Strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats

column9: A company is performing an analysis of its environment. It has detected that one of its greatest threats is the potential rise of inflation by 3%. The other two factors that impact it are that there might be a change in fiscal policy that will decrease the effective tax rate by 15% and that Republicans might lose their majority in Congress, creating a complicated political climate. Identify which of the factors mentioned are economic factors:
column11: The increase of inflation by 3%.
column12: Which of the following is a possible way to assemble a strategy?
column14: All of these answers are correct
column15: Why do you need to identify key deliverables?
column17: Because they are essential in the monitor and evaluate segment to ensure that everything is on track.
column18: You work in a small company that is currently in the planning process. Which of the following steps will you start with?
column20: Environmental scanning
column21: What are the main components of the strategic management process?
column23: Environmental scanning, assemble a strategy, implement the strategy and monitor and evaluate the strategy.

column9: Why do unions and company management enter into collective bargaining?
column11: To jointly come to agreement on workplace issues.
column12: Sammy Slugger the famous baseball player is having contentious negotiations with his team ownership about what he should be paid next year. The Baseball Commissioner has called for an arbitrator to end the dispute, the arbitrators ruling will be binding. What does this mean for Sammy and the owner?
column14: The arbitrator will determine Sammy's new salary
column15: Sammy Slugger the famous baseball player is having contentious negotiations with his team ownership about what he should be paid next year. The Baseball Commissioner has called for an arbitrator to end the dispute, the arbitrators ruling will be binding. What does this mean for Sammy and the owner?
column17: The arbitrator will determine Sammy's new salary
column18: Which of these best describes the negotiating step of the collective bargaining process ?
column20: The two sides make offers and counteroffers
column21: Which of these best describes the proposal step of the collective bargaining process ?
column23: Management makes an initial offer to the union
column24: Why do most strikes occur ?
column26: Because the union does not feel satisfaction with the negotiations

column9: Non-exempt employees who receive wages are paid _____.
column11: for every hour they work
column12: Stock options are considered _____
column14: a benefit
column15: Mary is an exempt supervisor of the accounting department. She worked 60 hours last week closing the books for month end. How much will she be paid ?
column17: One week's salary
column18: Jonas, the owner of a small engine repair shop, is going to give all of his employees a paid day off on New Year's Eve if profit goals for the year are achieved. This form of compensation is called:
column20: an incentive.
column21: Tom was top salesperson in the department and won a contest. His prize includes: a cash bonus, a small raise in his salary, the ability to buy company stock at a discount price and a slightly more flexible schedule. Identify which of these is indirect compensation:
column23: A slightly more flexible schedule

column9: The CEO of XYZ Corp. will be conducting reviews with his top managers. He has asked them to get feedback from lower level supervisors and outside vendors with whom they work. Which method is the CEO using to review his top managers?
column11: 360 Degree Feedback.
column12: Jill is concerned that her employees are stagnating and not developing their skills as she had hoped. Jill believes that _____ will help the employees assess their work and generate skill development plans.
column14: self assessments.
column15: How would a manager implement Management by Objective (MBO) in her employee appraisals?
column17: By collaborating with each employee on goal setting
column18: Employee appraisals are for _____.
column20: all employees
column21: Top-down appraisals measure employee performance against goals _____
column23: set with 360-degree feedback.

column9: Which of the following is an example of a good question for an exit interview?
column11: Can you summarize in a few sentences whether or not you feel included in the company?
column12: Thomas works in a PR company. The company's manager is not satisfied with his performance and wants to fire him. Why would it be a good idea to try to find an alternative to firing him, such as finding him a new post in the company?
column14: It raises company morale.
column15: What changes should you recommend be incorporated in a written statement of termination?
column17: Adding the termination dates
column18: Identify the first step that is involved in terminating an employee.
column20: Documenting employee performance and behaviors
column21: Why is it important to include a compelling reason for terminating an employee?
column23: It eliminates confusion for the employee.

column9: Who enforces employment discrimination laws relating to hostile work environments?
column11: EEOC
column12: Which of these is NOT an example of a hostile work environment?
column14: Asking a co-worker out on a date
column15: Why is it important to know what makes a hostile work environment?
column17: So employers don't violate the law, employees know their rights, and no one creates a hostile environment
column18: Which of the following do not involve a hostile workplace environment?
column20: The National Labor Relations Act
column21: Which of these is not one of the powers of the EEOC in enforcing employment discrimination laws?
column23: Order an employer to pay an employee damages

column9: Which of the following statements is inaccurate regarding sexual harassment?
column11: It is a form of unwanted sexual advances and may be illegal, but only if it's against the company's policy.
column12: How did the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) impact the Civil Rights Act of 1964?
column14: It helped to not only enforce, but to expand the prevention of discrimination as defined in the Civil Rights Act.
column15: Identify which of the following individuals would NOT be considered a covered employee under the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Title VII:
column17: A young African American male from New York
column18: Which of the following would assist an employer in dealing with an employee's pregnancy discrimination claim?
column20: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC)
column21: A company with 60 employees engages in government contract business and has revenue of $50,000,000. Why is this company subject to policies of affirmative action?
column23: The company has contracts with the government and has more than 50 employees.

column9: What federal law is concerned with data collected electronically?
column11: Electronic Communications Privacy Act of 1986
column12: Which amendment protects federal employees from some types of workplace monitoring?
column14: Fourth Amendment
column15: Which of the following is it generally illegal for an employer to monitor?
column17: Personal computer of the employee
column18: Which of the following are methods that employers use to monitor employees?
column20: All of these options are correct
column21: Employers use workplace monitoring to _____.
column23: All of these options are correct

column9: Ann has interviewed for a job with a new company. She has been informed that a background check will be completed as part of the hiring process. This may involve all of the following, EXCEPT _____.
column11: A review of previous tax returns
column12: Which of the following creates workplace health and safety standards that employers must follow?
column14: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration.
column15: Which of the following is an example of an off-duty act by an employee?
column17: Discussing the supervisor with coworkers in the employee break room.
column18: What type of legal liability does an employer seek to avoid by performing background checks on all applicants?
column20: Negligent hiring
column21: John has discovered that his employer has been monitoring his email account and telephone calls while he's at work. John is very upset, but is told the company has the right to do so because _____.
column23: the communication utilized company equipment

column9: What does employment-at-will mean?
column11: Employers can terminate an employee at any time so long as the reason is not illegal, and an employee can quit at any time and does not need to give a reason.
column12: Which of the following statements is FALSE?
column14: GINA bans discrimination based on an individual's genetic information or physical disability.
column15: An employer can legally retaliate against an employee for which of the following?
column17: None of the answers are correct
column18: Federal laws prohibit employment discrimination based on all of the following, EXCEPT:
column20: Education
column21: Karen feels that she was a victim of discrimination due to her race. How should she handle the matter?
column23: She should file a claim with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC).

column9: Using hands-on training while working alongside an experienced worker is called _____.
column11: unstructured on-the-job training
column12: Juan is a newly hired assembler at Speedy Cellular. He will spend his first week with Juanita, a veteran assembler, who will work side by side with Juan, showing him each step of the assembly process as he assembles the phones. Why is this an example of on-the-job training?
column14: Because Juan is learning his job by performing a specific task or job
column15: In which of the following cases would a company MOST benefit from a job rotation program?
column17: When absenteeism is slowing up the assembly line
column18: Why can job rotation be harmful to the productivity of a company?
column20: Because it can disrupt the workflow as the employee learns a new task or job
column21: Cindi is the newly appointed head of the accounting department. She is receiving training from a mentor and meets with her trainer every day to discuss how the day went and any unusual problems she is facing. Which of the following is NOT an advantage of using this training method?
column23: It hones in on employee interests

column9: Kathleen has a difficult time submitting project objectives and results to her supervisor in a clear and concise format. Her supervisor feels her reports are confusing. In order to improve Kathleen's skills in writing reports, her supervisor might recommend _____ training.
column11: Literacy
column12: Which type of training would MOST likely result in employees becoming more willing to work together and trust their coworkers?
column14: Interpersonal Skills Training
column15: Problem-solving training will teach employees to do all of the following, EXCEPT:
column17: Report results
column18: What are some of the possible benefits to training an employee in the use of new technology?
column20: Self-confidence and skills levels are improved
column21: Diversity training focuses on the recognition of cultural differences and improves the ability of employees to _____.
column23: work effectively with people who are different

column9: What is the purpose for training needs assessments?
column11: They bridge the gap between what is happening now and what needs to happen in the future
column12: Which of these would be a quick action that would aid in keeping current clients?
column14: Send surveys to current clients
column15: A manager finds her employees are unfamiliar with the mission and vision of the organization. What type of training will solve the problem?
column17: Organizational culture training
column18: Which of the following should be reviewed when assessing training needs?
column20: Employee job descriptions
column21: Which of these is a step in the process of assessing training needs?
column23: Take an inventory of what is presently being done

column9: At the beginning of new employee orientation, the employee is told about the company's:
column11: History, code of ethics and purpose
column12: The employee handbook contains information about _____.
column14: Vacation and time off
column15: The benefits to a company that has an effective employee orientation program include:
column17: Lower turnover since employees are less likely to quit
column18: Typical trainings a new employee will receive during new employee orientation include:
column20: How to set up email and computer passwords
column21: The job description includes:
column23: A list of duties and responsibilities

column9: Which of the following is NOT a step used by a human resources manager to determine the best possible fit for a job?
column11: Perform a detailed check of the candidates' regular contacts
column12: Which of the following will provide an employer with relevant information about the candidates, like personal hygiene, timeliness and manners?
column14: Conducting Interviews
column15: An HR manager is trying to determine what qualifications the candidates have in order to best serve the company. It is clear that the CV of several candidates are excellent, and it is now the HR manager's job to decide which of them will be invited to participate in face-to-face interviews. The remaining candidates' information will be stored in a database for possible future opportunities with the company. Why is this an example of application review?
column17: The HR manager is determining which candidates have the qualifications needed for the job
column18: What is the proper course of action when an employer is performing background checks and discovers that a candidate has provided information in his employment application that is untrue?
column20: The employer has grounds to rescind the job offer
column21: Which of the following is the LAST step in the hiring process?
column23: Sending a candidate for a health check.

column9: Which of the following is the difference between downsizing and turnover?
column11: Downsizing is planned while turnover can be unplanned and create gaps
column12: A successful architectural design firm is expanding its business and needs to hire three architects and five project managers in the next two months. The human resources department is already tied up with other critical staffing projects. Which of the following would BEST suit the firm's recruitment needs?
column14: Using an employment agency
column15: Felicia manages the training department. She notices that Adam, the training assistant, is bored performing the same, repetitive tasks and often has idle time throughout the day. Adam's low morale concerns Felicia since he is a good employee. Which of the following actions would BEST address this situation?
column17: Redesign Adam's job responsibilities and tasks
column18: Although downsizing saves a company money in salary and benefits, which of the following can be a disadvantage of this practice?
column20: The remaining employees become overworked
column21: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of promoting internal candidates into new positions?
column23: The promotion creates a gap in staffing

column9: Mark from accounting has prepared a budget that has the salaries of all of the workers, rent and office utilities that are essential to the company, as well as how many products his company expects to sell. Why is this NOT an example of an administration budget?
column11: It shouldn't have how many products his company expects to sell.
column12: Which of the following is usually the first budget?
column14: A sales budget
column15: Which of the following is included in a production budget?
column17: Forecasted unit sales
column18: A manager has reported that he will have to go a little bit off budget in order to be able to order some more office supplies. How will the accounting of the company respond to that?
column20: It won't be a problem because it's only a variance to the budget that should be reported so they can be more accurate next year.
column21: Why is receiving feedback for the budget important?
column23: Because it is important to consult managers on what can be done to increase productivity

column9: Tom works in accounting, and he has to prepare a budget that will take into account all of the activities of the company. There will be a strong investment from the acquisitions department that will impact their budget but is worth less than 2% of the company's value. Should Tom wait for a new report from the acquisition's department?
column11: He should because this is an example of a master budget which is a comprehensive view of the company from a financial standpoint.
column12: Why is financial feasibility an important step in financial planning?
column14: It involves determining whether the potential revenue of a project exceeds its anticipated costs and will increase profits.
column15: Financial planning can best be defined as a process for making sure that _____.
column17: the resources are allocated to maximize profitability
column18: After allocating the resources, a company CEO is trying to control and monitor the acquisition, allocation and utilization of the financial resources. Should the CEO even perform financial control?
column20: She DOES need to because she must ensure that they are done in accordance regulations and with the plan, and for possible SEC reports.
column21: What type of budget provides an estimation of costs and revenue regarding a long-term business venture or fixed asset?
column23: Investment budget

column9: Why can flexible budgeting cause problems?
column11: Everyone might feel their project was most important and want extra money allocated to it.
column12: Which of the following is NOT a function of a budget?
column14: To determine an organization's financial future based on market trends
column15: How does zero-based budgeting differ to top-down budgeting?
column17: Zero-based budgeting doesn't take into account the previous year's performance or actual results, while top-down does.
column18: A CEO of a company and a few members of upper management decided on the budget for the company and have stated there will be no changes in it based on feedback from their subordinates. In which of the following cases is such an action a good idea?
column20: Top-down budgeting may be a good idea because lower-level management does not have the time to prepare the budget.
column21: Why can bottom-up budgeting be a good idea?
column23: Because the lower management can make the plans based on the needs of specific departments.

column9: If your company's assets are $100,000 while it's shareholders' equity is $70,000, what is the value of your company's liabilities?
column12: If the revenue of a company is $100,000, its gross profit $70,000, and its expenses $20,000, what is the company's net profit/loss?
column15: What is the end product of the accounting cycle?
column17: A financial statement
column18: On a balance sheet, assets are equal to what?
column20: Shareholders' equity and liabilities
column21: What is generated by comparing multiple financial statements?
column23: Financial ratios

column9: Mary and Kelly have just started working for a new boss. Mary is unhappy because the new boss is strict and has many new rules. Kelly is optimistic because the office feels organized and has direction now under the new boss. Mary and Kelly have different _____
column11: perceptions.
column12: Tad was tasked with hiring a new sales manager for his team. He had two equally qualified candidates with personalities that seemed alike. However, he found Cathy to be more attractive than Kelly. Tad decided to hire Cathy because he felt she would get along better with the team than Kelly would. Tad's behavior is an example of _____
column14: halo effect.
column15: What does attribution theory suggest about how we assess the behavior of others?
column17: We attempt to determine whether the behavior is caused by internal or external factors
column18: Donald is an office manager. In his youth, he found that other kids of a certain nationality were quarrelsome and hard to get along with. When an applicant from the same nationality applied for an opening in Donald's office, Donald dismissed him because he didn't feel the applicant would get along with existing staff. Donald is using _____
column20: stereotyping.
column21: Joe is a top salesman, something he attributes to his own intelligence, personality and wit. When he recently missed a monthly quota though, he blamed it on new competitors in his territory. Joe is rationalizing his failure by using _____
column23: self-serving bias.

column9: Why is arbitration considered the most aggressive third-party intervention?
column11: Because the decision is binding and cannot be changed.
column12: Jane and Thomas are disputing over methods for advancing their company's image. Thomas wants to use online social media, whereas Jane believes most of their customers are older and should be contacted by mail. A person from outside the company is brought to weigh in on both sides of the argument and move them towards a more constructive dialog. The mediator maintains an impartial stance and keeps extensive notes that she presents to Jane and Thomas to resolve their conflict. Which of these in this scenario is NOT common for mediators?
column14: The mediator keeping written records.
column15: Which of these individuals would focus on understanding the reasons behind a conflict in order to plan a resolution strategy?
column17: A consultant
column18: Why is it sometimes necessary to bring in a third party to resolve a conflict?
column20: Because the parties involved cannot reach an agreement themselves.
column21: How does the role of the facilitator differ from that of the mediator?
column23: The mediator needs to use a hands-on approach, while the facilitator is less involved.

column9: Which of the following is the feeling that is most crucial after collaboration?
column11: That both parties are satisfied without feeling a sense of sacrifice
column12: Which of the following is a profile of a person likely to use accommodation as a conflict management style?
column14: A person with a high need for approval
column15: Which of these conflict management styles attempts to resolve a conflict by finding a middle ground?
column17: Compromise
column18: Jonathan and Sam are employed at a PR company in Boston. Both of them want the company to fund projects they've been working on for the past three years, but senior management has informed them that the company will only fund one of the projects. Which one of the following options best explains why this situation resulted in competition?
column20: The objective of each party was to win at the other party's expense, regardless of the cost.
column21: Mark from the IT sector and Wayne from the accounting sector are supposed to develop a strategy that will accommodate the long-term needs of the company. Mark thinks they need to buy the best computers on the market, while Wayne wants them to pick the cheapest. After an open disagreement, Mark has taken a 2-week leave in order to not have to disagree about the issue again. Which of the following best describes this conflict resolution style?
column23: Avoidance

column9: Organizational communication should be used to communicate which of the following pieces of information?
column11: All the answers are correct
column12: The manager of a company wants to inform his employees that they will not receive a high holiday bonus because revenue is down by 5%. He doesn't want to use formal methods of communication because if the information leaks it would further harm the company's stock, but he is sympathetic towards his employees and wants them to be able to plan their finances. Which method of communication should he use?
column14: The grapevine
column15: Thomas from marketing and James from accounting have been appointed to formulate the company's new PR strategy. They are both heads of a department, and the upper management wants them to cooperate in forming this new strategy. Why is their discussion of a new strategy an example of horizontal communication?
column17: Because they are of the same rank in managerial hierarchy
column18: In which of the following scenarios should external communication be utilized?
column20: When a company wants to communicate with its stakeholders
column21: Mark is not satisfied with how his employer, Johnson Electronics, distributes products to customers. He believes that the process is inefficient and costs far too much. He has some ideas as to how the distributing cost could be decreased. Mark would like to share his ideas with his superiors. Which form of communication is best suited for such a situation?
column23: Upward communication

column9: Why do managers rely heavily on oral communication?
column11: To check for understanding and get immediate feedback
column12: Which type of communication may be related to someone's physical appearance?
column14: Nonverbal communication
column15: Why is interpersonal communication considered to be minimally restricted?
column17: Individuals engaged in it share some level of familiarity with each other
column18: All of the following are types of communication successful managers use EXCEPT:
column20: Tactile communication
column21: How does written communication provide immediacy and economical feasibility?
column23: Messages are communicated quickly and with no travel expenses.

column9: Sender is to encode as receiver is to _____.
column11: decode
column12: The communication process is made up of _____.
column14: sender, channel, receiver
column15: How does understanding occur in a communication process?
column17: When each party can agree on what was being communicated without the need for inferences or assumptions.
column18: A continued dialogue between the sender & receiver is called _____.
column20: a feedback loop
column21: Which of the following illustrates the difference between psychological noise and physiological noise?
column23: Psychological noise refers to things that are going on in your head as you engage in the communication process, while physiological noise refers to things that prevent us from giving our full attention.

column9: Which of the following should a manager consider when communicating in a business environment?
column11: All the answers are correct
column12: Which of the following will likely cause understandable awareness of expectations and performance measurements for all employees?
column14: An open and clear communication climate
column15: Which of the following management functions occurs when a manager reviews and reports job performance and, if necessary, takes corrective and preventive actions?
column17: Controlling
column18: In a company, communication is vital towards achieving _____.
column20: sustained organizational success
column21: A new manager who is very informal has started sending text messages and e-mails to his employees during out-of-work hours when they would like to be with their families. The previous manager and the company itself are very formal and there is usually very little communication between the workers outside of regular working hours and the communication is always face-to-face. Which of the following does the new manager need to conform to?
column23: The cultural norms of the company

column9: Which shift is NOT an example of a compressed workweek?
column11: 9 hour shift for 5 days
column12: Why would Manny the manager consider alternatives to the typical nine-to-five work schedule for his employees?
column14: To help his employees to find a better balance between work and life
column15: How has job flexibility impacted organizations?
column17: It has improved employee performance.
column18: Anna is a full-time customer service representative who works from home. Which of these terms describes the job flexibility option that allows an employee to work the majority of their work hours from home or another remote location outside of the office?
column20: Telecommuting
column21: Aubrey is researching employers that offer telecommuting as a job flexibility option. Which of the following employee characteristics is NOT ideal for a telecommuting?
column23: Low time management

column9: Empowerment is thought to come from the _____.
column11: individual
column12: When employees are empowered there is _____.
column14: increased motivation and job satisfaction
column15: What could Manny the manager do to motivate employees and increase productivity in the workplace?
column17: Encourage participation in decision making processes
column18: To effectively empower employees, employers must do all of the following EXCEPT:
column20: Establish a clear hierarchy
column21: What should Manny the manager NOT do if he wants to empower his employees?
column23: Promote competition between employees

column9: How does job enrichment differ from job enlargement?
column11: Job enrichment provides additional responsibility and authority; job enlargement just adds extra tasks
column12: Maria is a teller at a bank. She was recently given the task of helping customers with the paperwork for opening checking accounts. This is an example of _____.
column14: job enlargement
column15: How might job redesign benefit an employee?
column17: It will make a job more interesting.
column18: Which job redesign strategy encourages respect for coworkers doing other jobs ?
column20: Job rotation
column21: How might job rotation benefit a company?
column23: It provides employees with a broader perspective on how the organization operates as a whole.

column9: Employees who are _____ motivated tend to work at higher levels of productivity and strive to develop professionally.
column11: intrinsically
column12: A company has stated that its organizational goal is to increase customer care quality. David, an employee in the marketing division, has created a new software that helps the company achieve that, and the customers are very satisfied with his work. Why should he be rewarded?
column14: Because he helped the company in achieving its organizational goal.
column15: How do extrinsic rewards differ from intrinsic rewards?
column17: Intrinsic rewards are self-administered, while extrinsic rewards are offered by a supervisor or manager.
column18: Which of the following is an example of an extrinsic reward?
column20: A worker met a sales quota and was awarded a large bonus to his salary.
column21: Thomas is an employee who has helped his IT company increase its revenue by 5% in the first quarter. The company CEO has asked the head of the HR department how they could best provide Thomas with an intrinsic reward. Which of the following is a likely response by the head of the HR department?
column23: You should give him more meaningful work, that might help him be more productive.

column9: Which of the following does NOT occur with goal commitment?
column11: Goals are kept secret
column12: Locke's goal setting theory states that goals should have all of the following elements, EXCEPT:
column14: Ease of attainment
column15: Directing a contractor to lay floor tile in a Versailles pattern with a half-inch grout joint is an example of:
column17: Providing a specific goal
column18: Identify the positive feedback message that provides the most specific feedback that could be used by a manager who follows Locke's Goal-Setting Theory.
column20: The cream filling in the cake you just now made is so smooth and delicious!
column21: When task complexity is high, an employee will be:
column23: More motivated

column9: One week, shortly after her mother's death, Sarah arrives at work an hour late on two different occasions. Considering Sarah's personal circumstances, her manager decides to ignore the behavior in the hopes that it will disappear over time. Sarah's manager is using the _____ technique.
column11: extinction
column12: All of the workers at Ted's Emporium have been shown the cold warehouse where employees who break any of the company rules are sent to work. Just thinking about the possibility of being sent into such a bleak work setting keeps most new employees from even considering breaking a rule. In this situation, management is successfully using the technique of _____ in order to encourage good behavior.
column14: avoidance
column15: Jim's manager catches Jim breaking one of the company rules. He decides that the best course of action will be to take away one of Jim's company privileges as a response. In terms of Thorndike's theory, how is Jim's manager responding to the incident?
column17: He is using punishment in order to decrease the probability of repeated inappropriate behavior on Jim's part.
column18: Which of these techniques is used to reward desirable behavior with the intent of increasing the likelihood that the pleasing behavior will be repeated?
column20: Positive reinforcement
column21: Why would a manager incorporate reinforcement theory in dealing with his or her employees?
column23: In order to influence employee motivation

column9: Identify the three components of expectancy theory.
column11: Expectancy, performance, reward
column12: How would XYZ Corporation implement Vroom's expectancy theory regarding promotions in the company?
column14: By informing employees that promotions are tied to their performance and only promoting the best workers
column15: Which component of Vroom's expectancy theory refers to the level of effort an employee is willing to exert in hopes that the increased effort will result in better performance.
column17: Expectancy
column18: Which person developed expectancy theory?
column20: Victor Vroom
column21: How can Vroom's expectancy theory be used to explain employee motivation?
column23: Once the relationship between effort and reward is linked in the employee's mind, he will work harder.

column9: Based on the equity theory, which of the following is NOT an example of an output?
column11: Employees being flexible and adaptable about their work environment.
column12: Why does the equity theory believe that the number of inputs must be equal to the number of outputs?
column14: Because employees will be more productive if this balance occurs.
column15: One of your employees feels like he is not being treated equally in comparison to other workers. He has not voiced that opinion but is constantly trying to make his work seem better in comparison to others. However, you feel that his work is not as good because he isn't trying hard enough. He just requested a transfer from marketing to PR. Which of the following is a usual behavior that this employee did NOT do when he felt that he was not being treated equally?
column17: Asking for more equitable treatment.
column18: A team designing their company's new marketing strategy has shown loyalty by refusing to accept a job offer from a competing firm. They have shown great knowledge, skill and enthusiasm because they have a belief that they are growing as people within their current job. Which of the following from the above scenario is NOT an input?
column20: The feeling of personal growth.
column21: Who developed the equity theory in 1963?
column23: John Stacey Adams

column9: Tom is the manager of a sales team. Becky is one of his employees with a need for affiliation. What type of work environment would be most beneficial to Becky?
column11: A cooperative team environment
column12: Rachel is applying to business school programs. She has been avoiding schools that do not require an entrance exam, because she thinks the program might not be rigorous enough if they accept too many people. At the same time, she is also avoiding the most elite schools in her area because she is worried those programs will be too challenging. Based on the acquired needs theory, what type of need is strongest for Rachel?
column14: Power
column15: Which of these theories is based on the premise that one's needs are acquired over time as a result of their experiences and includes the needs of achievement, power, and affiliation?
column17: Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs Theory
column18: An individual with the _____ will desire agreement and compliance.
column20: need for power
column21: Phil is a leader within a political campaign. He has recently been named campaign manager because of his ability to coordinate and motivate his team of people. What type of need does Phil likely have?
column23: Need for institutional power

column9: The 'ERG' in Alderfer's ERG Theory stands for:
column11: existence, relatedness and growth
column12: All of the following are true of Alderfer's ERG theory EXCEPT:
column14: It suggests that fulfilling one need lowers the motivation to fulfill another.
column15: Frustration-regression involves:
column17: a tendency to pursue lower-order needs when higher-order needs are no longer satisfied
column18: If Dennis, top producer at a financial firm, breaks his leg, what need from Alderfer's ERG theory would he likely try to satisfy?
column20: Existence need
column21: Ginger just got the promotion she has been after for a very long time. She will be in charge of the entire creative division of her company. What need, according to Alderfer's ERG theory, will be satisfied?
column23: Growth need

column9: _____ cause dissatisfaction in the workplace, are extrinsic to the work itself, and linked to compensation and job security.
column11: Hygiene factors
column12: How did Herzberg develop the two-factor theory?
column14: He interviewed employees to determine what made them feel good and bad about their jobs.
column15: In employee motivation, the opposite of satisfaction is _____.
column17: no satisfaction
column18: _____ are linked to employee motivation and arise from intrinsic conditions of the job itself.
column20: Motivators/satisfiers
column21: According to Herzberg, how can employee dissatisfaction be reduced while at the same time building employee satisfaction?
column23: By finding the right balance between hygiene factors and motivators.

column9: In Tara's performance review, her boss points out Tara's positive ranking when it comes to meeting deadlines for key projects. In terms of organizational goals, why is sharing this information so important in the performance review?
column11: Tara will probably continue to meet deadlines, since employees typically end up repeating behaviors that they receive positive rankings on.
column12: James has read about the Pygmalion effect and hopes that it can be used to enable growth for his employees, which will ultimately strengthen the organization. Which of these is a commonly used way of communicating expectations that James could use to start the ball rolling with his employees?
column14: Performance reviews
column15: Which of these is an example of the Pygmalion effect?
column17: Bob stubs his toe getting into the shower and thinks to himself that it's going to be a bad day. The day does turn out bad.
column18: Sandra's boss has a high opinion of her and believes that she has the potential to some day work in management. Which of the following would NOT be involved in Sandra's experience of the Pygmalion effect based on her boss's expectations?
column20: Sandra would take time to investigate the basis for her boss's expectations.
column21: Which of these terms is considered synonymous with the Pygmalion effect?
column23: The self-fulfilling prophecy

column9: An employee's primary needs include _____.
column11: safe working conditions
column12: According to the needs-based theory of motivation, employees are more likely to be productive if their _____ needs are met.
column14: Primary and secondary
column15: How can employers use the behavior-based theory of motivation to increase worker output?
column17: Set clear goals with the employee and assign clearly defined tasks.
column18: Which of the following is an example of a situation that would satisfy a secondary need?
column20: Getting an assignment where you supervise 10 employees.
column21: Behavior-based motivation says employees can be driven by _____.
column23: opportunities to do meaningful work

column9: Which of the following is NOT correct regarding the attribution theory of leadership?
column11: Assumptions about others' behavior are generally wrong.
column12: Which of the following is an example of the Attribution Theory of Leadership?
column14: A leader sees Frank doing great work and decides he is a great employee.
column15: According to the Attribution Theory of Leadership, there are many ways in which an organization might be negatively impacted by a leader's attributions. How might that organization be positively affected?
column17: Employees could be recognized and accurately placed within the organization based on attributions.
column18: Joe seems on edge and is short-tempered with everyone at work. His boss, Leon, thinks that Joe's behavior is caused by the extreme pressure of recent work deadlines and the current staff shortage. Leon is using _____ to explain Joe's behavior.
column20: external attribution
column21: Jeremy tends to use internal attribution in viewing his employees' behavior. Which of the following would MOST reflect this attribution?
column23: Jeremy thinks that Sarah's snapping at coworkers must be the result of a mental illness.

column9: How does the trait theory of leadership differ from the behavioral theory of leadership?
column11: The trait theory focuses on the characteristics of the leader, while the behavioral theory believes leaders can behave in different ways.
column12: Your team leader has always been a natural communicator. He has performed his job well and he never doubted any of his team members. When working in a stressful environment, he always managed to achieve team coherency. Why is this an example of a trait leader?
column14: Because his traits, such as managing to connect to his team, seem to make him a good leader.
column15: Which of the following is NOT an example of a behavioral theory leader?
column17: An emotional leader
column18: How do democratic leaders significantly differ to laissez-faire leaders?
column20: Laissez-faire leaders are trait leaders, while democratic leaders are behavioral.
column21: Why are there opposing views on how the leadership of an organization should be conducted?
column23: Because of the grave impact on the economy that large companies have.

column9: John, a manager, is leading his team on a new promotional strategy to make the company best positioned for the acquisition of what used to be a very competitive company. He is trying to determine the skills of his workers, and what are their strengths and weaknesses. Why is this an example of role taking?
column11: Because the manager is assessing his employees' skills.
column12: Why is it better to be in the in-group rather than the out-group?
column14: The manager trusts the members in this group and begins to bond with them.
column15: Team members begin working on projects, and the manager begins to see how devoted they are to the work that needs to be done. What is this process called?
column17: Role making
column18: Which of the following is true in regards to Leader-Member Exchange Theory?
column20: Managers expect employees to work hard, be loyal, and trustworthy.
column21: Jane leads a team that is working in the R&D department, where they focus on developing new lines of products for customers. They are pretty used to working with each other more cohesively, and have given up on establishing some basic norms that they follow because they think it is a waste of time. Why is this NOT an example of routinization?
column23: Because there are no established basic norms.

column9: Sue is a law enforcement officer. She is excellent at gaining confessions from suspects through her persuasive personality and questionable interrogation techniques. Where would Sue likely land on the Mach scale?
column11: High Mach
column12: Which of the following characteristic is common in low Machs?
column14: They are highly submissive.
column15: Which type of Mach flourishes in face-to-face settings where there are limited rules and structure, and emotions hold little value in goal achievement?
column17: High
column18: Grant is a high school student who is taking a math test. The teacher had to step out of the room for an emergency and instructed the class to continue silently taking their tests. One of the other students realizes the teacher left the answer key on his desk and begins passing it around. Grant continues to silently take his test and does not look at the answers when they pass his desk. Where is Grant on the Mach scale?
column20: Low
column21: What type of trait is Machiavellianism?
column23: Personality

column9: When a manager gives specific advice, clarifies expectations, and assigns tasks, he is using which leadership style?
column11: Directive leadership.
column12: The manager of a retail store sets a sales goal of over 1,000 pairs of sneakers to be sold in a day, more than any shoe store has ever sold. He rallied the sales team to sell sneakers and encouraged each salesperson during the sales event. This manager was using _____.
column14: achievement-oriented leadership
column15: Path-Goal Theory involves _____.
column17: establishing a supportive plan for goal achievement
column18: Mike is a sales manager who was recently informed of a large account his company will be acquiring this year. He brought this new information up at his monthly meeting so his team could discuss what that might mean for their sales goals this fiscal year. What style of leadership is Mike displaying?
column20: Participative leadership.
column21: A manager that expresses and shows concern for the well-being of weary employees is using _____.
column23: supportive leadership

column9: Juan never worked as a waiter before. He asked his boss to let him take a few tables. He said he was ready to take on the challenge. Which leadership style would be best for Juan?
column11: Selling
column12: Clara is a veteran waitress who knows what to do and enjoys her work and chatting with the customers. Which leadership style would be best for Clara?
column14: Delegating
column15: It is Darla's first day at her very first job at the ice cream parlor. Darla does not know anything about how an ice cream parlor is run. Which leadership style would be best for Darla?
column17: Telling
column18: Follower confidence is:
column20: the degree to which a follower feels comfortable performing a task.
column21: Tara is a very good hairdresser. She was asked to style the mayor's hair today. She refused to do it because she was afraid she may make a mistake. Which leadership style would work best with Tara?
column23: Participating
column24: Follower ability means:
column26: the degree to which the follower possesses skills to perform a task.

column9: The Least Preferred Co-worker ranking system is about:
column11: a manager's tendency to lead a certain way
column12: Larry the leader has a low LPC score. Which situation will he work best in?
column14: Situations where success depends on meeting production goals
column15: Tom is a new graduate just appointed to be supervisor. He walks around with a stopwatch timing how quickly tasks are getting done and suggesting improvements. He does not care to get to know his employees. What kind of situation has Tom created?
column17: Unfavorable
column18: Sarah the supervisor has a high LPC score. How can the regional manager use this in Sarah's job assignments?
column20: By placing her in situations where the ability to make complex decisions is required
column21: Fred the football coach is known as one of the league's best. He explains complex plays in a way that everyone on the team understands. The team members like Coach Fred because he takes a personal interest in each of them and they have confidence that his game strategies will work. Fred has created what type of work situation?
column23: Favorable

column9: Joe was 15 minutes late returning from lunch break today. Jill, his supervisor, tells Joe he must stay 15 minutes extra after work today to make it up. Jill is using _____ power.
column11: coercive
column12: Sam is a sales manager at a car dealership. He is instituting a salesperson of the month program where the top seller gets a plaque to hang on their office wall along with a free lunch. Sam is using _____ power.
column14: referent
column15: The main bases of positional power include:
column17: legitimate, coercive, and reward.
column18: Juanita is a manager at the bank. This morning she advised her staff that she wanted all pending credit applications completed and on her desk for review by 3 PM. Juanita is using _____ power.
column20: expert
column21: A key to a manager's success is the ability to use _____ to influence employee behavior.
column23: a combination of personal and positional power

column9: Mr. Rogers has been promoted to a General Manager position at local real estate agency. He has over 30 years experience and is well respected by fellow agents and former customers. Through the company's mentorship program, he is seen as a father figure to a number of the younger agents. How can Mr. Rogers BEST influence the company's agents to respect his authority?
column11: Through referent power
column12: Which of these power bases is commonly seen in charismatic leaders who are able to invoke a passion for followership due to their magnetic personality?
column14: referent
column15: Which of these power bases is the result of knowing or understanding how to do job-related tasks that subordinates need to know?
column17: expert
column18: Ms. Pauline Powers has been promoted to Divisional Manager at a software development company. Ms. Powers is an internationally recognized expert in the computer language that the company uses. How can Ms. Powers influence her subordinates to respect her authority?
column20: Through expert power
column21: Which type of power is independent from the position a manager holds in an organization and rests solely in the individual in things such as a manager's personality, experience, and special knowledge?
column23: Personal

column9: Tiana is a manager at a software company. She does not concern herself with production or employee needs. The work does not get done, and the employees are miserable. Which type of leader is Tiana?
column11: Impoverished leader
column12: Thomas is a CEO of a large PR company. As a team leader, he believes that _____.
column14: the company must be productive, but it is equally important that its employees are also satisfied with their working conditions
column15: Which of the following is a likely trait of a produce or perish leader?
column17: Authoritarian tendencies.
column18: Which of the following is the most important for a middle-of-the-road leader?
column20: A balanced concern for both production and his employees.
column21: Tom is a manager that allows employees to relax on the job. He often asks questions like, How are you? Is there anything I can do to help? and Are you satisfied with the working conditions here? Why is this an example of a country club leader?
column23: Because he cares about his employees mental state and happiness.

column9: In which of these situations will bureaucratic leadership fail?
column11: When an organization needs to promote change and take risks on a regular basis.
column12: Bureaucratic leadership follows a _____ management philosophy.
column14: it depends
column15: Which of the following scenarios depicts a bureaucratic leader?
column17: Aiden is head of security for a large software company. He is meticulous and carefully handles all security incidents according to the company's policies, rules and procedures.
column18: In which of these situations would a bureaucratic leadership style be most effective?
column20: Samantha supervises an auto service shop. It is her responsibility to ensure the cars her team services are repaired properly and are safe to drive.
column21: Who is considered to have developed the idea of bureaucratic leadership?
column23: Max Weber

column9: Which school of thought produced situational management?
column11: Contingency
column12: Which of the following is NOT an example of situational leadership?
column14: Quentin is a project manager who really admires Abraham Lincoln. He studies Lincoln's leadership style and makes a conscious effort to modify his style to match Lincoln's.
column15: Anne coaches girls soccer. This season she is working with teams from two different age groups, one team is for 8-9 year old girls, and the other is for 14-16 year old girls. How can Anne apply situational leadership based on the capacity of the followers?
column17: Anne could provide more specific instruction to the girls on the younger team.
column18: Mike coaches boys baseball. During practice, Mike spends a lot of time working with each of the boys on specific baseball skills. On game day, however, Mike becomes very directive, giving rapid instructions to the boys. This is an example of situational leadership based on the _____.
column20: situation
column21: According to situational theory, _____.
column23: leaders should adjust their behavior depending on circumstances

column9: Charismatic leaders are good role models because they _____.
column11: exhibit desirable values
column12: All of the following can occur when a charismatic leader has personal motives EXCEPT:
column14: Allowing subordinates to share in the decision making
column15: Charismatic leaders use their _____ to appeal to followers.
column17: passive personalities and kindness
column18: The charismatic leader's influence over others is due to his/her _____ power.
column20: referent
column21: Why are subordinates willing to follow a charismatic leader?
column23: Because of how the leader treats them

column9: Drawbacks of the authoritarian style of leadership include all of the followingÂ EXCEPT
column11: Autocratic leaders are regarded by subordinates as inferior.
column12: Which of the following scenarios best depicts authoritarian leadership?
column14: Arnold does not trust his employees to work unsupervised. He is constantly interfering in their work to make sure things are completed to his standards.
column15: Autocratic leaders have complete control over
column17: decision making
column18: Autocratic leaders
column20: expect their subordinates to trust that they have come to the best possible decision on their own.
column21: Benefits of the authoritarian style of leadership include all of the followingÂ EXCEPT
column23: Autocratic leaders empower their subordinates and are pleasant to work for.

column9: When is the participative/democratic leadership style considered effective?
column11: In a team environment where productivity and efficiency are secondary to quality
column12: Sarita recently transferred to a newly-created learning and innovation department at her company. Her new supervisor leads a team of eight but does all the decision making on new projects. Is the supervisor an effective or ineffective leader and why?
column14: Ineffective; the supervisor does not appear to value his subordinates' input
column15: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a participative/democratic leader?
column17: Focuses on what a subordinate is doing wrong
column18: Employees under a participative/democratic leadership tend to have a high level of _____ and _____.
column20: productivity; job satisfaction
column21: When is the participative/democratic leadership style ineffective in the workplace?
column23: In a deadline-driven environment where speed and efficiency are stressed

column9: Laissez-faire is a French phrase that translates into:
column11: Leave it be
column12: The laissez-faire leader provides their employee with which of the following?
column14: All of these
column15: At which point will the laissez-faire leader intervene in an employee's work?
column17: At the employee's request
column18: Laissez-faire leadership is most likely to be effective with which of the following groups of employees?
column20: A team of experienced landscapers who have worked together for years and enjoy tackling new projects.
column21: Monitoring employees is a critical activity for the laissez-faire leader for all of the following reasonsÂ EXCEPT
column23: it empowers employees by shifting the focus to them and away from the leader.

column9: Which of the following statements is TRUE of philanthropic characteristics in a leader?
column11: It is a testament of character and a requirement of being a true leader
column12: Which of the following is NOT a trait of a servant leader?
column14: Spending more time talking than listening
column15: All of the following are examples of philanthropy EXCEPT:
column17: Feeling good when in the company of others
column18: Pamela is a CEO who makes employees feel special by celebrating and promoting their work activities as well as supporting their professional and personal development. She also treats customers with the utmost care. However, Pamela's behavior toward the company's other executives is dismissive; she does not respect their work ethics. Pamela does NOT exhibit servant leadership because:
column20: Her supportive behavior does not extend to her peers
column21: Which of the following is NOT one of Greenleaf's tenets of leadership?
column23: A real leader ensures his/her own highest priorities are served ahead of others'

column9: After Mario completes his monthly report, his boss reviews it to see if the standards were met. If there are errors, Mario is told he has to work an extra hour each day for the next two weeks. This is an example of which type of management?
column11: Passive management by exception
column12: Wendy's supervisor constantly monitors her performance closely. He scrutinizes her work for potential problems and quickly jumps in to correct her to prevent additional errors. Which type of management is he exhibiting?
column14: Active management by exception
column15: What is most important to a transactional leader when delivering rewards or punishment to subordinates?
column17: Employee performance
column18: Transactional leadership assumes people are motivated by _____.
column20: extrinsic rewards
column21: Which of the following statements about transactional leaders and the chain of command is FALSE?
column23: Chain of command promotes employee dependence which decreases accountability

column9: How is vision central to a transformational leader's goal?
column11: Before anyone can follow a leader, they need to have an idea of where they are going and why through vision.
column12: Which of the following scenarios depicts intellectual stimulation?
column14: Whenever John's team is beginning a new project he holds brainstorming sessions, and encourages them to propose new, creative ideas for completing the project.
column15: The transformational leader uses individualized consideration, intellectual stimulation, charisma, and _____ to convince employees to transcend their personal interests for the sake of the larger organization.
column17: idealized influence
column18: What sets the transformational leader apart from many other leadership styles is their ability to influence others to follow them through all of the following, EXCEPT _____.
column20: extrinsic rewards
column21: The transformational leader uses _____ to control how they are viewed by their followers.
column23: impression management

column9: A leader who influences employees to conceptualize the future state of the organization is _____.
column11: setting a clear vision
column12: A leader can BEST motivate employees by _____.
column14: learning about the employees' needs and wants and recognizing their good work
column15: How do informal and formal leadership roles differ?
column17: Personality traits are more important in informal leadership roles
column18: The CEO of a large company tells his employees what he expects them to do to increase revenue in the next quarter. He specifically explains an algorithm he purchased which should help their company. He gives his employees details on how to use the algorithm and he has a comprehensive list of assignments for them. How is this an example of guiding employees?
column20: The CEO is providing clear instructions on using a new tool in addition to clarifying everyone's role in the process
column21: The membership representatives at a health insurance company have been working hard during a particularly stressful open enrollment. The manager decides to throw a catered lunch for the employees because _____.
column23: it's a gesture of appreciation for their hard work, which helps build morale

column9: How does the lack of any conflict impact the work environment?
column11: It may expose conformity and lack of diversity.
column12: Thomas and Jane are working on a proposal for a new PR strategy for their company. Thomas believes that they should focus on TV ads, while Jane believes they should focus on the world of social media because most other forms of communication are outdated. Identify the kind of conflict in this situation and the reason behind it.
column14: It is a task conflict, because they are proposing alternative methods to achieving the same goal.
column15: Two coworkers are having a dispute about how to achieve the goal of their company, which is to introduce the most competitive product in the smart phones industry. In the heat of the argument, one of the workers calls the other a lazy good-for-nothing. Why is this an example of a people conflict?
column17: Because it was a personal insult not relevant to the task.
column18: Which of the following is a major source of people conflict in teams?
