column20: Perceived inequality
column21: How does a perceptual set of beliefs, values and attitudes influence the behavior of people?
column23: Each individual interprets factual situations in a different manner, which can lead to conflict.

column9: What is a preventative measure that can be taken to reduce the chances of groupthink?
column11: All the answers are correct.
column12: Which of the following describes the likely outcome of decisions shaped by groupthink?
column14: They have a low probability of success
column15: The king of a small country wants to go to war. Everyone agrees with him in an attempt to gain his favor, even though they would be attacking a much larger nation. This an example of:
column17: groupthink
column18: Groups that experience groupthink disregard _____ in order to maintain harmony in the group.
column20: alternatives
column21: Groupthink occurs:
column23: When a group makes faulty or ineffective decisions for the sake of reaching a consensus.

column9: Which of these terms is used to describe a sequence of planned activities aimed at improving teamwork to increase group cohesion and effectiveness?
column11: team building
column12: Which of these terms describes the degree to which group members come together as one unit to reach a common goal?
column14: group cohesion
column15: Which type of team building is aimed at improving the specific teamwork skills which group members need to accomplish their goal and can be immediately applied in the workplace?
column17: skills-based team building
column18: Which of these is not considered a characteristic of cohesive groups?
column20: members hold hidden agendas
column21: Which type of team building is used to increase the understanding of who each group member is and how to better communicate with one another?
column23: all of these

column9: Which of these stages represents the time when the group becomes a cohesive unit, morale is high and members actively acknowledge the talents, skills and experience that each member brings to the group?
column11: norming
column12: Which of these stages represent the time characterized with anxiety and uncertainty when the group is just starting to come together?
column14: forming
column15: Jamal, Antonio, Lorraine and Sasha have been assigned to work together on a software development project. Their first few meetings went well. They established a rough schedule for the project and assigned responsibilities for the key tasks. Now, however, their meetings seem to be unproductive and filled with conflict. Sasha and Jamal are continually arguing about which part of the software should be developed first, and Lorraine keeps asking about who is going to present the project plan. Which stage of development is this group in?
column17: storming
column18: Jennifer, Eric, Gabriel and Maria are working together to develop a marketing plan for one of their company's newest product lines. After some initial conflict, the group started to really come together. Now, the group is highly unified and very productive. The marketing plan is practically writing itself! Which stage of development is this group in?
column20: performing
column21: Which of these stages is used to wrap up activities of the group and provide a sense of closure to its members?
column23: adjourning

column9: Why do organizations use work teams?
column11: Work teams offer the benefit of combined experiences, ideas and opinions
column12: Vivian works in housekeeping at a resort hotel. She manages the laundry division and has three dozen valets and laundry attendants reporting directly to her, in addition to six contracted tailors and furniture upholsterers. Why is this a functional work team?
column14: The team members all perform tasks specific to the function of the department
column15: How do functional teams differ from self-directed teams?
column17: Members of self-directed teams have significantly more authority than those in functional teams
column18: Which of the following is NOT a type of work team common in contemporary organizations?
column20: Self-directed team
column21: Howard is vice president of media relations. Keisha is a senior web developer in marketing. Both are part of a team of high-level employees from various departments that will determine how best to present the company's new line of products to the public. Although each team member has authority over company policy, there is no designated group leader. Why is this a cross-functional team?
column23: Each member is expected to cross train in the others' areas of expertise

column9: Why is having a suitable organizational structure important for the company?
column11: It will allow the company to implement proper operating procedures and decision-making processes.
column12: Why is the mechanistic structure often referred to as a bureaucratic structure?
column14: Because the organization has a formal network
column15: Why is it impossible to institute standardized processes and procedures in an organic structure?
column17: Because of the uncertainty of organic organizations
column18: Which of the following is a characteristic of a mechanistic structure?
column20: Individualized job specialization
column21: A state university has a system where most of the decisions are made by the top level of management and the subordinates are not supposed to question them. There are no complex decision-making processes that involve multiple parties and most of the communication goes from the bottom toward the top. Why is this NOT a common mechanistic structure?
column23: Because most of the communication goes from the bottom toward the top

column9: Why is the team organizational structure utilized?
column11: To break down functional barriers among departments to strengthen working relationships and improve efficiency.
column12: Robert works in a large informational technology company that uses a matrix structure. Joanna is his manager in the programming department. Tristan leads the project that Robert is currently working on. Robert reports to which of these individuals?
column14: Both Joanna and Tristan.
column15: What does the organizational matrix structure focus on?
column17: The use of cross-functional teams.
column18: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of a network organizational design structure?
column20: Increased employee retention
column21: Which type of organizational design structure keeps the core functions of the business internal while outsourcing non-core functions to third parties?
column23: Network

column9: What's another name for a divisional organizational structure?
column11: M-form
column12: Which of the following best describes a divisional organizational structure?
column14: An organization that is divided into semi-autonomous units
column15: Which of the following is not an advantage of a divisional structure?
column17: It's always cheap
column18: Which one of the following companies was one of the first to use of a divisional structure?
column20: General Motors
column21: Which one of the following is not a disadvantage of a divisional structure?
column23: Divisions are semi-autonomous

column9: Sales and marketing, finance and accounting, customer service, and human resources are a few examples of groupings within which organizational design type?
column11: Functional
column12: All of the following are traits of the simple organizational design structure, EXCEPT:
column14: High departmentalization
column15: Why are functional structures used by an organization?
column17: To have specialized work units that maximize functionality.
column18: Why is a divisional design structure used?
column20: To create several semi-autonomous units that focus on a narrow sector of business.
column21: How does having a top-level executive impact divisional structures?
column23: It makes them more successful by ensuring that someone who has authority is available at all times.

column9: Why should you NOT generalize when linking elements of organizational structure to employee performance and satisfaction?
column11: Everyone is different: some people prefer high specialization and centralization, while others prefer it to be low.
column12: The structure of an organization can impact the organization's members in which of the following ways?
column14: All of the answers are correct.
column15: Which statement captures the downside to a high level of work specialization?
column17: A high degree of work specialization can lead to a low level of job satisfaction by some individual members of an organization.
column18: Of the six elements of organizational structure, how many can be shown to be consistently tied to employee performance and behavior?
column21: Which statement is NOT true regarding centralization in organizational structure?
column23: A high level of centralization results in participative decision-making among organizational members, which is positively linked to a high level of job satisfaction.
column24: Why is structure so important to an organization?
column26: Organizational structure helps to define roles and expectations for employees.

column9: How does a mechanistic structure differ from an organic structure?
column11: The organic structure is usually far less formal and departmentalized
column12: How does organizational strategy affect organizational structure?
column14: An organizational strategy is crucial to developing and implementing a viable organizational structure
column15: A small business sells computers directly to customers. It does not incorporate excessive innovation and spends little on advertising. The environment at the company is very informal and could best be described as organic. Why is this NOT a common cost minimization strategy?
column17: There usually is a strong hierarchy in a cost minimization strategy
column18: An IT company focuses on copying and mass-producing computer hardware that is similar to successful devices developed by companies that follow an innovation strategy. Which of the following structures would best suit the IT company's strategy?
column20: Both the mechanistic and organic structure
column21: Why does an organic structure work best for an innovation strategy?
column23: This combination encourages input and decision-making by all members of the organization

column9: In a centralized organization, policies and procedures are usually _____.
column11: uniform
column12: Span of Control is:
column14: the number of employees a manager can feasibly oversee
column15: How can centralized authority be a disadvantage?
column17: Decision-making can be very slow.
column18: How are orders transmitted in a centralized organization?
column20: From top management down
column21: Marcy gets orders to work on clients from her supervisor. When her supervisor is away and an important decision needs to be made, Marcy is authorized to make it. Marcy works _____.
column23: under decentralized authority

column9: Which of the following is synonymous with work specialization?
column11: Division of labor
column12: _____ refers to an organization's practice of assigning individual tasks into separate jobs.
column14: Work specialization
column15: Fred has chosen to implement work specialization at his expanding recycling company. What could he do to prevent a negative outcome?
column17: Develop methods to facilitate clear communication and build a sense of teamwork to prevent isolation
column18: Which of the following businesses would BEST benefit from work specialization?
column20: An umbrella manufacturer
column21: What is one potential outcome for an organization utilizing work specialization?
column23: Low morale due to limited interaction and collaboration

column9: Amy works in a company that has had a very casual environment for years. Now she has to sign her name both electronically and on paper prior to submitting any work and she feels that this change is completely unnecessary. Identify which of the following factors motivates her resistance to change:
column11: Lack of understanding why an additional process was needed
column12: Approximately 70 workers are employed at an IT firm called Johnson Incorporated. All of these workers are used to checking in with their supervisors five minutes before starting to work. In case an employee has a good idea, he doesn't have to worry about channels but can go straight to the CEO. The environment is very casual here. Why are these things examples of organizational culture?
column14: Because they reflect basic shared norms, beliefs and values of Johnson Incorporated.
column15: Which of the following is a useful tactic after deciding on a change?
column17: Involve staff in every step of decision-making
column18: Which of the following does an organization have full control over?
column20: The number of customers that will regularly purchase their goods and services
column21: An advisory board of a multinational company is trying to assess the main challenges that the company will have to overcome in the next five years. Amongst them, they have listed these: dismissing fears regarding globalization, trying to predict the fluctuations of the stock market, and keeping up with the technological requirements of the industry. What do all of these goals have in common?
column23: They are all examples of external changes.

column9: Why did Senge include personal mastery as one of his five disciplines?
column11: Because individual workers need to have something to focus energy on and personal professional goals provide this
column12: Which of these is NOT considered to be a benefit of becoming a learning organization?
column14: Promotes additional competition between internal employees
column15: Sam's Gear is a very traditional organization that manufactures camping equipment. Stellar Trek is a learning organization that also manufactures camping equipment. How might the two organizations vary in their approaches to an economic slow down in a way that CLEARLY demonstrates their organizational difference?
column17: Sam's Gear might continue manufacturing their best selling line of gear, while Stellar Trek might create a new line in response to changing consumer desires.
column18: Which of these answers BEST describes a learning organization?
column20: One in which organizational members are constantly learning from everything they do.
column21: How did Peter Senge help to popularize the idea of learning organizations?
column23: Through the publication of his book, The Fifth Discipline

column9: Lauren held a staff appreciation luncheon to inform her employees that existing clients' feedback on phase one of the new skincare system and pricing structure was overwhelmingly positive. Why is this an example of the sixth step of the change model, generate short-term wins?
column11: The manager publicly recognized employees with evidence their efforts are paying off
column12: Which of the following does NOT occur during step seven of Kotter's 8-step change model, consolidate gains to produce more change?
column14: Creating a team tasked with kick starting the change
column15: Which of the following actions would a manager take to empower broad-based action?
column17: Immediately address any barriers to keep the change process moving
column18: Why would an organization use Kotter's eight-step change model?
column20: To implement transformational change in the organization
column21: As CEO of his company, Mack seeks to use Kotter's 8-step change model to make a comprehensive organizational change to improve efficiency and boost the company's sagging profits. As part of the first step, he outlines a program he believes will revive the business in six to nine months. What aspect of the first step in the change model did he miss?
column23: He didn't foster a sense of urgency by helping employees realize that their jobs depend on their support of the changes

column9: In which of the following steps of Kotter's change model does management take time to paint a picture of what the organization's future will look like after the change has taken place?
column11: Develop a vision and strategy
column12: Which of the following steps in Kotter's change model involves inspiring the necessary teamwork, ideas, and eagerness to make sacrifices relating to the change?
column14: Create the guiding coalition
column15: During a major change initiative, management discovers that there is not enough understanding about the change itself and there is a lack of strong project management for the change. These types of obstacles would be dealt with in which of the following steps in Kotter's change model?
column17: Empowering broad-based action
column18: Which of the following steps in Kotter's change model involves monitoring the acceptance of change and how well the organizational culture is adapting to the change?
column20: Anchor changes in the organization's culture
column21: Which of the following steps in Kotter's change model involves the change leader selecting and recruiting a team of individuals who will be capable of carrying out the change?
column23: Create the guiding coalition

column9: When stating the problem, it is important to:
column11: define the current and future state
column12: The first step in the force field analysis involves:
column14: stating the problem
column15: Driving forces are interested in:
column17: causing change
column18: Equilibrium is:
column20: balance of power
column21: Which of the following influences both driving and resistant forces?Â 1. peopleÂ 2. habitsÂ 3. customsÂ 4. attitudes
column24: Resistant forces:
column26: want to maintain the status quo

column9: Which stage of Lewin's model is used to create an awareness of how the status quo, or current level of acceptability, is hindering the organization in some way?
column11: Unfreezing
column12: Which step did Lewin find to be especially important to ensure that people do not revert back to their old ways of thinking or doing prior to the implementation of the change?
column14: Refreezing
column15: During which stage of Lewin's model does reinforcing, stabilizing, and solidifying the new state after the change occur?
column17: Refreezing
column18: During which stage of Lewin's model do employees learn the new behaviors, processes and ways of thinking?
column20: Changing
column21: Which of the three stages make up Lewin's change model?
column23: Unfreezing, changing, refreezing

column9: Identify the business situation that will require an urgent change plan.
column11: The profit for HS company Ltd has decreased by 75% over the last 2 years.
column12: Which of these steps in the planned change process provides the objective or expectation of how a change will respond to whatever forces are driving the need for change?
column14: Develop change goals.
column15: How is the effectiveness of a change plan evaluated?
column17: By comparing the actual results against change goals to determine if the goals were achieved.
column18: Why is it desirable to appoint a change agent who is outside of the company?
column20: Because of the expertise and unique abilities that the change agent possess to drive change.
column21: Which of these steps in the planned change process puts the change plan into action?
column23: Implement the change.

column9: Which of the following is NOT a reason why employees resist change?
column11: They fear the status quo.
column12: How does organizational change impact a company?
column14: It restructures the company in a way so that it is completely transformed.
column15: A large company is trying to implement an organizational change. The company is trying to switch from primarily door-to-door operations to internet sales. They feel the changing marketplace requires that they adapt and have invested over $10,000,000 into this transition. The company's labor unions have organized strikes and the workers are threatening to resign. Why did the change fail?
column17: Because the employees refuse to accept the change.
column18: How do external factors differ to internal factors?
column20: Internal factors are things like company policies or procedures, while external factors are things over which the company has very little influence on.
column21: A company is trying to force a change by letting their employees know they will be fired if the organizational change fails. They have also stated that the entire change must happen at once and have tried to communicate to the employees why the change was necessary. Did company management perform any of the right steps to overcome employee opposition to change?
column23: Company management tried to communicate the importance of the change to the employees.

column9: An IT company has decided that you no longer need to report to your supervisor before you make minor changes to software. Instead, you can now simply post the minor change on the company's community forum. Why is this an example of a structural change?
column11: Because there is a change in the administrative procedures
column12: Which of the following changes occur as a result of structural, strategic, people, and process changes in an organizational environments?
column14: Internal
column15: How should the external environment of a company impact its strategy?
column17: It should be monitored, and at times even the company's fundamental approach to business may be altered due to it.
column18: ABC Corp wants to improve employee performance, skills, attitudes, behavior and loyalty to the organization. What type of changes should they make?
column20: People changes
column21: How does process change differ from strategic change?
column23: Process change is based on everyday operations, while strategic focuses on long-term goals.

column9: Which term describes the act of monitoring the organization's internal and external environments for early signs that a change may be needed?
column11: Environmental scanning
column12: ABC Company manufactures various electronic items for sale in an online market. Recently, sales have dropped off and, after doing some research, the management team discovers that an upstart company is selling to a portion of ABC's long-standing customer base. In response, ABC's management elects to launch a new marketing strategy to rebuild its customer base. This action represents _____.
column14: changing for the external environment
column15: The following are representative of an organization's external environment EXCEPT _____.
column17: the ability to attract good employees
column18: The following are representative of an organization's internal environment EXCEPT the _____.
column20: availability of product manufacturing materials
column21: To remain competitive in the marketplace, Mary and her leadership team conducted a SWOT analysis to develop new strategies. This analysis could include studying all of the following EXCEPT:
column23: tactics within the company's external environment

column9: Speedy Cellular is implementing a Kaizen program for the assembly department. The assemblers will be asked to _____
column11: remember that department management gets the credit when quotas are achieved.
column12: Why did Japanese business leaders feel the need to develop and implement the process known as TQM?
column14: Its economy was a shambles after World War II and needed rebuilding.
column15: When a university implements TQM to improve the quality of classroom instruction, which of these would be an output?
column17: student achievement on standardized tests
column18: The head of Acme Tools and Plumbing, Jordy McClellan, decided to solve a customer complaint problem by conducting company-wide customer service training. The goals were to improve the process and transform the culture of the company to revolve around serving customers. Which aspect of Total Quality Management (TQM) did Mr. McClellan use?
column20: Reengineering
column21: The foundation of Total Quality Management (TQM) is based upon a continuous thought process that involves the entire purchase experience. Which of the following is NOT part of that process?
column23: Company profits

column9: When looking at the external environment, companies typically look at
column11: Technology, politics, competitors, economy
column12: Define contingency planning.
column14: If you want to run a business effectively, for any period of time, you must be prepared for emergencies or disruptions that relate to how your business runs.
column15: Mary is an analyst for a bank. Every month she reviews company reports and goes online to search for potential threats and opportunities that may affect the bank in the future. Mary is performing which aspect of contingency planning?
column17: Environmental scanning
column18: A fruit packing company in Florida makes plans for what it will do in the event a hurricane strikes. This is called _____
column20: disaster recovery planning.
column21: Which of these would be part of the implementation of contingency management at XYZ Corp.
column23: A willingness to change plans based on circumstances

column9: Which of the following products is most likely produced in a company that utilizes a closed system?
column11: A space satellite
column12: How does a failure in one part impact the system as a whole?
column14: It renders the rest of the system unusable.
column15: What does entropy cause in a business system?
column17: A discord or a lack of predictability, a gradual decline into disorder.
column18: Why do companies mostly use the same system throughout the world?
column20: Because the system is part of how the company functions.
column21: The board of an IT company is discussing their new business strategy to increase sales by 30%, although they are satisfied with the current number of products they have. Based on customer surveys that shows a demand for a longer battery life for their top product, an expensive mobile phone, they have added a much stronger battery to their product. Why is this an example of an open system?
column23: Because they are paying attention to customer demands.

column9: How does the operations management of today differ from the time of Henry Ford and his assembly line?
column11: It is a lot more complex today as companies used to be focused only on production, while today they are more oriented towards the quality of the product.
column12: Which of the following is relevant in regards to capital requirements?
column14: How much machinery you need to implement a project.
column15: Jane is a company CEO. She heard rumors that the accounting division is very unproductive because many of her employees do not have their talents utilized in the best manner, and there is constant infighting. What aspect should Jane focus on to improve the productivity there?
column17: Human capital
column18: John's company is starting a new product line to increase their revenue, and make themselves more famous in the general public. They are trying to make the production process as efficient as possible by analyzing every step and making sure it doesn't waste needless time. Why is this an example of process planning?
column20: Because they are trying to make sure the production process is as effective as possible.
column21: Which of the following is NOT an integral part of business?
column23: Controlling

column9: What is classic management theory?
column11: Finding the best possible way for employees to perform their tasks
column12: A manager in an IT company is trying to decide whether to focus on producing very expensive computers or cheap laptops at affordable prices. Before making his decision, he is interested in knowing more about the analysis of data and the past, present and future trends of both the market and his company. Which of the following should he use to make his decision?
column14: Management information systems
column15: Behavioral aspects are considered in _____.
column17: both classic management theory and the quantitative school of management
column18: Which of the following is considered only by the quantitative school of management?
column20: Analysis of data using statistical models and simulations
column21: The top level of management of a company which produces old-fashioned furniture is not satisfied with its productivity. It has hired a consultant who specializes in systems management theory to take a look at the manufacturing process. A factory worker has described the process as: taking a quality piece of pine or maple and subjecting it to a process where specialised equipment is used to transform it into a table which they then ship to the customer and request a survey response of his satisfaction about the product. Which of the following is the output of the process?
column23: The specialized equipment

column9: Which option best matches the systems approach?
column11: Focus on data, processes and products that, when put together, make a whole unit.
column12: Which option best matches the contingency approach?
column14: Use different approaches or systems for different situations
column15: Which of these choices best matches the quantitative approach?
column17: Use statistics and mathematical techniques to analyze data.
column18: How is the quantitative approach better for management, as opposed to the systems approach?
column20: Neither approach is better or worse, as each has a place and situation where it might be better or worse. Additionally, they can be merged and blended.
column21: An approach solely reliant on statistics and data is _____
column23: Quantitative

column9: Mary allows her employees plenty of leeway in how they do their jobs and expects them to motivate themselves to be high achievers. She sets the standard by coming in early and working as hard as they do. The self fulfilling prophecies predict that her employees _____
column11: will motivate themselves and achieve the goals she sets.
column12: Joe thinks that his workers hate their job and only come to work to earn their paychecks. However, he is satisfied with their creativity and imagination when they work on projects. Is Joe a typical Theory X manager?
column14: No, because he believes in their creativity and imagination.
column15: Which of the following is credited with the development of the Theory X and Theory Y?
column17: Douglas McGregor
column18: Rebecca runs a research department with specific goals for new product ideas. She lets employees work on their own new product ideas every Friday with little supervision. Rebecca is practicing _____ management.
column20: Theory Y
column21: Mike is a Theory X manager. Which of these does he assume about his employees ?
column23: They would rather be told what to do instead of directing themselves

column9: What does a manager need to provide in order to satisfy his employees' physiological needs?
column11: Comfortable working conditions, reasonable work hours, and the necessary breaks to use the bathroom and eat and/or drink.
column12: Which of the following is necessary in order to satisfy Maslow's safety needs?
column14: Having job security and receiving a salary
column15: Which of Maslow's five needs can a manager fulfill by providing challenging work, inviting employees to participate in decision-making, and giving them flexibility and autonomy in their jobs?
column17: Self-actualization needs
column18: Each of the following answer choices represents the fulfillment of one of Maslow's needs. Identify the answer choice that represents achieving the HIGHEST need on Maslow's Hierarchy pyramid.
column20: Tom started working at 8:00. At 8:15, his team-leader told him that the work he had recently done was excellent and he said if Tom kept up with the good work he would surely be promoted very soon.
column21: You are working for a large international company. One of your project proposals raised the revenue of your department by 5%. Your boss said, You are an exemplary employee and your work ethic and efficiency is at such a level that the entire company should strive towards it. Which of Maslow's five needs would your boss's comment satisfy?
column23: Esteem needs

column9: How would a modern day manager best implement what was learned in the Hawthorne Studies?
column11: Show employees they are valued by being available and supportive
column12: How did the Hawthorne Study of five women in a bank writing room change perceptions about what motivates workers?
column14: They showed that motivation improved when workers were shown attention by observers.
column15: Which two researchers are most commonly associated with the second Hawthorne Studies experiment?
column17: Mayo and Roethlisberger
column18: Which term describes a psychological phenomenon in which participants in behavioral studies change their behavior or performance in response to being observed?
column20: The Hawthorne effect
column21: How did the Hawthorne Studies affect thinking about management theory?
column23: Social and human relations aspects became part of management theory.

column9: Which of the following is a factor that can help increase employee motivation?
column11: Positive feedback and appraisals.
column12: How does the theory of classical leadership management differ from the behavioral management theory?
column14: Classical leadership focused only on high production and efficiency, while behavioral management theory focuses on worker satisfaction.
column15: Which of the following is NOT an intrinsic motive for working?
column17: Salary
column18: Why was Mayo's Hawthorne experiment relevant to behavioral management theory?
column20: Because it proved that there was increased productivity if the workers felt the management was interested in their well-being.
column21: A manager is trying to motivate his employees because company productivity is declining. He decreases their benefits by 10%, and awards them tasks he knows they will find boring. Employees are told that their position is safe, and they can advance if they start working harder. He declares the only goal is increasing company revenue, and that common values are not important to the company. Which of these was a good move based on the behavioral management theory?
column23: Ensuring workers that their position is safe.

column9: Why was the neoclassical theory of management developed?
column11: Because classical theories were deficient by not accounting for the human side of production
column12: Which of these describes the focus of neoclassical management theory?
column14: the best way to motivate, structure, and support employees
column15: According to the Human Relations Movement, which of these would increase employee productivity?
column17: Making employees feel valued by taking care of their social and human relations needs
column18: According to Neoclassical Management Theory, managers are encouraged to do which of these?
column20: Make working conditions more efficient and create supportive social systems
column21: How would a manager implement the ideas of the behavioral movement into her workplace?
column23: By rewarding the best employees with more responsibility and promotions

column9: What is the best reward an informal group can offer a new member?
column11: It provides the social status not offered by the formal organization.
column12: Effective organizations, according to Barnard, are those that _____.
column14: have no concern for employees
column15: Marge, a manager, makes it a point to join in with the informal group's lunchtime conversation at least once per week. She lets them know they are valued and doing important work. Why is it important that Marge do this ?
column17: It will help get the informal group to accept her formal authority.
column18: Formal organizations are _____.
column20: structured by hierarchy, rules, and policies
column21: According to the acceptance theory, managers have authority when _____
column23: they can legitimately give orders and have a legitimate expectation that the orders will be carried out.

column9: How would Amy implement people oriented management in her beauty salon?
column11: By setting the weekly schedule jointly with her staff
column12: How would a pizza restaurant illustrate group network management?
column14: Cooks, cashiers, and delivery people all contribute to the goal of satisfying each customer.
column15: Which of these is NOT a result of successful group interaction?
column17: Better management control
column18: Mary Parker Follett's concept of management and the idea of employees working together to make decisions is known today as _____ leadership.
column20: participative
column21: When there is positive collaboration between employees who are socially attracted to one another, who have shared goals and a unique identity that set them apart from others, it is called _____.
column23: group interaction

column9: As Jane goes about her duties as an administrative style supervisor at XYZ Corporation, she thinks of herself as _____
column11: a professional

column15: Jane and Thomas are disputing over methods for advancing their company's image. A person from outside the company is brought to weigh in on both sides of the argument and move them towards a more constructive dialog. The mediator maintains an impartial stance and keeps extensive notes that she presents to Jane and Thomas to resolve their conflict. Which of these in this scenario is NOT common for mediators?
column17: The mediator keeping written records.
column18: Why is it sometimes necessary to bring in a third party to resolve a conflict?
column20: Because the parties involved cannot reach an agreement themselves.
column21: How does the role of the facilitator differ from that of the mediator?
column23: The mediator needs to use a hands-on approach, while the facilitator is less involved.

column9: Why do most strikes occur ?
column11: Because the union does not feel satisfaction with the negotiations
column12: Which of these best describes the proposal step of the collective bargaining process ?
column14: Management makes an initial offer to the union
column15: Sammy Slugger the famous baseball player is having contentious negotiations with his team ownership about what he should be paid next year. The Baseball Commissioner has called for an arbitrator to end the dispute, the arbitrators ruling will be binding. What does this mean for Sammy and the owner?
column17: The arbitrator will determine Sammy's new salary
column18: Why do unions and company management enter into collective bargaining?
column20: To jointly come to agreement on workplace issues.
column21: Which of these best describes the negotiating step of the collective bargaining process ?
column23: The two sides make offers and counteroffers

column9: How did organized labor change during the Progressive Era?
column11: It improved with passage of The Clayton Act, which permitted labor unions.
column12: How did The National Labor Relations Act help organized labor?
column14: It gave workers the right to form unions, collectively bargain, and strike.
column15: What were the workers guilty of according to the verdict in the Cordwainer's Case of 1806?
column17: Interfering with labor markets and destroying competition
column18: How does being blacklisted hurt a worker?
column20: If you are blacklisted, it is illegal for you to work.
column21: Which of the following was a cause of the decline of union membership and influence in the United States?
column23: Globalization and cheaper labor overseas

column9: Mary is an exempt supervisor of the accounting department. She worked 60 hours last week closing the books for month end. How much will she be paid ?
column11: 60 hours at her salaried rate
column12: Stock options are considered _____
column14: direct compensation.
column15: Jonas, the owner of a small engine repair shop, is going to give all of his employees a paid day off on New Year's Eve if profit goals for the year are achieved. This form of compensation is called:
column17: an incentive.
column18: Non-exempt employees who receive wages are paid _____.
column20: for every hour they work
column21: Tom was top salesperson in the department and won a contest. His prize includes: a cash bonus, a small raise in his salary, the ability to buy company stock at a discount price and a slightly more flexible schedule. Identify which of these is indirect compensation:
column23: A slightly more flexible schedule

column9: Jill is concerned that her employees are stagnating and not developing their skills as she had hoped. Jill believes that _____ will help the employees assess their work and generate skill development plans.
column11: self assessments.
column12: Top-down appraisals measure employee performance against goals _____
column14: set by management.
column15: Employee appraisals are for _____.
column17: all employees
column18: The CEO of XYZ Corp. will be conducting reviews with his top managers. He has asked them to get feedback from lower level supervisors and outside vendors with whom they work. Which method is the CEO using to review his top managers?
column20: 360 Degree Feedback.
column21: How would a manager implement Management by Objective (MBO) in her employee appraisals?
column23: By collaborating with each employee on goal setting

column9: Which of the following would assist an employer in dealing with an employee's pregnancy discrimination claim?
column11: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC)
column12: A company with 60 employees engages in government contract business and has revenue of $50,000,000. Why is this company subject to policies of affirmative action?
column14: Any company that engages in government contract business is subject to affirmative action.
column15: How did the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) impact the Civil Rights Act of 1964?
column17: It helped to not only enforce, but to expand the prevention of discrimination as defined in the Civil Rights Act.
column18: Identify which of the following individuals would NOT be considered a covered employee under the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Title VII:
column20: A middle-aged white male from New Jersey
column21: Which of the following statements is inaccurate regarding sexual harassment?
column23: It is a form of unwanted sexual advances and may be illegal, but only if it's against the company's policy.

column9: Felicia manages the training department. She notices that Adam, the training assistant, is bored performing the same, repetitive tasks and often has idle time throughout the day. Adam's low morale concerns Felicia since he is a good employee. Which of the following actions would BEST address this situation?
column11: Redesign Adam's job responsibilities and tasks
column12: A successful architectural design firm is expanding its business and needs to hire three architects and five project managers in the next two months. The human resources department is already tied up with other critical staffing projects. Which of the following would BEST suit the firm's recruitment needs?
column14: Using an employment agency
column15: Although downsizing saves a company money in salary and benefits, which of the following can be a disadvantage of this practice?
column17: The remaining employees become overworked
column18: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of promoting internal candidates into new positions?
column20: The promotion creates a gap in staffing
column21: Which of the following is the difference between downsizing and turnover?
column23: Downsizing is planned while turnover can be unplanned and create gaps

column9: According to Adam's Equity Theory, how should a manager lead his/her team?
column11: Be sure to compensate employees reasonably for the work that they do
column12: According to David McClelland's Achievement Motivation Theory, which of the following is NOT considered an employee need?
column14: Safety
column15: The manner in which an employee responds to a work request depends on his/her _____.
column17: Level of motivation
column18: How should a manager lead his/her team according to McClelland's Achievement Motivation Theory?
column20: Be cognizant of which employees have which needs, and create ways for employees to fulfill their needs
column21: John Stacey Adams's equity theory is centered around the concept of _____.
column23: Fairness

column9: According to Maslow's hierarchy of needs, Harold, who is motivated and rewarded for his hard work, finds his needs met at the _____ level of the pyramid, while Rob, who just has a job for employment, finds his needs met at the _____ level of the pyramid.
column11: physiological; self-actualization
column12: After their annual performance reviews, Stacy tells her coworker, Rachel, her new salary. Rachel is furious to find out that Stacy, who has only been at the company for one year, is now making just as much money as she is because Stacy is always gossiping instead of working. Rachel's reaction is an example of which motivational theory?
column14: Equity theory
column15: Which of the following is NOT a way for managers to ensure that their employees are motivated?
column17: Pay employees in identical jobs the same regardless of performance.
column18: Gina works on a team that has recently experienced a lot of turnover. She has been volunteering to work extra hours and has offered to train the temporary employees who have been brought in to help. Although Gina wants to support her manager through this difficult time, she is expecting to be rewarded for all of her extra effort. This is an example of:
column20: Expectancy theory
column21: Which of the following is an outcome of highly motivated employees in the workplace?
column23: Increased sales

column9: An employee's primary needs include _____.
column11: safe working conditions
column12: How can employers use the behavior-based theory of motivation to increase worker output?
column14: Set clear goals with the employee and assign clearly defined tasks.
column15: According to the needs-based theory of motivation, employees are more likely to be productive if their _____ needs are met.
column17: Primary and secondary
column18: Behavior-based motivation says employees can be driven by _____.
column20: opportunities to do meaningful work
column21: Which of the following is an example of a situation that would satisfy a secondary need?
column23: Getting an assignment where you supervise 10 employees.

column9: Which of the following best describes Abraham Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs theory of workplace motivation?
column11: It is made up of five tiers that motivate human behavior, ranked from the most basic to more complex needs.
column12: Why should managers make it a point to understand motivation?
column14: So they can understand the factors that lead employees to perform at a higher level and increase the performance of their entire departments.
column15: Katherine is a recruiter who extends an offer of employment for an IT manager position at her company to Walter. Walter says that he is pleased to have the opportunity to have a chance at a management roll, but he will be unable to take the position unless he is given another week of vacation in his offer. The additional vacation time that he is requesting is an example of _____.
column17: a form of direct compensation
column18: Which of the following BEST describes the type of motivation and level in Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs when an employee goes to work because he is 'driven to succeed'?
column20: Intrinsic, self-actualization
column21: What is the basis behind Frederick Herzberg's Two-Factor Model of workplace motivation?
column23: There are certain factors of an employee's job that are associated with satisfaction and different factors that are associated with dissatisfaction.

column9: How does quantitative data differ from qualitative data?
column11: Quantitative data tells you how much data there is.
column12: Historical/past data allows a manager to _____.
column14: make an informed decision when planning for the future.
column15: What is raw data?
column17: The Data page of a report from your Management Information System
column18: What are management information systems?
column20: The computer information available to a company and the system that it resides in.
column21: How would you define qualitative data?
column23: Data gained through a personal inspection or viewing of a problem or issue.

column9: In a Gantt chart, which of the following include smaller, more intricate tasks that need to be completed as part of a larger task?
column11: Terminal elements
column12: How can the Gantt chart be beneficial to an organization?
column14: It makes it easy for others to understand the individual work tasks and their due dates within a greater project deadline.
column15: Which of the following are made up of terminal elements in a Gantt chart?
column17: Summary elements
column18: Who is responsible for creating the Task and Bonus System?
column20: Henry Gantt
column21: According to the Task and Bonus System, an employee _____.
column23: Should not be paid an hourly salary until they are proficient in their job

column9: Optimistic Time is defined as _____.
column11: The minimum possible time required to accomplish a task, assuming everything proceeds better than is normally expected
column12: What does PERT stand for?
column14: Program Evaluation and Review Technique
column15: Joe's supervisor has asked how long it will take for him to finish a project. Joe anticipates a 'best case' scenario of 4 hours, a 'worst case' scenario of 8 hours, and a 'probable' scenario of 5 hours. Using the formula to calculate 'Expected Time', Joe should tell his supervisor the project will take _____.
column17: 2.8 hours
column18: What must be done before a PERT analysis can take place?
column20: Determine the tasks that will be assigned to a particular project
column21: Pessimistic Time is defined as _____.
column23: The maximum possible time required to accomplish a task, assuming everything goes wrong (but excluding major catastrophes)

column9: Business _____ are the day-to-day activities that entail running the company in order to make a profit and meet other business-related goals.
column11: operations
column12: Which of the following is NOT one of the steps in the strategic planning process?
column14: Product testing
column15: Danisha is a manager at a furniture manufacturing company. She is currently planning employees' schedules and deciding which positions they will cover on the factory line. What type of planning is Danisha engaged in?
column17: Operational planning
column18: Why is a company's decision to build a new facility considered a strategic decision?
column20: It is a substantial investment of time and capital.
column21: What is the difference between strategic and tactical planning?
column23: Strategic planning involves the big picture, while tactical planning determines the resources needed to achieve strategic objectives.

column9: Annie is a lower-level manager who oversees daily production and scheduling. Which of the following issues should she watch out for to ensure there is not a negative impact on profitability?
column11: Work stoppage due to faulty production equipment
column12: Tom is a manager at a large firm. He has worked for the firm for a very long time and has spent much of his time focusing on the company's budget. Aside from that, he is also responsible for determining the 10-year goals of the company, one of which, is that every employee needs to have access to healthcare. Why is Tom an example of a top-level manager?
column14: Because he is responsible for designing the long-term company strategy.
column15: Which of the following best defines productivity?
column17: The relationship between the amount of outputs and amount of inputs needed to produce a product.
column18: Why do the decisions of middle-level management impact profitability?
column20: Because they are in charge of implementing the strategic plans.
column21: How can quality negatively impact profitability?
column23: When the quality is lower than the quality standard.

column9: How does the operations management of today differ from the time of Henry Ford and his assembly line?
column11: It is a lot more complex today as companies used to be focused only on production, while today they are more oriented towards the quality of the product.
column12: Which of the following is NOT an integral part of business?
column14: Controlling
column15: John's company is starting a new product line to increase their revenue, and make themselves more famous in the general public. They are trying to make the production process as efficient as possible by analyzing every step and making sure it doesn't waste needless time. Why is this an example of process planning?
column17: Because they are trying to make sure the production process is as effective as possible.
column18: Which of the following is relevant in regards to capital requirements?
column20: How much machinery you need to implement a project.
column21: Jane is a company CEO. She heard rumors that the accounting division is very unproductive because many of her employees do not have their talents utilized in the best manner, and there is constant infighting. What aspect should Jane focus on to improve the productivity there?
column23: Human capital

column9: Which option best matches the systems approach?
column11: Focus on systems then the quality, then the answer.
column12: Which of these choices best matches the quantitative approach?
column14: Use statistics and mathematical techniques to analyze data.
column15: Which option best matches the contingency approach?
column17: Use different approaches or systems for different situations
column18: How is the quantitative approach better for management, as opposed to the systems approach?
column20: Neither approach is better or worse, as each has a place and situation where it might be better or worse. Additionally, they can be merged and blended.
column21: An approach solely reliant on statistics and data is _____
column23: Quantitative

column9: The company you work for wants to develop a strategic approach to improvement. In order to do so, it is considering how all processes in the company function and how to test the quality of their product. Your company is also considering launching a new line of products. Why is this an example of a strategic approach to improvement?
column11: Because they are developing a process to test the quality of their product
column12: Why is it important to use various media sources for marketing when a company is in the phase of focusing on the customer?
column14: It helps a company reach potential customers.
column15: A large company is having trouble with the IRS because it seems that they have not paid enough taxes. Accounting says that they have done their job right, but that retail failed to disclose all of the new contracts. Retail and acquisition reported that they did all they could have, but that the procedure accounting set up was far too long and filled with needless bureaucracy. Identify the main problem this company is facing:
column17: Lack of inter-departmental cooperation
column18: Identify which of the following is NOT a component of an organization's total quality management.
column20: The CEO of a competing company
column21: An airline has employed an IT company to optimize their web service. In the airline's web service, you can purchase your ticket, as well as check in for your flight and purchase additional luggage space. Which of the following is essential if the company is in the phase of producing quality work the first time?
column23: Monitoring the web service and checking whether the customers are actually purchasing services or just browsing

column9: What is the name of a learning laboratory that offers a space for individuals to learn about communication skills, interpersonal relations, individual personality theories, and group dynamics?
column11: T-groups
column12: Which theorist is referred to as the 'father of scientific management'?
column14: Kurt Lewin
column15: Terry has just been promoted to supervisor of production at ABC Manufacturing. To improve production, he begins his first day by explaining to his employees he will be watching them very closely and dock their pay if they are not on task at all times. Is he following McGregor's Theory X or Theory Y, and why?
column17: Theory X; he is assuming his employees will not do their jobs correctly and goof off.
column18: How can a business positively affect the extrinsic motivation of their employees?
column20: Employers can provide increases in salary, a better work environment, promotions, and terminations to affect their employees' extrinsic motivation.
column21: What is one of the main challenges to organizational behavior theory and practice?
column23: Technology and tools

column9: Why is the team organizational structure utilized?
column11: To break down functional barriers among departments to strengthen working relationships and improve efficiency.
column12: Robert works in a large informational technology company that uses a matrix structure. Joanna is his manager in the programming department. Tristan leads the project that Robert is currently working on. Robert reports to which of these individuals?
column14: Nobody; a matrix organization means there is no hierarchy.
column15: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of a network organizational design structure?
column17: Increased employee retention
column18: What does the organizational matrix structure focus on?
column20: The use of cross-functional teams.
column21: Which type of organizational design structure keeps the core functions of the business internal while outsourcing non-core functions to third parties?
column23: Network

column9: Why is a divisional design structure used?
column11: To create several semi-autonomous units that focus on a narrow sector of business.
column12: How does having a top-level executive impact divisional structures?
column14: It makes them more successful by ensuring that someone who has authority is available at all times.
column15: All of the following are traits of the simple organizational design structure, EXCEPT:
column17: High departmentalization
column18: Sales and marketing, finance and accounting, customer service, and human resources are a few examples of groupings within which organizational design type?
column20: Team
column21: Why are functional structures used by an organization?
column23: To have specialized work units that maximize functionality.

column9: Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between organizational structure and organizational design?
column11: Organizational structure is the formal lines of authority and power, while organizational design is a formal process of integrating information, technology, and people to achieve objectives.
column12: How might new organizational design strategies negatively affect an organization's culture?
column14: Employees who are content with the status quo may resist innovation that may affect the company's competitive edge.
column15: How is decision-making impacted when individuals work for a large organization?
column17: They have less input in decision-making.
column18: Patricia works for a company that manufactures DVD players. The company is experiencing a decrease in profits since most consumers who were interested in purchasing a DVD player have already done so. Patricia's company is in which of the following stages of the organizational life cycle?
column20: Decline and death
column21: Don works for a major healthcare system in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Recently a patient was admitted for treatment who was diagnosed with the Ebola virus after returning from a trip to West Africa. Don's hospital is now in the process of training all of its staff on the proper procedures for donning personal protective equipment and notifying the proper government agencies when treating these types of patients. This is an example of a change to organizational design due to _____.
column23: environmental factors

column9: What are two elements of organizational design?
column11: Plan and process
column12: How do heterarchy and responsible autonomy differ from other organizational designs?
column14: The designs do not have strict hierarchies of authority.
column15: What type of organizational design has minimal job specialization, few layers of management, decentralized decision-making and not much direct supervision?
column17: An organic organization
column18: The Sarbanes-Oxley Act requires the chief executive officer and the chief financial officer be responsible for the reporting of financial statements. How would this affect the organizational design of a company?
column20: These external regulations create a hierarchy of authority
column21: Referring to organizational design, the acronym PARC stands for:
column23: People, architecture, routine, and culture

column9: How can division of labor lead to increases in efficiency?
column11: It makes the best use of employees specialized skills through organization and cooperation.
column12: Karen is a new, non-management employee. She is the only one in her department who has received training on a new software program. The rest of her coworkers are now looking to her for guidance. What type of authority is Karen displaying?
column14: Informal
column15: Why might a decentralized model of authority be advantageous for an organization?
column17: People at the ground level often have better information about the tasks or issues at hand.
column18: Walt is an IT manager who works for a large financial institution. When he needs to implement a coding change, he must first send an email to Linda, his supervisor. She then seeks approval from Mike, the Department Vice President. Mike presents the change request in a meeting with the change review board, ultimately sending the request to a Quality Control Manager for final sign-off. What is the name of this organizational structure?
column20: Hierarchical
column21: Which of the following statements best describes organizational management?
column23: The process of planning, structuring, and directing the resources and members of an organization to achieve the goal.

column9: Which of the following under the 5 P's of Leadership theory addresses how the leader fits into the organization?
column11: Position
column12: Which of the following statements was the basis of the Great Man (or woman) theory prior to modern research on leadership?
column14: Individuals are essentially born to be good leaders.
column15: Is a leader always the individual who is in the highest ranked position?
column17: No, because an employee with long tenure who is well-respected may have more power than an official leader.
column18: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the 5 P's Leadership model?
column20: Each dimension is used individually to judge whether a leader is good or bad.
column21: What is the difference between a leader's purpose and his product?
column23: A leader's purpose is the desired outcome, while a leader's product is the actual outcome.

column9: What style of leadership is generally associated with the CEO of a Fortune 500 company?
column11: Authoritative
column12: Which characteristic is most strongly associated with a situational leader?
column14: The ability to adjust their leadership style when interacting with individual employees.
column15: Under which of the following conditions is a bureaucratic style of leadership most likely to be utilized?
column17: When managing a large governmental entity such as the Department of Commerce.
column18: Susan is a manager who uses a hands-off approach that allows her subordinates to perform their duties without having to consult with her constantly. She believes in hiring well and allowing employees to work independently. What leadership style does she embrace?
column20: Laissez-faire
column21: Participative leaders are very likely to display which style of communication in their interactions with others?
column23: A willingness to openly communicate and involve others in the decision-making process.

column9: Charismatic leadership style refers to the ability of a leader to _____.
column11: influence others through his/her behaviors
column12: Charismatic leadership style refers to the ability of a leader to _____.
column14: influence others through using his/her position of power
column15: Which of the following is an example of the traditional leadership style?
column17: A leader asking staff for input about a decision that will affect their entire business unit.
column18: Which of the following phrases best describes the concept of transformational leadership?
column20: Interactions between management and employees are encouraged to determine if changes need to be made.
column21: Which of these is an example of new leadership theory?
column23: A leader who encourages and motivates employees by using a positive and exuberant attitude.

column9: Adam is a CEO of a major healthcare organization. He is typically calm, cool, and collected and likes to take the time to evaluate all of his options before making a decision. When Adam went to work on Monday, he was faced with survivors being brought in from three different traumas (a plane crash, a high-rise fire, and a multi-vehicle accident). He was forced to become more authoritative and to quickly delegate tasks to some of his more senior staff, such as setting up a mobile trauma unit in one of the parking lots. This is an example of what leadership theory?
column11: Trait
column12: According to the Behavior theories, some leaders focus on people-oriented behaviors, and other leaders are centered on _____.
column14: task-oriented behaviors
column15: The _____ leadership theory is often criticized for its simplicity and exclusion of other factors.
column17: Trait
column18: The _____ theory can be used as a tool by companies when making hiring decisions.
column20: Trait
column21: Richard Branson, the founder of the Virgin Group, is known for having the ability to help his followers to be able to look at old problems in new ways. He also pays attention to his followers' needs while inspiring them to put forth additional effort in order to achieve the goals of the group. Richard Branson is an example of a _____ leader.
column23: transformational

column9: Which of the following is a characteristic of a task-oriented leader?
column11: staying accountable for assigning work
column12: Task-oriented leaders are more likely to take control of a process because they _____.
column14: want to find the best resources and people to complete the activity.
column15: The degree to which one is either task-oriented or people-oriented is referred to as one's _____.
column17: leadership orientation
column18: How do people-oriented leaders try to focus their employees?
column20: By focusing on the needs of the employees in the work process.
column21: Which type of leader is concerned with making employees happy by supporting, developing, and accommodating them?
column23: servant-oriented

column9: How is Management by Objective (MBO) BEST defined?
column11: Managers and employees collaborate to set objectives; their collective buy-in increases the organization's success.
column12: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of Management by Objective (MBO)?
column14: A company's stock increases in price.
column15: Which of the following was established by Peter Drucker's Management by Objective (MBO) concept?
column17: It started the practice of management listening to employees, and marrying that with the thoughts and ideas of management.
column18: Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding the role of employees in the Management by Objective (MBO) process?
column20: Employees are able to benefit financially by purchasing stock in the company.
column21: Which of the following is NOT part of the Management by Objective (MBO) process?
column23: Management has the final say on the company's objectives.

column9: The CEO of a large company tells his employees what he expects them to do to increase revenue in the next quarter. He specifically explains an algorithm he purchased which should help their company. He gives his employees details on how to use the algorithm and he has a comprehensive list of assignments for them. How is this an example of guiding employees?
column11: The CEO is providing clear instructions on using a new tool in addition to clarifying everyone's role in the process
column12: How do informal and formal leadership roles differ?
column14: Personality traits are more important in informal leadership roles
column15: A leader who influences employees to conceptualize the future state of the organization is _____.
column17: motivating employees
column18: A leader can BEST motivate employees by _____.
column20: learning about the employees' needs and wants and recognizing their good work
column21: The membership representatives at a health insurance company have been working hard during a particularly stressful open enrollment. The manager decides to throw a catered lunch for the employees because _____.
column23: it's a gesture of appreciation for their hard work, which helps build morale

column9: How should the external environment of a company impact its strategy?
column11: It should be monitored, and at times even the company's fundamental approach to business may be altered due to it.
column12: How does process change differ from strategic change?
column14: Process change is based on everyday operations, while strategic focuses on long-term goals.
column15: Which of the following changes occur as a result of structural, strategic, people, and process changes in an organizational environments?
column17: Internal
column18: An IT company has decided that you no longer need to report to your supervisor before you make minor changes to software. Instead, you can now simply post the minor change on the company's community forum. Why is this an example of a structural change?
column20: Because there is a change in the administrative procedures
column21: ABC Corp wants to improve employee performance, skills, attitudes, behavior and loyalty to the organization. What type of changes should they make?
column23: People changes

column9: Why is it important for companies to evaluate managerial decisions using a SWOT Analysis?
column11: It analyzes strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and time.
column12: The first steps management should consider determining the feasibility of a new project or expansion project is to determine:
column14: Internal strengths and weaknesses.
column15: Jessica has just conducted a SWOT analysis of her firm. What should her next steps be?
column17: Making sure that weaknesses are offset by the strengths and threats are turned into opportunities.
column18: Why is a unique selling proposition important for a company?
column20: It is something that a company is very good at, but their competition is not.
column21: Why is environmental scanning used in marketing?
column23: To analyze the overall marketing environment, including the economy, political, and technological changes.

column9: How are strategic, tactical, and operational plans related to each other?
column11: Operational plans are necessary to fulfill tactical plans, which lead to achievement of strategic plans.
column12: Why is a tactical plan relevant for the functioning of each company?
column14: Because it deals with the responsibility and functionality of lower-level departments.
column15: A procedure that details how to take an inventory is an example of a(n) _____ plan, while a promotional advertisement is an example of a(n) _____ plan.
column17: strategic, tactical
column18: Managers use operational plans to _____.
column20: regulate the day-to-day affairs of each department.
column21: Why do managers create contingency plans?
column23: In case the original plan fails to produce the desired results

column9: Pick the answer choice that represents an example of organizing:
column11: Tom is a project manager at an IT company and is determining how he should distribute resources and allocate roles.
column12: Sylvia is a manager at an accounting services firm. She is designing a four-step process based on the functions of management, which include:
column14: Planning, organizing, leading, and controlling
column15: _____ is often called the fifth function of management. It involves the evaluation, recruitment, selection, training and placement of individuals in specific job roles.
column17: Staffing
column18: Daniel manages a team that has missed their production goals for the past three months. After reviewing each employee's performance record, Daniel adjusted the sales goal to take additional quality control measures into consideration. Why is this an example of controlling?
column20: Because Daniel looked at team results and took appropriate corrective action.
column21: Matthew manages a mobile phone retail store. He has set a specific sales goal for his team to achieve by the end of the month. Matthew created a detailed action plan to help reach the sales goal. Which managerial function has Matthew performed?
column23: Planning

column9: You're a novice teacher and expect your supervisor to show you how to create more effective lessons. In order for this to occur, your boss will need to possess _____.
column11: technical skills
column12: At what level are technical skills in a manager most important?
column14: Bottom-level management
column15: Which skill set do top-level managers need in order to see the 'big picture?'
column17: Goal setting
column18: Shirley the shop clerk is upset about the longer hours she must work during the holiday season. She really would prefer to have extra time off. column9: Drafting a memoIn this assignment you are required to write a memo using the scenario provided below:Scenario:You are a Sales Manager at XYZ Shoes Corporation. There is a company sales meeting scheduled on October 1, 2019. The meeting is to discuss the company's sales performance and annual targets. This meeting is compulsory for all sales staff and each member must bring their own sales results forecast for the next 3 months.TaskYou must draft a business memo to advise all sales staff of the meeting. In this, you must advise them of the reason for the meeting, that attendance is compulsory and let them know what they need to prepare and bring to the meeting. You will need to decide where the meeting should take place and at what time.Assignment tips:You may use today's date as the date in your memoUse your own words and do not copy and paste any of the language in the scenarioRemember to revisit your personal notes and learning resources about business writing to help you complete your assignment
column11:
To: Sales Department 

From: Somansh Goenka, Sales Manager

Date: September 15, 2019

Subject: Sales Performance and Annual Target

The company has scheduled a meeting to discuss the sales performance and the annual target of the company.

All the staff members are asked to bring their own sales results forecast for the next 3 months as all the stats will be analyzed in order to make better decisions for the company, so it becomes compulsory for all the members in the sales department to attend this meeting.

The venue and timings are given below;
Venue: Conference room no.7 
Timing: 10 AM to 2 PM.

If you have any queries, please let me know.
Thank you,
Somansh Goenka

column9: Now it's your turn!Proofreading PracticeHere is a sample business email with spelling, grammar, accuracy and clarity errors.Â Your task is to rewrite the email and correct the errors that you found (you can use any online tool that you want).Subject: Quote for Tree RemovalDear Mr. Smith;I have appraised the proposed job of removeing the dead oak tree on your property at 665 Lorain Avenue in Cleveland, OH: After inspecting the site in person and assessing the tree, a quote has been developed for your reveiw.Use of crane to remove all dead branches - $1,000 Chipper to take care of all debris - $500 Removal of trunk - $200 Grind the stump - $200 Labor and cleanup - $200 Total = $2,100This quote includes more than everything listed above, guaranteeing of leaving the yard nice and clean, with the same condition as before the job. All parts of the tree will be removed from your property the stump will be ground up and the hole filled with mulch.If this is exceptable to you, please give me a call at 216-554-2343 so we can schedule a date for this job. Thank you for your time.Sincerely.Lamar JohnsonOwner Affordible Tree Inc.Useful Hints:SpellingThere are 4 spelling errors in that email. See if you can find them and produce the correct spelling.PunctuationThere are 5 punctuation errors in that email. Three involve misuse of punctuation, and two are missing commas. Try to find and fix each one.Dangling ModifierThere is one dangling modifier. Remember, a modifier is a word or phrase that describes something else in the sentence, usually a noun or pronoun. A dangling modifier occurs when that noun or pronoun is missing from the sentence. Thus, it is unclear who or what is being described. Can you find the dangling modifier in this email? How can you fix it?Long SentenceThere is one sentence in this email that is too long. It causes some confusion in the message of the email. Find that sentence and determine how to shorten it.Key PointsIt is often useful to use bullet points or numbered lists to help summarize or structure key information. There is one area where a bulleted list would be helpful in this email. Find that section.
column11:
Subject: Quote for Tree Removal

Dear Mr. Smith,

I have appraised the proposed job of removing the dead oak tree on your property at 665 Lorain Avenue in Cleveland, OH. After inspecting the site in person and assessing the tree, I have developed a quote for your review.

Use of crane to remove all dead branches - $1,000
Chipper to take care of all debris - $500
Removal of trunk - $200
Grind the stump - $200
Labor and cleanup - $200
Total = $2,100

This quote includes the guarantee of leaving the yard clean and in the same condition as prior to the start of the job. All parts of the tree will be removed from your property, the stump will be ground up, and the hole filled with mulch.

If this is acceptable to you, please give me a call at 216-554-2343 so we can schedule a date for this job. Thank you for your time.

Sincerely,
Lamar Johnson
Owner Affordable Tree Inc.
